text: father, Mark Walker, expressed his devastation at the loss of his wife and son. "Julie and Lucas were the light of my life. I can't believe they're gone," he said in a statement to the press. The tragic incident occurred on a sunny Saturday afternoon at Aberdeen Beach, where the family had gone for a day out. Eyewitnesses reported seeing Lucas playing in the shallow water, with Julie keeping a close eye on him from the shore. Suddenly, a strong wave hit the beach, pulling Lucas further into the sea. Desperate to save her son, Julie rushed into the water, fighting against the strong currents. She managed to reach Lucas and hold onto him for a few precious moments before they were both overpowered by the waves. Witnesses on the shore called emergency services and brave onlookers attempted to rescue them, but the treacherous waters made it difficult to reach the pair. When the coastguard finally arrived, Julie and Lucas were pulled from the water and rushed to hospital. Despite the best efforts of the medical staff, they could not be revived. The Aberdeen community was left in shock and mourning for the loss of such a beloved mother and son. Julie was known in the local area as a devoted mother who always put her son's needs above everything else. Lucas, a bubbly and energetic young boy, had a smile that could light up any room. The Walker family had been looking forward to spending the summer together, making plans for picnics in the park and trips to the beach. Now, those dreams lay shattered, leaving behind only memories of happier times. As the news of the tragedy spread, messages of condolences poured in from friends, family, and well-wishers. Floral tributes were placed on Aberdeen Beach in memory of Julie and Lucas, offering a small comfort to those grieving their loss. The authorities have launched an investigation into the incident, focusing on the safety measures in place at Aberdeen Beach and whether more could have been done to prevent such a tragedy. Local officials have urged beachgoers to be cautious when swimming in the sea and to always respect the power of the water. For Mark Walker, the pain of losing his wife and son was unimaginable. "I never thought I would have to bury my own family," he said, tears streaming down his face. "Julie and Lucas will always be in my heart, and I will never forget the love and joy they brought into my life." The community rallied around Mark, offering their support and condolences during this difficult time of grief and loss.

title: Aquamarine Power hails Oyster wave device test results
text: The Edinburgh-based firm spent months testing the device at the European Marine Energy Centre (EMEC) in Orkney. It said operational data collected during the tests demonstrated significant improvements in performance compared to previous models. The Oyster wave device is designed to harness the power of ocean waves to generate electricity, providing a renewable and sustainable energy source. During the testing phase, Aquamarine Power was able to gather valuable data on the device's efficiency, reliability, and overall performance. This data will be crucial as the company continues to refine and improve the technology for widespread commercial use. The successful test results mark a major milestone for Aquamarine Power and bring the company one step closer to achieving its goal of providing clean energy solutions for a greener future. One of the key advantages of the Oyster wave device is its simplicity and durability. Unlike other wave energy technologies that require complex infrastructure and maintenance, the Oyster device is designed to be robust and easy to deploy. This makes it ideal for remote or challenging environments where traditional power sources may be limited or unreliable. In addition to its technical advantages, the Oyster wave device also offers environmental benefits. By harnessing the power of ocean waves, Aquamarine Power is able to provide a renewable energy source that reduces dependence on fossil fuels and helps to lower carbon emissions. This aligns with global efforts to combat climate change and transition to a more sustainable energy future. Aquamarine Power's successful testing of the Oyster wave device is a significant achievement for the company and the marine energy industry as a whole. The data collected during the tests will be used to further optimize the technology and prepare for commercial deployment in the near future. As the world seeks to reduce its reliance on nonrenewable energy sources, wave energy technologies like the Oyster device hold great promise for a cleaner and more sustainable future. Moving forward, Aquamarine Power is committed to continuing its research and development efforts to further refine the Oyster wave device and bring it to market. With growing interest and investment in renewable energy technologies, the company's success in Orkney is a testament to the potential of wave energy as a viable solution for addressing the world's energy needs in a sustainable and environmentally friendly way.

title: A third of domestic abuse victims 'cannot get legal aid'
text: that access to justice for victims of domestic abuse was being severely compromised. The committee highlighted the concerning fact that a third of domestic abuse victims are unable to access legal aid due to the strict eligibility criteria implemented by the government. This lack of financial support leaves vulnerable individuals at the mercy of their abusers, unable to seek legal advice or representation to help them navigate the complex legal procedures involved in leaving an abusive relationship. Without the assistance of a lawyer, victims often struggle to understand their legal rights and options, making it harder for them to break free from the cycle of abuse they are trapped in. The report emphasized that legal aid is crucial in helping victims secure protective orders, access housing and financial support, and ultimately rebuild their lives free from violence and intimidation. Furthermore, the committee raised concerns about the impact of the government's legal aid cuts on specialist domestic abuse services, which have seen a significant decrease in funding in recent years. These services play a vital role in supporting victims through trauma-informed care, providing counseling, advocacy, and practical support to help them recover from the effects of abuse. The committee called on the government to urgently review its legal aid policy and ensure that victims of domestic abuse have the support they need to access justice and rebuild their lives. It also recommended increased funding for specialist services to ensure that victims receive the holistic support they require to overcome the trauma of abuse. In response to the report, a spokesperson for the Ministry of Justice acknowledged the importance of legal aid in supporting victims of domestic abuse and committed to reviewing the eligibility criteria to ensure that those in need receive the assistance they require. The spokesperson also highlighted the government's commitment to addressing domestic abuse through the landmark Domestic Abuse Bill, which aims to improve support for victims and hold perpetrators accountable for their actions. The Justice Select Committee's report serves as a stark reminder of the challenges faced by domestic abuse victims in accessing justice and the urgent need for policy changes to ensure that no victim is left without the support they need to break free from abuse. It is imperative that the government takes swift action to address these shortcomings and prioritize the needs of survivors in order to create a society free from domestic violence.

title: BCP Council leader Vikki Slade ousted in second confidence vote loss
text: Lib Dem Vikki Slade failed to win support over a Tory motion stating "a high level of public frustration and mistrust" in her leadership, leading to her ousting as leader of BCP Council in a second confidence vote loss. The motion, which was supported by Conservative councillors in the Bournemouth, Christchurch, and Poole areas, highlighted concerns over Slade's handling of various issues, including the council's response to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. Slade, who has been in the position since May 2019, faced criticism from both opposition councillors and members of her own party for what they perceived as indecisiveness and poor communication. The Tory motion, which was presented at a full council meeting, also cited concerns about the council's financial management under Slade's leadership. During the debate, Conservative councillor Drew Mellor argued that there was a "demonstrable lack of leadership" from Slade, pointing to a series of missteps and controversies that had eroded public confidence in the council. He accused Slade of failing to provide clear direction and of making decisions without adequate consultation with council members or the public. In response, Slade defended her record, highlighting achievements such as the council's response to the Covid-19 crisis, efforts to tackle climate change, and investments in local infrastructure. She acknowledged that there were challenges facing the council but argued that she was committed to addressing them in a constructive and collaborative manner. Despite her efforts to defend her leadership, the motion ultimately passed with a majority of councillors voting against Slade. The result effectively removed her from the position of council leader, leaving the door open for a new leader to be elected. The ousting of Slade comes at a challenging time for BCP Council, as it continues to grapple with the impacts of the pandemic and the need to rebuild public trust in local government. The decision to remove Slade from her role reflects growing concerns among councillors and the public about the council's ability to effectively govern and deliver services to residents. As the search for a new leader begins, councillors from all parties will need to work together to ensure a smooth transition and restore confidence in the council's ability to lead the community. The outcome of the confidence vote serves as a reminder of the importance of strong and effective leadership in times of crisis, and the need for accountability and transparency in local government.

title: Kent MPs lobbied to support Thames estuary airport
text: Johnson added, "I understand the arguments in favor of the proposed airport, but I believe there are better alternatives that should be explored first." Holloway echoed these sentiments, stating, "I have concerns about the environmental impact and disruption to local communities that an airport in the Thames Estuary could bring." The meeting with Moylan, who is a long-time advocate for the Thames Estuary airport, highlighted the ongoing debate surrounding the controversial project. Proponents argue that a new airport in the estuary would help alleviate the capacity constraints at Heathrow and Gatwick, as well as create thousands of jobs in the local area. However, opponents, including the Kent MPs, have raised a number of concerns about the feasibility and viability of the project. They argue that the environmental impact on the delicate ecosystem of the estuary, as well as the noise pollution and disruption to local communities, outweigh the potential benefits. The debate over the Thames Estuary airport has been ongoing for years, with various proposals and plans being put forward and subsequently scrapped. The issue has divided opinion among politicians, local residents, and environmental groups, with both sides presenting compelling arguments for and against the project. Despite the opposition from Kent MPs, supporters of the Thames Estuary airport continue to push for the project to be given serious consideration. They argue that the airport would not only provide much-needed additional capacity for air travel in the region but also stimulate economic growth and create new opportunities for businesses. With the future of aviation in the UK being a hotly debated topic, the question of whether or not a new airport in the Thames Estuary is the right solution remains unanswered. As the debate continues to intensify, it is clear that both sides are committed to making their voices heard and advocating for what they believe is the best course of action for the region. As Kent MPs continue to lobby against the construction of a Thames Estuary airport, the future of the project remains uncertain. With strong opinions on both sides of the debate, it is likely that the discussion will continue for some time to come, with no clear resolution in sight. The decision on whether or not to proceed with the airport will ultimately rest in the hands of policymakers and stakeholders, who will need to carefully weigh the arguments and consider the potential impacts of such a significant development.

title: Unilever: Ice cream in, personal hygiene out in lockdown
text: The firm said ice cream sales leapt 26% in the three months to June, but demand for shampoo and deodorant fell. It said it had seen strong "growth in home consumption of foods," as people stayed indoors during the lockdown. The COVID-19 pandemic has undoubtedly changed consumer behavior, with more people opting to indulge in comfort foods like ice cream rather than personal hygiene products. Unilever, one of the world's largest consumer goods companies, reported a mixed bag of results in the face of the global health crisis. While its ice cream brands, such as Ben & Jerry's and Magnum, experienced a surge in sales as people sought solace in sweet treats during the lockdown, its personal care products struggled to maintain traction in the market. The shift in consumer preferences towards food and beverage products can be attributed to the closure of restaurants and cafes, which forced people to cook and eat at home. As a result, Unilever witnessed a significant increase in the demand for its food and refreshment segment, which includes popular brands like Knorr, Hellmann's, and Lipton. In contrast, the company's beauty and personal care division faced challenges as people prioritized essential items over luxury products. With more individuals working remotely and socializing less, the need for grooming and personal hygiene products decreased significantly. This led to a decline in sales of items like shampoo, deodorant, and skincare products, affecting Unilever's overall revenue in the second quarter. Despite the obstacles faced by its personal care segment, Unilever remains optimistic about its long-term prospects. The company has adapted its marketing strategies to meet the evolving needs of consumers and has introduced innovative products to cater to changing trends. For instance, its hygiene portfolio now includes hand sanitizers and antibacterial soaps, which have experienced heightened demand in the wake of the pandemic. Unilever's ability to pivot and capitalize on emerging opportunities has allowed it to weather the storm caused by COVID-19. By focusing on consumer needs and investing in product development, the company remains resilient in the face of uncertainty. As the world gradually reopens and adjusts to the new normal, Unilever continues to monitor market trends and consumer behavior to stay ahead of the curve in a rapidly changing landscape.

title: Nick Grimshaw's Radio 1 debut impresses critics
text: The Telegraph's Michael Hogan was impressed by Grimshaw's "youthful energy and enthusiasm for new music". The Guardian's Elisabeth Mahoney said Grimshaw made a confident debut. It was "a very promising, refreshing start that politely challenged the station's music policy," she added. Grimshaw took over the popular morning slot on BBC Radio 1 following the departure of Chris Moyles, who had been a mainstay on the station for over eight years. Grimshaw's debut was highly anticipated, with many wondering how he would fill the shoes of his predecessor. But Grimshaw proved to be a breath of fresh air for listeners, with his laid-back and friendly presenting style. He seamlessly mixed new tracks with classic hits, appealing to a wide range of musical tastes. His ability to connect with his audience was evident, as he effortlessly engaged with callers and guests throughout the show. Critics praised Grimshaw for bringing a new energy to the morning slot, with The Independent's Alice Jones calling him "a natural fit for Radio 1". She highlighted his ability to keep the show moving at a fast pace while still managing to inject his own personality into the mix. Grimshaw's choice of music was also a hit with critics, with many applauding his willingness to showcase up-and-coming artists alongside established acts. The Daily Mail's Mark Jefferies noted that Grimshaw's playlist was "fresh and exciting, reflecting his passion for new music." In addition to his musical selections, Grimshaw's banter with co-hosts and guests was a highlight of the show. His quick wit and natural charm made him instantly likable, with The Times' Helen Brown praising him for his ability to "lighten up the morning with his infectious personality." Overall, Grimshaw's debut was met with positive reviews from critics and listeners alike. His unique approach to the morning slot breathed new life into the station, attracting a younger audience while still maintaining the core Radio 1 demographic. As Grimshaw settles into his new role, it is clear that he has the potential to become a long-standing fixture on BBC Radio 1. With his passion for music, engaging personality, and ability to connect with his audience, Grimshaw is well on his way to becoming a beloved radio host for years to come.

title: Lancashire County Council election: Tories gain control
text: The authority had been under no overall control, with Labour the biggest party by four councillors. Nationally, the UK Independence Party (UKIP) suffered huge losses, but they did manage to gain the Padiham and Burnley West ward. However, it was the Conservatives who made significant gains in the Lancashire County Council election, ultimately securing control of the council. The Conservative Party gained a total of 10 seats, bringing their total to 45 seats on the council. This was a significant shift in power, as the council had previously been led by a coalition of Labour, Liberal Democrats, and independents. The Labour Party suffered losses in this election, losing a total of six seats and ending up with 33 seats on the council. This was a disappointing result for Labour, who had hoped to maintain their position as the largest party on the council. The Liberal Democrats also saw a decrease in their representation on the council, losing two seats and ending up with four councillors. Independents had a mixed outcome in this election, with some gaining seats while others lost, leaving them with a total of 22 seats on the council. The results of this election highlight the changing political landscape in Lancashire, with the Conservative Party making gains at the expense of Labour and other parties. The Tories' victory was seen as a sign of growing support for their policies and leadership in the region. One of the key issues in this election was the council's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic. The Conservative Party campaigned on a platform of economic recovery and supporting local businesses, which resonated with voters in the region. Overall, the Lancashire County Council election results reflect a shift in political power towards the Conservative Party. With their new majority on the council, the Tories will now have the opportunity to implement their agenda and shape the future of the region. As the new council prepares to take office, there will be challenges ahead in addressing issues such as economic recovery, social care, and local infrastructure. The newly elected councillors will have a mandate to deliver on their promises and work towards improving the lives of residents in Lancashire.

title: Concern at mortality rates at two Lanarkshire hospitals
text: Lanarkshire has been alerted to concerning mortality rates at two of its hospitals, Monklands and Wishaw General Hospitals. According to recent data, both hospitals have recorded higher rates than the national average during the last quarter. This has prompted Healthcare Improvement Scotland (HIS) to launch an investigation into the matter, with Hairmyres Hospital in East Kilbride also set to be scrutinized. NHS Lanarkshire, the health board responsible for the hospitals in question, has acknowledged the need for a thorough examination of the mortality rates. The board has pledged to cooperate fully with HIS and to provide any necessary information to assist in the investigation. NHS Lanarkshire aims to ensure the safety and quality of care provided at its hospitals, and any issues identified will be addressed promptly and effectively. The higher than average mortality rates at Monklands and Wishaw General Hospitals have raised concerns among the local community and healthcare professionals. Patients and their families deserve to have confidence in the healthcare services they receive, and any indications of substandard care must be addressed promptly. HIS's investigation will seek to determine the root causes of the higher mortality rates and to recommend measures for improvement. Monklands and Wishaw General Hospitals play a vital role in providing healthcare services to the people of Lanarkshire. The staff at these hospitals work tirelessly to care for patients and to save lives, and it is essential that they have the resources and support necessary to deliver high-quality care. Any issues affecting patient safety and outcomes must be identified and addressed to ensure that patients receive the best possible care. The investigation by HIS will also encompass Hairmyres Hospital in East Kilbride, another important healthcare facility in Lanarkshire. By examining the mortality rates at all three hospitals, HIS will be able to gain a comprehensive understanding of any common factors contributing to the higher rates. This will enable the health board to implement targeted interventions to improve patient outcomes and reduce mortality rates. As the investigation unfolds, NHS Lanarkshire will continue to prioritize the safety and well-being of its patients. The health board is committed to transparency and accountability in addressing any issues that may arise. By working collaboratively with HIS and other stakeholders, NHS Lanarkshire is dedicated to providing the highest standards of care to the people of Lanarkshire.

title: UK plans £3m no-deal medicine transport
text: By Howard Mustoe & Joe Miller Business reporter It wants to hire an "express freight service" to transport medicines, blood, and transplant tissue. But experts have raised concerns about the feasibility of the UK government's plans to spend £3m on a no-deal Brexit medicine transport scheme. The Department of Health and Social Care announced the new investment, which will be used to secure transport services in the event of a no-deal Brexit. The department cited the need to ensure the supply of vital medical products in any scenario as the primary reason for the funding. However, critics argue that the plan may be overly ambitious, given the tight timeframe and the complexities involved in transporting medical supplies. The logistics of transporting medicines with strict temperature requirements, such as vaccines and certain medications, could pose significant challenges for any express freight service. Additionally, concerns have been raised about the availability of qualified and experienced transport providers who can meet the specific regulatory requirements for transporting medical goods. As such, there are doubts about whether the £3m investment will be sufficient to secure a reliable and efficient transport service for these critical supplies. The plan comes amid growing uncertainty surrounding the UK's departure from the European Union, scheduled for March 29. With less than two months to go until the deadline, the government is facing increasing pressure to ensure that medical supplies are not disrupted in the event of a no-deal Brexit. The potential for delays at the UK's borders and disruptions to supply chains have raised concerns about the availability of essential medicines and medical products. The Department of Health and Social Care has stated that it will be working closely with the pharmaceutical industry to develop contingency plans for the transportation of medical supplies in the event of a no-deal Brexit. It is crucial that these plans are robust and comprehensive to ensure that patients continue to receive the treatments they need without interruption. The government has also emphasized the need for transparency and accountability in its planning for post-Brexit healthcare logistics. It has pledged to provide regular updates on the progress of the £3m no-deal medicine transport scheme and to engage with industry stakeholders to address any concerns or challenges that may arise. While the government's efforts to secure the transport of medical supplies in a no-deal Brexit scenario are commendable, it remains to be seen whether the £3m investment will be sufficient to address the complex logistical challenges that lie ahead. With just weeks remaining until the Brexit deadline, time is of the essence for ensuring that patients can access the medicines and medical treatments they rely on.

title: Russia halts Lithuania dairy imports in trade row
text: Russia's consumer watchdog said the levels of yeast and mould in Lithuanian dairy produce were unacceptable. Lithuania is already involved in a bitter dispute with Russia over the imports of its dairy products, and the latest halt in imports is expected to escalate tensions between the two countries. The move by Russia to temporarily halt dairy imports from Lithuania comes after the country banned certain Lithuanian dairy products in the past due to alleged quality control issues. Lithuania has denied the accusations and has accused Russia of using food safety concerns as a pretext to impose trade restrictions on the country. The Russian consumer watchdog, Rospotrebnadzor, stated that recent inspections of Lithuanian dairy facilities revealed high levels of yeast and mould in the products. The agency argued that these levels posed a risk to public health and safety, thus justifying the decision to halt imports from Lithuania. Lithuania has condemned Russia's decision as unjustified and politically motivated. The country's Minister of Agriculture, Giedrius Surplys, stated that Lithuania fully complies with European Union regulations on food safety and quality, and that the ban on its dairy products is unwarranted. The trade dispute between Russia and Lithuania has deepened in recent years, with the two countries imposing tit-for-tat measures on each other's exports. Lithuania, which heavily relies on exports to Russia for its dairy industry, has been particularly hard hit by the trade restrictions imposed by Moscow. In response to the halt in dairy imports from Lithuania, the Lithuanian government is considering retaliatory measures against Russian exports. However, such actions are likely to further escalate the trade dispute and harm the economic interests of both countries. The European Union has expressed support for Lithuania and called on Russia to lift the ban on its dairy products. The EU has also warned Russia of potential consequences if it continues to impose unjustified trade restrictions on member states. The halt in dairy imports from Lithuania is just the latest chapter in the ongoing trade dispute between Russia and Lithuania. As the two countries continue to engage in a war of words and trade restrictions, the future of their economic relations remains uncertain. It is unclear how long the halt in dairy imports will last, and whether the two countries will be able to resolve their differences and restore normal trade relations.

title: Coronavirus: London key workers to star on cover of British Vogue
text: A London Overground train driver, an east London midwife, and a King's Cross supermarket worker will all feature on July's front page. Photographer Jamie Hawkesworth captured the key workers in their element, showcasing the dedication and hard work they have displayed throughout the coronavirus pandemic. The decision to feature these essential workers on the cover of British Vogue comes as a tribute to the millions of key workers who have kept the country running during these challenging times. From healthcare workers to delivery drivers, these everyday heroes have played a vital role in keeping the nation safe and secure. The train driver, midwife, and supermarket worker chosen to grace the cover represent the diverse range of key workers who have gone above and beyond in their duties. They symbolize the resilience and strength of the British workforce, showing that no matter the circumstances, they are willing to step up and do their part. In a statement, British Vogue's editor-in-chief, Edward Enninful, praised the key workers for their selfless dedication and unwavering commitment to their jobs. He emphasized the importance of recognizing and celebrating their contributions during these unprecedented times. The cover shoot with the key workers is a departure from the typical high-fashion spreads usually featured in Vogue, but it serves as a powerful reminder of the extraordinary individuals who have kept the country moving forward. The shoot captures the essence of the key workers' spirit, showcasing their determination and resilience in the face of adversity. The images captured by Jamie Hawkesworth are striking and emotive, capturing the essence of each key worker's personality and strength. From the train driver's steely gaze to the midwife's gentle smile, each portrait tells a story of courage and determination. As the country begins to emerge from the grips of the pandemic, it is important to remember and honor the sacrifices made by key workers. Their selfless dedication and tireless efforts have not gone unnoticed, and British Vogue's decision to feature them on the cover is a fitting tribute to their bravery and resilience. The July issue of British Vogue promises to be a poignant and moving tribute to the key workers who have kept the country running during these difficult times. It serves as a reminder of the power of community and the strength of the human spirit in the face of adversity.

title: British Steel in talks with government to avert collapse
text: secure its future and prevent collapse. The company, which employs around 5,000 workers, has been facing challenges due to a variety of factors, including a weak global steel market, rising costs, and uncertainty surrounding Brexit. British Steel's struggles have raised concerns about the impact on the UK's steel industry, which has already seen several high-profile closures in recent years. Unions have warned that the collapse of British Steel would be a devastating blow to the sector and would put thousands of jobs at risk. In a statement, British Steel acknowledged the difficult trading conditions it is facing and emphasized the need for government support to help address its current financial challenges. The company also highlighted its commitment to working with the government to find a sustainable solution that will enable it to continue operations and safeguard jobs. Sources close to the discussions have indicated that British Steel is seeking a loan of around £75 million from the government to help alleviate its immediate cash flow problems. The company is also reportedly in talks with potential buyers and investors in an effort to secure additional funding to support its long-term viability. The government has expressed its willingness to support British Steel, with Business Secretary Greg Clark stating that ministers are actively engaged in discussions with the company and its owners to explore all options to secure a positive future for the business. Clark emphasized the importance of the steel industry to the UK economy and pledged to work closely with British Steel to find a way forward. The potential collapse of British Steel comes at a challenging time for the UK manufacturing sector, which has been impacted by ongoing uncertainty surrounding Brexit and a slowdown in global economic growth. The government has faced criticism for its handling of the situation, with opposition politicians calling for more decisive action to support the steel industry and protect jobs. As talks between British Steel and the government continue, workers at the company are anxiously awaiting news of a potential rescue plan. Many are concerned about the future of their jobs and the impact that a collapse of British Steel could have on their communities. In the coming days, all eyes will be on the negotiations between British Steel and the government as they work towards a deal to secure the company's future. The outcome of these talks will not only determine the fate of British Steel but will also have far-reaching implications for the UK steel industry as a whole.

title: Lagarde warns UK of pain ahead as Brexit approaches
text: Kamal Ahmed Economics editor @bbckamal on Twitter Christine Lagarde told the BBC the Brexit process would be complicated. She said that although the UK had officially left the European Union, there were still many uncertainties and challenges ahead. In an interview with the BBC, Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund (IMF), warned that the UK would face pain as Brexit approached. She emphasized the importance of a smooth and orderly transition to minimize disruption to the economy. "Brexit is not a simple process," Lagarde said. "There will be challenges and uncertainties along the way. It is crucial for the UK to have a clear plan and to prepare for the potential impact on businesses, trade, and investment." Lagarde highlighted the need for the UK to negotiate a trade deal with the EU to ensure continued access to the single market. She cautioned that failure to reach an agreement could have negative consequences for both the UK and the EU. "The UK must be prepared for a range of scenarios, including the possibility of a no-deal Brexit," Lagarde said. "It is important for both sides to work together to find a mutually beneficial solution that will minimize the economic costs of Brexit." Lagarde's comments come as the UK government continues to negotiate the terms of its future relationship with the EU. Prime Minister Boris Johnson has vowed to leave the EU by the end of 2020, with or without a trade deal. However, Lagarde's warning is a reminder of the potential risks and uncertainties that lie ahead. The UK economy is already facing challenges due to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic, and Brexit could further exacerbate these difficulties. Despite the challenges ahead, Lagarde expressed confidence in the resilience of the UK economy. She noted that the UK had already taken steps to mitigate the economic impact of Brexit, such as providing support for businesses and workers affected by the transition. As the UK prepares to enter a new chapter in its relationship with the EU, Lagarde's warning serves as a timely reminder of the need for careful planning and preparation. The road ahead may be bumpy, but with the right approach, the UK can navigate the challenges of Brexit and emerge stronger on the other side.

title: US 'may free Israel spy Jonathan Pollard'
text: US official told the New York Times that no decisions had been made, but confirmed there had been discussions. Israel would have to make significant concessions to the Palestinians in return, reports said. Pollard, a former US Navy intelligence analyst, was convicted of spying for Israel in 1987 and sentenced to life in prison. Speculation about a potential release for Pollard has been swirling for years, with some in Israel pushing for his freedom as a way to strengthen ties between the two countries. Pollard's supporters argue that his sentence is overly harsh and that he has already served more than enough time behind bars. The issue of Pollard's release is a sensitive one, with many in the US intelligence community strongly opposed to the idea. They argue that releasing him would send the wrong message to other would-be spies and could harm US national security interests. However, some US officials believe that releasing Pollard could be a way to advance peace negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians. The Trump administration has been working to broker a peace deal between the two sides, and securing Pollard's release could be seen as a goodwill gesture towards Israel. Pollard's case has long been a source of tension between the US and Israel, with the Israeli government repeatedly calling for his release. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has personally raised the issue with US officials on multiple occasions, but previous administrations have been reluctant to grant his request. If Pollard is indeed released, it would likely be conditioned on Israel making significant concessions to the Palestinians in return. This could include actions such as freezing settlement construction in the West Bank or agreeing to a two-state solution, both of which are key demands of the Palestinian leadership. Despite the potential political implications of Pollard's release, some argue that it would be a small price to pay for advancing peace in the region. The Israeli-Palestinian conflict has been a longstanding source of instability in the Middle East, and any progress towards a peaceful resolution would be welcomed by the international community. As of now, it remains to be seen whether Pollard will indeed be granted clemency by the US government. The decision will likely be heavily influenced by ongoing peace negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians and the broader geopolitical situation in the region. Regardless of the outcome, the issue of Pollard's release will continue to be a point of contention between the US and Israel for the foreseeable future.

title: Government says sorry to women 'ignored' by doctors
text: By Zoe KleinmanReporter, BBC News Nadine Dorries was giving a statement in Parliament, on the Cumberlege review, published on Wednesday. The review, which had heard from about 700 women, revealed shocking instances where women had been ignored by healthcare professionals, leading to serious and sometimes life-changing consequences. In her statement, Ms. Dorries expressed the government's deep regret for the pain and suffering experienced by these women. She acknowledged that there had been a systemic failure in the healthcare system to listen to and prioritize the needs of female patients, particularly when it came to issues such as pelvic mesh implants, hormone pregnancy tests, and sodium valproate. The Cumberlege review highlighted how these women had been dismissed, belittled, and ignored by doctors who failed to take their symptoms seriously. Many of them had been left with debilitating injuries and long-term health issues as a result of medical interventions that were not properly researched or communicated to patients. As part of the government's response to the review, Ms. Dorries announced a series of measures aimed at improving patient safety and ensuring that women are no longer disregarded or overlooked by healthcare professionals. These included implementing a new patient safety commissioner, creating a redress scheme for those affected by medical negligence, and establishing a task force to address the recommendations laid out in the Cumberlege review. Ms. Dorries also emphasized the importance of raising awareness among healthcare professionals about the unique healthcare needs of women, including the need for improved training and education on gender-specific health issues. She stressed that it was crucial for doctors to listen to and believe women when they report symptoms or concerns, rather than dismissing them as hysterical or overreacting. The government's apology and commitment to reforming the healthcare system were welcomed by patient advocacy groups and women's rights organizations. Many survivors of medical harm expressed relief that their voices had finally been heard and validated, and that steps were being taken to prevent similar incidents from happening in the future. Moving forward, the focus will be on implementing the recommendations of the Cumberlege review and ensuring that the mistakes of the past are not repeated. The government's apology is a significant step towards acknowledging and addressing the systemic failures that have harmed countless women across the country, and it is hoped that this will lead to positive change and better healthcare outcomes for all patients.

title: Donegal crash: Mullan family funeral hears there are 'no words and no answers'
text: By Keiron Tourish BBC News NI John Mullan, 49, his six-year-old daughter Amelia, and 14-year-old stepson Tomas died in the crash. Their mother, Geraldine Mullan, managed to escape and raise the alarm. She told their funeral in County Donegal that she was still struggling to come to terms with the tragic loss of her husband and two children. "There are no words and no answers," Geraldine said through tears, surrounded by grieving family and friends. "I can't make sense of why this happened to us. John was a loving husband and a devoted father, Amelia and Tomas were bright, beautiful children with their whole lives ahead of them. Now they're gone, and I'm left asking why." The community in Donegal has been left reeling by the tragedy, with many struggling to comprehend how such a devastating accident could happen to a family that was so deeply loved and respected. The funeral service was attended by hundreds of mourners, who came to pay their respects and offer support to the grieving family. The local priest, Father Declan O'Carroll, spoke of the pain and sorrow that the Mullan family's deaths had brought to the tight-knit community. "We are all struggling to find words of comfort in the face of such profound loss," he said. "Our hearts are heavy with grief, and our thoughts are with Geraldine as she navigates the difficult road ahead without her beloved husband and children by her side." As the funeral procession made its way to the cemetery, there was a palpable sense of sadness in the air. The sound of mournful hymns filled the air, as friends and family members clung to each other for support. The loss of three lives in such a tragic and sudden manner has left a deep scar on the community, with many still reeling from the shock of the crash. As the coffins were lowered into the ground, there was a collective sense of disbelief and sorrow among those in attendance. The reality of the loss of John, Amelia, and Tomas began to sink in, and the full weight of their absence was felt by all. In the days and weeks to come, the community will rally around Geraldine and offer her whatever support and comfort they can. The road ahead will be long and difficult, but she can take solace in the knowledge that she is not alone in her grief. The memory of John, Amelia, and Tomas will live on in the hearts of all who knew and loved them, and they will never be forgotten.

title: Covid: West Midlands universities plan lockdown lectures
text: The University of Wolverhampton and Keele University in Staffordshire both said teaching would continue online. However, students in some subjects will have to wait for some lessons to become possible again, the universities said. Meanwhile, other universities in the West Midlands are also planning to move lectures and seminars online as part of efforts to curb the spread of Covid-19. The decision comes as the number of cases in the region continues to rise, prompting concerns about the safety of students and staff. Both universities cited the need to prioritize the health and well-being of their communities as the main reason for the move to online learning. "We have been closely monitoring the situation and have decided that it is in the best interest of our students and staff to move all lectures online for the time being," said a spokesperson for the University of Wolverhampton. "We understand that this may be disappointing for some students, but we believe that this is the safest course of action given the current circumstances." Similarly, Keele University emphasized the importance of taking proactive measures to protect the university community. "While we understand that face-to-face teaching is beneficial for many students, we feel that the risk of transmission is too high at the moment," said a spokesperson for Keele University. "We are committed to providing a safe learning environment for our students, and moving lectures online is one way that we can achieve this." The decision to move lectures online has been met with mixed reactions from students. Some have expressed disappointment at the prospect of missing out on in-person interactions with their peers and professors, while others have welcomed the move as a necessary step to protect the health and safety of the university community. "I understand why the university is taking this step, but it's still disappointing to miss out on the full university experience," said Sarah, a third-year student at the University of Wolverhampton. "I will miss seeing my classmates and professors in person, but I know that this is the right decision given the current situation." Despite the challenges posed by the move to online learning, both universities have expressed their commitment to providing high-quality education to their students. They have reassured students that they will do everything in their power to support them during this difficult time and ensure that they have the resources they need to succeed in their studies. As the situation continues to evolve, the universities will closely monitor developments and make adjustments as necessary to keep their communities safe. In the meantime, students are encouraged to stay informed, follow public health guidelines, and reach out for support if needed.

title: Cladding: MPs fail in bid to change fire safety payment rules
text: £78,000 to ensure their buildings are safe. MPs have failed in their bid to change the rules around who pays for the necessary fire safety improvements, leaving many leaseholders in a state of uncertainty. The government has allocated £5.1 billion to help fund the removal and replacement of unsafe cladding on high-rise buildings above 18 meters. However, this funding does not cover all necessary fire safety upgrades, leaving many flat owners with hefty bills to foot. Leaseholders have expressed their frustration and financial concerns, arguing that they should not be held responsible for the failings of building regulations and developers. Many are already struggling to make ends meet due to the economic impact of the ongoing pandemic, making unexpected expenses like cladding repairs extremely burdensome. Some MPs have called for a change in the rules to ensure that flat owners are not unfairly burdened with the costs of fire safety improvements. They argue that it is the responsibility of the government to ensure the safety of all residents, regardless of who owns the building. Despite these calls for change, the Fire Safety Bill has passed through Parliament without any amendments to the payment rules. This has left many leaseholders feeling vulnerable and uncertain about their financial futures. In response to the government's failure to address the issue of cladding costs, many residents have taken matters into their own hands. Some have organized protests and demonstrations to demand justice and fair treatment for all those affected by the cladding crisis. The lack of action from the government has also raised concerns about the potential for another tragedy like the Grenfell Tower fire to occur. Without adequate fire safety measures in place, residents fear that their lives are at risk and that the government is not doing enough to protect them. As leaseholders continue to struggle with the financial burden of cladding repairs, many are calling for urgent action to address this pressing issue. They are demanding that the government step up and take responsibility for ensuring the safety of all residents, regardless of who owns their building. In the meantime, leaseholders are left with mounting costs and uncertainty about their futures as they wait for a resolution to the cladding crisis. The fight for fair treatment and justice continues as residents push for change and demand accountability from those in power.

title: Manchester attack: Veil of quiet respect descends over city
text: By Tom MullenBBC News Online  Tuesday's proud show of solidarity and defiance at a vigil in Albert Square appears to have given way to a sense of quiet respect that has settled over the city of Manchester in the wake of the tragic attack. As the shock and disbelief of Monday night's bombing slowly dissipates, the city is coming together in mourning, reflection, and unity. The streets are noticeably quieter today, as residents and visitors alike pay their respects to the victims of the attack. Floral tributes line the streets, and messages of love and support adorn the city's buildings. In a show of solidarity, many people are wearing the symbolic bee badges that have come to represent the strength and resilience of Manchester in the face of adversity. While the city grapples with grief and loss, there is also a sense of determination to stand together and not let fear and hatred divide us. The kindness and compassion that has been shown in the aftermath of the attack is a testament to the unbreakable spirit of the people of Manchester. Police presence remains heavy in the city, with armed officers patrolling the streets and security heightened at key locations. Though this visible reminder of the tragedy is unsettling, it also serves as a comfort to many who are reassured by the swift and strong response of law enforcement. In the midst of the sadness and uncertainty, stories of heroism and selflessness have emerged. Tales of strangers helping strangers, of emergency responders working tirelessly to save lives, and of ordinary people going above and beyond to assist those in need. These acts of bravery and compassion are a shining light in the darkness of this tragedy, reminding us all of the goodness that exists in the world. As the investigation into the attack continues, the city is coming to terms with the reality of what has happened. The loss of innocent lives, the pain of the injured and their families, and the sense of vulnerability that comes with such a senseless act of violence. But as we mourn those who have been taken from us too soon, we also honor their memory by standing together as a community and refusing to be broken by fear. The veil of quiet respect that has descended over Manchester is a sign of the city's strength and resilience. We will grieve, we will mourn, but we will also stand tall and show the world that love will always conquer hate. Manchester will not be defined by this tragedy, but by the way its people come together in the face of adversity.

title: BT signs 5G deal with Ericsson to help ditch Huawei
text: By Leo Kelion Technology desk editor  BT said in time it expected 50% of all its 5G traffic to be transmitted via the Swedish company's kit. The move will let it ditch Huawei without becoming totally dependent on one supplier in what is still a highly competitive and fast-evolving market. The announcement comes as part of BT's ongoing efforts to phase out the use of Huawei equipment in its 5G network infrastructure. The UK government has mandated that all mobile operators must stop installing Huawei's 5G gear by the end of September 2021 due to security concerns. The deal with Ericsson represents a significant step in BT's journey towards achieving this goal. By diversifying its supplier base and reducing reliance on Huawei, BT aims to enhance the security and resilience of its network while also maintaining a competitive edge in the rapidly growing 5G market. Huawei has faced increased scrutiny and pressure from Western governments over allegations of close ties to the Chinese government and concerns about the security of its equipment. In response, Huawei has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing and emphasized its commitment to transparency and compliance with global standards. BT's decision to partner with Ericsson highlights the growing importance of trust, security, and resilience in the deployment of 5G networks. As the demand for high-speed and reliable connectivity continues to rise, operators must prioritize these factors to ensure the integrity and performance of their networks. Ericsson, a long-standing player in the telecommunications industry, has a proven track record of delivering innovative and reliable solutions to network operators worldwide. Its partnership with BT demonstrates its commitment to supporting the UK's 5G rollout and meeting the evolving needs of its customers. In addition to bolstering the security of its network, the deal with Ericsson will also enable BT to take advantage of the latest technological advancements and capabilities offered by the Swedish company. This will position BT at the forefront of 5G innovation and help it deliver a superior and future-proofed network experience to its customers. Overall, BT's partnership with Ericsson signals a new chapter in the evolution of its 5G network infrastructure. By embracing diversity, resilience, and innovation, BT is taking a proactive and strategic approach to address the challenges and opportunities posed by the rapidly evolving 5G landscape. With Ericsson's support, BT is well-positioned to achieve its goals and deliver a secure, high-performance 5G network that meets the needs of its customers and stakeholders.

title: Ex-Celtic Boys Club coach 'touched player's thigh in car'
text: The witness, who played for the team in the 1980s, told a jury the incident happened while Mr Torbett was driving. Mr Torbett, 71, denies sexually abusing four boys over a nine-year period. The High Court in Glasgow heard how the witness had been a promising young player at the time and looked up to Mr Torbett as a coach and mentor. However, the witness described feeling uncomfortable when Mr Torbett began to touch his thigh while they were alone in the car. The witness struggled to come to terms with what was happening, as he had always trusted Mr Torbett and believed he had his best interests at heart. However, the touching escalated to a point where the witness felt violated and scared. He said he didn't know how to react in the moment and chose to stay silent, hoping it would stop soon. The witness's testimony shed light on the culture of fear and silence that permeated the Celtic Boys Club during Mr Torbett's tenure. Many young players saw Mr Torbett as a father figure and were hesitant to speak out against him, fearing the consequences of going against someone in such a position of power. The trial also heard from the other alleged victims, who described similar experiences of being groomed and abused by Mr Torbett. They recounted instances of inappropriate touching, offers of gifts and bribes, and emotional manipulation to keep them quiet. The prosecution argued that Mr Torbett had taken advantage of his position of trust to exploit vulnerable young boys for his own gratification. Mr Torbett's defense team, however, maintained his innocence and claimed that the allegations were part of a conspiracy to tarnish his reputation. They argued that the witnesses' testimonies were inconsistent and unreliable, and that there was no concrete evidence to prove their claims. As the trial continued, the emotional toll on the alleged victims became evident. Many of them struggled to hold back tears as they relived their traumatic experiences on the stand. The trial served as a stark reminder of the lasting impact that sexual abuse can have on victims, both physically and emotionally. The case against Mr Torbett is set to continue, with more witnesses expected to take the stand in the coming days. The outcome of the trial will not only determine Mr Torbett's fate but also shed light on the dark history of abuse within the Celtic Boys Club and the wider football community.

title: Chevron: Indigenous Ecuadoreans seek higher damages
text: By Irene Caselli BBC News, Ecuador A triumphant atmosphere might have been expected as they gathered for a news conference in Quito, given the favorable verdict finally reached in the long-standing legal battle between Chevron and indigenous communities in the Ecuadorean Amazon. However, the mood was more subdued as the indigenous Ecuadoreans sought higher damages and reiterated their demands for justice. The legal saga, which began over two decades ago, has been marked by twists and turns, accusations of fraud, and appeals at various levels of the legal system. Chevron, originally Texaco, was accused of polluting vast swathes of the Ecuadorean Amazon and causing irreparable damage to the environment and people's health. After a lengthy legal battle, an Ecuadorean court initially ruled in favor of the indigenous communities, awarding them $9.5 billion in damages. However, Chevron has refused to pay, arguing that the judgment was obtained through fraud and bribery. The case has since made its way to international arbitration courts, where the dispute continues to be litigated. Despite these setbacks, the indigenous communities remain steadfast in their pursuit of justice. They are seeking to have the damages increased to reflect the full extent of the environmental and human rights violations caused by Chevron's activities in the Amazon. Their leaders have emphasized that the fight is not just about compensation but also about holding the oil giant accountable for its actions. At the heart of the matter lies the issue of environmental justice and the rights of indigenous peoples. The Ecuadorean Amazon is home to numerous indigenous communities who rely on the rainforest for their livelihoods and cultural identity. The contamination caused by oil extraction has had a devastating impact on their way of life, leading to widespread health problems and the destruction of the natural environment. For the indigenous communities, this legal battle represents a fight for their survival and the protection of their ancestral lands. They see the court case as an opportunity to hold Chevron accountable for the harm it has caused and to prevent similar abuses from occurring in the future. As the legal wrangling continues, the indigenous Ecuadoreans remain determined to see justice served. They have vowed to continue their fight until Chevron pays the full amount of damages and takes responsibility for the environmental disaster in the Amazon. Despite the challenges they face, they are unwavering in their commitment to seeking redress for the harm inflicted on their communities and the land they hold sacred.

title: China morning round-up: Illegal workers
text: Shanghai Daily says Vice-Minister of Public Security Yang Huanning told the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress on Wednesday that the crackdown will include improving visa controls and increasing penalties for companies that hire illegal workers. The announcement comes as China steps up efforts to tackle illegal workers in the country, amid concerns of potential security risks and labor rights violations. According to official data, there are an estimated 260,000 illegal workers in China, with the majority coming from neighboring countries such as Vietnam, Myanmar, and North Korea. The crackdown on illegal workers is part of a broader campaign to reform the country's labor market and ensure greater protection for both Chinese and foreign workers. In recent years, China has made significant progress in improving labor standards and combating labor abuses, but challenges remain, particularly in sectors such as construction, agriculture, and domestic work. In addition to targeting companies that hire illegal workers, the Chinese government is also taking steps to improve the legal status of migrant workers in the country. This includes providing better access to social security benefits, improving working conditions, and ensuring that all workers are paid fairly and on time. Critics, however, argue that the crackdown on illegal workers could have unintended consequences, including driving vulnerable workers further underground and making them more susceptible to exploitation. They also point out that some immigrants come to China out of economic necessity and are forced to work in the informal sector due to restrictive visa policies and limited job opportunities. Despite these challenges, the Chinese government is determined to address the issue of illegal workers and ensure that all workers in the country are treated fairly and with dignity. This includes working closely with other countries to improve border controls and crack down on human trafficking networks that exploit vulnerable workers. Overall, the crackdown on illegal workers in China reflects the government's commitment to upholding the rule of law and protecting the rights of all workers in the country. By improving visa controls, increasing penalties for companies that hire illegal workers, and providing better support for migrant workers, China is taking important steps to ensure a more just and equitable labor market for everyone.

title: 'I'm gay and I was sexually assaulted by a woman'
text: By Shiona McCallum Newsbeat reporter He says he "didn't feel under threat" by his attacker, Cheryl Cottrell, because she was a woman. The film-maker, who is gay, has been struggling with post-traumatic stress disorder since the assault took place. "I think it's important for people to understand that sexual assault can happen to anyone, regardless of their gender or sexual orientation," he says. "I used to think that because I'm a man and she was a woman, I couldn't be a victim of sexual assault. But that's just not true." The film-maker, who wishes to remain anonymous, was sexually assaulted by Cottrell after a night out with friends. He had known her for a while and trusted her, which made the incident even more traumatic for him. "I was in shock afterwards. I couldn't believe what had happened. I kept questioning myself, wondering if I did something to lead her on or if I had somehow given her the wrong impression," he recalls. "But the reality is that she took advantage of me, and it wasn't my fault." He struggled with feelings of shame and guilt in the days following the assault. He didn't want to talk about it with anyone, fearing that he wouldn't be believed or that people would judge him for being a man who was assaulted by a woman. "I felt like I had to hide what happened to me because I didn't fit the stereotype of a sexual assault victim," he says. "But keeping it a secret only made things worse for me. It wasn't until I sought help from a therapist that I began to work through my trauma and learn to accept what happened to me." The film-maker wants to raise awareness about sexual assault against men and encourage others to speak out about their experiences. He believes that breaking the silence surrounding male victims of sexual violence is crucial in helping them heal and seek justice. "I want other men who have been through similar experiences to know that they are not alone and that it's okay to ask for help," he says. "We need to challenge the stereotypes and misconceptions about sexual assault so that all survivors, regardless of their gender, can feel supported and validated." He hopes that sharing his story will help reduce the stigma and shame associated with being a male survivor of sexual assault. By speaking out, he is taking a stand against the idea that men can't be victims of such violence and is advocating for a more inclusive and understanding society.

title: Brexit: Giant lorry park branded 'concrete monstrosity'
text: Construction work on a site off the M20 near Ashford began earlier this month. One resident labelled the plans "sneaky", stating she had not been told about them. The Department for Transport said "commercial sensitivities" prevented them from informing the public, but they assured residents that the lorry park was necessary to deal with potential post-Brexit congestion issues. The construction project, which is expected to be completed by the end of the year, involves turning a 27-acre field into a lorry park that can accommodate up to 2,000 vehicles. The park is intended to provide a space for trucks waiting to cross the Channel in case of delays at the ports due to new customs checks and regulations after Brexit. While some residents have expressed concerns about the visual impact of the lorry park, others are more worried about the potential noise and air pollution it could bring to the area. Local environmental groups have also raised objections to the project, citing the loss of green space and the impact on wildlife in the surrounding area. The Department for Transport has tried to address these concerns by implementing measures to mitigate the environmental impact of the lorry park. They have committed to planting new trees and shrubs around the site to create a green buffer zone and have promised to install noise barriers to reduce the impact on nearby residents. Despite these efforts, opposition to the lorry park remains strong among some residents and environmental groups. They argue that the project is unnecessary and that the government should focus on finding alternative solutions to potential post-Brexit congestion issues, such as investing in infrastructure at the ports. However, the government has defended the need for the lorry park, emphasizing that it is a crucial part of their contingency plans for Brexit. They believe that having a dedicated space for lorries to wait will help ensure the smooth flow of traffic and goods between the UK and the EU after the transition period ends. As construction continues on the site, tensions remain high between those in favor of the lorry park and those opposed to it. The debate over the project reflects the broader divisions in the UK over Brexit and its implications for the country's infrastructure and economy. With the deadline for the end of the transition period fast approaching, the government is under pressure to ensure that the necessary preparations are in place to deal with the potential impacts of Brexit. The lorry park near Ashford is just one of many projects being undertaken to address these challenges, but its controversial nature highlights the complex and divisive nature of the Brexit process.

title: Love Island to return this summer, ITV confirms
text: set their sights on a new exotic location for the upcoming season. Fans of the hit reality show have been eagerly anticipating the return of Love Island after it was put on hold last year due to the ongoing pandemic. The announcement comes as a welcome relief to viewers who have been waiting for their fix of drama, romance, and endless sun-drenched days. Speculation has been rife about who will be entering the villa this summer, with rumors circulating about potential celebrity contestants and surprise appearances from past Islanders. The show has become a cultural phenomenon, with its mix of beautiful singles, tropical settings, and addictive storylines captivating audiences around the globe. Love Island is known for its love triangles, explosive arguments, and unexpected plot twists, making it a must-watch for fans of reality TV. The show follows a group of singletons as they compete to find love and win a cash prize, all while being filmed 24/7. The drama unfolds as the Islanders couple up, swap partners, and face challenges designed to test their relationships. ITV has not revealed the exact air date for the new series, but fans can expect it to premiere in the coming months. With Covid-19 restrictions easing in the UK, it is likely that the show will be able to return to its usual format, with contestants living in close quarters and engaging in activities both inside and outside the villa. Love Island has proven to be a ratings hit for ITV, attracting millions of viewers each season and dominating social media conversations. The show's unique blend of romance, comedy, and drama has turned it into a cultural phenomenon, inspiring spin-offs, merchandise, and even international versions. As fans eagerly await the return of Love Island, they can rest assured that the upcoming season will deliver all the drama and romance they have come to expect. Whether it's heartbreak, betrayal, or true love, the show promises to keep viewers on the edge of their seats as the Islanders navigate the highs and lows of life in the villa. With the announcement that Love Island will be returning this summer, ITV has given fans something to look forward to after a challenging year. The show's mix of romance, competition, and entertainment has made it a firm favorite with viewers, who can't wait to see what surprises the new season has in store.

title: Preston GP struck off over 'dishonest' food poisoning claims
text: A tribunal found the actions of Dr Zuber Bux, who practised in the Preston area in Lancashire, were "misleading, dishonest and unethical." The General Practitioner was found guilty of submitting fraudulent claims for food poisoning on behalf of his patients in order to claim compensation from holiday companies. During the tribunal, it was revealed that Dr Bux had exaggerated or fabricated symptoms in medical reports to support the claims of his patients. He even went as far as coaching his patients on what to say in order to strengthen their case. This dishonest behavior not only deceived the holiday companies but also put a strain on the already overburdened healthcare system. The tribunal heard testimonies from former colleagues who highlighted Dr Bux's unprofessional conduct and lack of integrity. One colleague recalled a specific incident where Dr Bux had pressured them to provide false information for a food poisoning claim, despite there being no clinical evidence to support it. The panel ultimately decided to strike off Dr Zuber Bux from the medical register, citing the seriousness of his dishonest actions and the harm it caused to the reputation of the medical profession. In their ruling, the tribunal stated that Dr Bux's behavior was a clear breach of medical ethics and undermined the trust that patients place in their doctors. Dr Bux's lawyer expressed disappointment in the tribunal's decision, claiming that his client had made a mistake in judgment but was remorseful for his actions. However, the severity of the deception and the impact it had on both the healthcare system and the holiday companies left the panel with no choice but to remove Dr Bux from practicing medicine. The case of Dr Zuber Bux serves as a cautionary tale for medical professionals who may be tempted to engage in dishonest practices for personal gain. The consequences of such actions not only affect the individual involved but also tarnish the reputation of the entire profession. Patients place their trust in doctors to provide them with accurate and honest medical care, and any breach of that trust can have far-reaching consequences. The tribunal's decision to strike off Dr Bux sends a clear message that such behavior will not be tolerated within the medical community. As the news of Dr Bux's striking off spreads, it serves as a reminder of the importance of upholding professional standards and maintaining integrity in all aspects of medical practice. The consequences of dishonesty in healthcare cannot be understated, and the actions of a few can have detrimental effects on the entire profession.

title: Teletubbies creator 'sad' about show's remake
text: Wood, 77, told Radio Times she is not a fan of the trend for remaking old shows such as Dangermouse and Clangers. "I'm a bit sad," she said. "It seems like there is a lack of original ideas in the industry. It's disappointing to see the same concepts being recycled instead of exploring new and innovative content." The iconic creator of Teletubbies expressed her concern over the lack of creativity in the entertainment industry. Wood, who brought the colorful and imaginative world of Tinky Winky, Dipsy, Laa-Laa, and Po to life, believes that the focus on remakes diminishes the value of original storytelling. "Teletubbies was a unique and groundbreaking show that captured the hearts of children around the world. I poured my heart and soul into creating something that was truly special, and it's disheartening to see that creativity taking a backseat to nostalgia," Wood lamented. The Teletubbies creator emphasized the importance of encouraging new voices and fresh ideas in the industry. She expressed her hope that future generations of creators would be inspired to think outside the box and push the boundaries of storytelling. "I believe in the power of imagination and the ability to create something truly original. It's important to nurture creativity and support new ideas, rather than relying on past successes to drive the industry forward," Wood said. Despite her reservations about the trend of remakes, Wood remains proud of the legacy of Teletubbies and the impact it has had on generations of children. The show, which originally aired in 1997, became a global phenomenon and is still beloved by fans today. "Teletubbies holds a special place in my heart, and I am grateful for the opportunity to bring joy and wonder to children all over the world. It's a testament to the power of storytelling and the enduring appeal of timeless characters," Wood reflected. As the conversation around remakes and reboots continues to dominate the entertainment industry, Wood's words serve as a reminder of the importance of creativity and originality in storytelling. While nostalgia can be comforting, it is essential to embrace new ideas and fresh perspectives to keep the industry vibrant and innovative. The legacy of Teletubbies serves as a testament to the enduring power of storytelling and the impact it can have on audiences of all ages.

title: Depression: 'Second biggest cause of disability' in world
text: By Helen Briggs BBC News The disease must be treated as a global public health priority, experts report in the journal PLOS Medicine. The study compared clinical data from around the world and found that depression is the second biggest cause of disability worldwide. Depression affects people of all ages, from all walks of life, and can have a devastating impact on individuals, families, and communities. It is a serious mental health condition that can lead to severe emotional distress, impaired functioning, and even suicide. According to the World Health Organization, more than 264 million people worldwide suffer from depression. This staggering number highlights the urgent need for increased awareness, resources, and support for those affected by this debilitating illness. The study also found that depression is more prevalent in women than men, with rates of depression being higher in low and middle-income countries. This disparity in access to mental health care and treatment is a major concern, as it can lead to poorer outcomes for those struggling with depression. One of the key findings of the study was that depression often goes untreated or undiagnosed, particularly in low-resource settings. This highlights the importance of increasing access to mental health services, including counseling, therapy, and medication, for those in need. Experts stress the need for a comprehensive approach to addressing depression, including early intervention, holistic treatment options, and increased mental health literacy. By raising awareness and breaking down stigma surrounding mental illness, we can improve outcomes for individuals battling depression and prevent further disability. It is crucial that governments, healthcare professionals, and communities work together to prioritize mental health and ensure that those suffering from depression receive the care and support they need. This includes investing in mental health services, training healthcare providers, and promoting mental health education and awareness programs. In conclusion, depression is a significant public health issue that requires urgent attention and action. By recognizing depression as a leading cause of disability and working towards improving access to mental health care, we can help those affected by depression lead healthier, more fulfilling lives. Let us come together to support those struggling with depression and make mental health a global priority.

title: Nick Clegg 'appalled' by former school head master's abuse
text: Nick Clegg, former Deputy Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, expressed deep shock and disgust upon learning about the actions of Roland Peter Wright, an 83-year-old former school headmaster who was found guilty of abusing five boys aged between eight and 13. The Amersham Crown Court jury convicted Wright on 10 charges of historic child abuse, shedding light on a dark chapter in the education system. Clegg, who has been a vocal advocate for child protection and safeguarding, described the case as "appalling" and emphasized the importance of holding perpetrators accountable for their actions. The revelations surrounding Wright's abuse of vulnerable young boys have sent shockwaves throughout the community, prompting calls for greater vigilance and oversight in educational settings. The former Liberal Democrat leader emphasized the need for a thorough investigation into how such abuse was able to occur under the guise of education and authority. He called for a zero-tolerance approach towards child abuse and stressed the critical role that schools play in ensuring the safety and well-being of their students. Wright, who resided in Crown Lane, Farnham Royal, had denied all allegations against him, claiming innocence in the face of overwhelming evidence presented during the trial. The victims, now grown men, bravely came forward to share their harrowing experiences of abuse at the hands of someone they had trusted and looked up to as a figure of authority. The guilty verdict serves as a reminder of the lasting impact that childhood abuse can have on survivors, with many facing lifelong struggles as a result of the trauma inflicted upon them. Clegg called for increased support and resources for survivors of abuse, stressing the need for a compassionate and empathetic response to those who have been victimized. As the news of Wright's conviction reverberates across the country, questions have been raised about how such abuse could go undetected for so long within the educational system. Clegg urged policymakers, educators, and the public to remain vigilant and proactive in safeguarding children from harm, emphasizing the importance of creating a culture of transparency, accountability, and trust. In the wake of this disturbing case, Clegg reiterated his commitment to advocating for the rights and protection of children, calling for a united effort to prevent future incidents of abuse and ensure that perpetrators are brought to justice.
