text: Over 33,000 former soldiers are thought to suffer from illnesses related to their service such as chronic headaches, fatigue and memory problems. The charity British Legion is calling for more research to be done into Gulf War illnesses in order to better understand and treat the veterans affected. Many veterans who served in the Gulf War have reported experiencing a range of debilitating symptoms that have had a profound impact on their quality of life. These symptoms are often referred to as Gulf War illnesses and are believed to be linked to their time spent serving in the conflict. The British Legion is urging the government to allocate more resources towards researching these illnesses and developing effective treatments for those affected. They argue that the veterans who put their lives on the line deserve to have access to the best possible care and support for their health issues. Despite years of research and medical advancements, the exact causes of Gulf War illnesses remain largely unknown. Some theories suggest that exposure to harmful chemicals, such as nerve agents and pesticides, during the conflict may have played a role in the development of these illnesses. Many veterans have expressed frustration at the lack of understanding and support for their conditions, with some feeling like their symptoms are being dismissed or downplayed. The British Legion hopes that by raising awareness of Gulf War illnesses, more attention will be given to finding effective treatments and providing the necessary support for those in need. In addition to calling for more research, the British Legion is also working to improve the overall support services available to veterans with Gulf War illnesses. They provide a range of services, including welfare support, mental health assistance, and advocacy for veterans seeking compensation for their conditions. The charity is committed to ensuring that veterans receive the care and support they need to live healthy and fulfilling lives after their service. By advocating for more research into Gulf War illnesses, they hope to improve the quality of life for those affected and honor the sacrifices made by these brave men and women. As the debate continues, it is clear that more needs to be done to address the challenges faced by veterans with Gulf War illnesses. The British Legion's call for increased research is a step in the right direction towards finding answers and providing better care for those who have served their country.

title: Dale Farm eviction: 'Show of force designed to shock'
text: By Julian Sturdy BBC East  The police, the travellers were told, would only be there to maintain the peace and prevent criminality. But when they struck, the eviction operation was sudden and unexpected. This was a police operation to break the law, force families from their homes, and shock the community into submission. The Dale Farm eviction has been in the works for years. It all began in 2011 when Basildon Council obtained a court order to clear the site, claiming breaches of planning regulations. The site, home to around 80 families, had been the subject of a prolonged legal battle that had captured national attention.  As the day of the eviction approached, tensions rose. Many of the travellers had lived on the site for decades, some even from birth. For them, Dale Farm was not just a place to live but a community, a way of life. They had fought tooth and nail to protect their homes, but ultimately, the law was against them. When the police arrived in the early hours of the morning, it was with a show of force that left many reeling. Riot vans, helicopters, and a massive police presence descended upon the site, catching the travellers off guard. The message was clear - resistance would not be tolerated. As the eviction unfolded, scenes of chaos and despair played out. Families watched helplessly as their homes were bulldozed, their belongings tossed into skips. Children cried, adults shouted in anger and frustration. It was a heart-wrenching sight that left many wondering if there could have been a better way. The aftermath of the eviction has been devastating. Many families have been left homeless, with nowhere to go. Some have been forced to live in cramped temporary accommodation, others have been left to fend for themselves on the streets. The impact on the traveller community has been profound, with trust in the authorities shattered and wounds that may never fully heal. In the eyes of many, the Dale Farm eviction was a show of force designed to shock and intimidate. It was a stark reminder of the power that the state holds and the lengths it will go to enforce its will. But for the travellers of Dale Farm, it was a brutal end to a way of life they had fought so hard to protect. And as the dust settles, the scars left behind will serve as a painful reminder of the day their community was torn apart.

title: Venezuela ex-prosecutor: I have proof of Maduro corruption
text: arrested, made the allegations during a news conference in Brazil. She revealed that she possesses evidence of corruption carried out by President Nicolas Maduro and other high-ranking officials within his administration. Ms Ortega accused Maduro of receiving illicit payments from Odebrecht, a Brazilian construction company that has been at the center of numerous corruption scandals in Latin America. She also pointed fingers at two top leaders of the ruling Socialist Party, Diosdado Cabello and Jorge Rodriguez, alleging that they were involved in money laundering and embezzlement. The former prosecutor did not provide specific details about the evidence she holds, but she claimed that it is substantial and irrefutable. She called on the international community to investigate the allegations and hold those responsible for corruption in Venezuela accountable. In addition to her accusations against Maduro and top party leaders, Ms Ortega also criticized the new prosecutor appointed by the government, Tarek William Saab. She questioned his independence and integrity, suggesting that he was chosen to protect the interests of the ruling regime rather than uphold the law. Since fleeing Venezuela, Ms Ortega has been vocal in denouncing the Maduro government and calling for international pressure to be exerted on the regime. She has met with foreign officials and human rights organizations to present her case and seek support for the Venezuelan opposition. The allegations made by Luisa Ortega are not the first to surface against the Maduro government. The administration has been embroiled in numerous corruption scandals and allegations of human rights abuses in recent years. Critics of the regime argue that corruption is widespread within the ruling elite, leading to economic mismanagement and a severe humanitarian crisis in the country. President Maduro has dismissed the accusations as part of a smear campaign orchestrated by the political opposition and foreign powers seeking to destabilize Venezuela. He has called Ms Ortega a traitor and accused her of colluding with the United States to undermine his government. The international community remains divided on how to address the crisis in Venezuela. Some countries have imposed sanctions on Venezuelan officials and called for free and fair elections to be held, while others have expressed support for the Maduro government and criticized foreign intervention in the country's affairs. As the political and economic turmoil in Venezuela continues to escalate, the allegations of corruption made by Luisa Ortega add another layer of complexity to the already volatile situation. The coming weeks and months will be crucial in determining the future of the country and the well-being of its citizens.

title: Tesla's Elon Musk may be in contempt over tweet
text: His comments came after the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) asked the courts to hold him in contempt for violating a settlement aimed at limiting his social media activity. This latest clash between Elon Musk and the SEC stems from a tweet he sent out in February, which the agency claims was not reviewed as per their agreement. The tweet in question referenced Tesla's production forecast for the year, with Musk stating that the company was on track to manufacture 500,000 vehicles in 2019. This drew the attention of the SEC, as the settlement from last year required Musk to have his tweets about the company reviewed by their lawyers before posting. In response to the SEC's motion for contempt, Musk fired back at the agency, accusing them of attempting to muzzle his free speech rights. He defended his tweet, arguing that it did not contain any material information that would impact Tesla's stock price. Musk believes that the SEC is overstepping their bounds by trying to control his communication on social media platforms. Despite the contentious relationship between Musk and the SEC, it is unclear how this latest dispute will play out. If the courts do find Musk in contempt, he could face additional fines or even more severe penalties. This could also impact Tesla's stock price and investors' confidence in the company's stability. This is not the first time Musk has clashed with the SEC over his social media activity. Last year, he was forced to step down as Tesla's chairman and pay a $20 million fine as part of a settlement with the agency. The agreement was supposed to prevent Musk from making misleading statements about the company on Twitter or other platforms. However, Musk's tendency to make bold claims and controversial statements on social media has continued to create headaches for Tesla and its shareholders. His unfiltered approach to communication has sparked both admiration and criticism, with some praising his transparency and others questioning his judgment. As the legal battle with the SEC looms, the future of Tesla and its mercurial leader remains uncertain. Musk's supporters argue that his vision and innovation outweigh any shortcomings in his behavior, while his detractors warn of the risks associated with his unpredictable actions. For now, all eyes are on the courts as they decide whether Elon Musk will be held in contempt for his latest tweet. The outcome of this case could have far-reaching implications for Tesla, its investors, and the future of corporate governance in the age of social media.

title: Dundee University to tackle hepatitis in Tayside drug users
text: transmitted through the sharing of needles among drug users. The initiative at Dundee University aims to provide education and support to this vulnerable population in order to prevent the spread of the virus. Dr. Rebecca Anderson, a leading researcher in the field of hepatitis C, stressed the importance of early intervention in tackling this public health issue. "By reaching out to drug users before they become infected, we can make a significant impact on reducing the overall prevalence of hepatitis C in Tayside," she said. The program will involve a combination of outreach efforts, educational campaigns, and access to testing and treatment services. By working closely with NHS Tayside, the university hopes to streamline the process for drug users to receive the care they need, from getting tested for hepatitis C to accessing antiviral medications. One of the main challenges in addressing hepatitis C among drug users is the stigma associated with drug addiction. Many individuals may be hesitant to come forward for testing or treatment due to fear of judgment or discrimination. To combat this barrier, the team at Dundee University is focusing on creating a safe and welcoming environment for drug users to seek help. In addition to providing medical care, the program will also offer mental health support and referrals to addiction treatment services. The goal is to address the holistic needs of drug users in order to improve their overall well-being and reduce their risk of hepatitis C transmission. The community response to the initiative has been overwhelmingly positive, with local organizations and healthcare providers expressing their support for the university's efforts. By working together, stakeholders are hopeful that they can make a meaningful impact on the health of drug users in Tayside. As the program gets underway, researchers will closely monitor its effectiveness through data collection and analysis. By tracking the number of hepatitis C infections among drug users over time, they hope to demonstrate the positive impact of early intervention and prevention efforts. Overall, the partnership between Dundee University and NHS Tayside represents a critical step forward in addressing the public health crisis of hepatitis C in Tayside. By focusing on education, outreach, and access to care, the initiative aims to create a healthier and more resilient community for all residents.

title: Cambridgeshire guided busway opens to passengers
text: miles of dedicated busway track, aims to reduce travel times and alleviate traffic congestion in the busy area. Passengers can expect a comfortable and efficient journey, with the buses running every few minutes during peak times. The guided busway is a significant investment in the region's transportation infrastructure, providing a much-needed alternative to driving and offering a more sustainable travel option for residents. With growing concerns about air quality and carbon emissions, initiatives like the Cambridgeshire guided busway play a crucial role in promoting greener modes of transportation. The project has been years in the making, with construction delays and budget overruns causing frustration among local residents. However, the opening of the busway marks a milestone in the county's efforts to improve public transport and provide better connectivity between its communities. Local officials hope that the guided busway will encourage more people to leave their cars at home and embrace public transportation. By offering a reliable and efficient bus service, they aim to reduce the number of single-occupancy vehicles on the roads and ease congestion during peak travel times. With dedicated bus lanes and priority at intersections, the guided busway promises a faster and more reliable journey for passengers. Commuters can expect reduced travel times and a more pleasant experience compared to traditional bus routes, which are often subject to delays and traffic congestion. In addition to improving the daily commute for residents, the guided busway also offers connections to key destinations in the region. With stops at major employment centers, retail areas, and residential neighborhoods, the busway provides a convenient way for people to access the places they need to go. As the Cambridgeshire guided busway opens to passengers, local authorities are hopeful that it will be a success in promoting sustainable travel and reducing reliance on private vehicles. By investing in public transportation infrastructure, they aim to create a more connected and environmentally friendly region for residents and visitors alike. Overall, the new guided busway represents a step forward in the county's efforts to improve transportation options and reduce congestion on its roads. With its dedicated lanes and frequent service, the busway offers a convenient and efficient way for people to get around the area, while also promoting sustainability and reducing the impact of single-occupancy vehicles on the environment.

title: The heartbreak of watching the slow death of ash trees
text: Chris Jackson Presenter, Inside Out, North East & Cumbria At primary school I remember learning how to identify trees by their leaves or bark. The one I was most interested in spotting was the one that would deliver conkers; the mighty horse chestnut tree. But over the years, my attention shifted to another type of tree - the ash tree. As a child, I was captivated by the ash tree's distinctive leaflets and the way they danced in the wind. I would spend hours playing under the shade of its branches, feeling its cool embrace on hot summer days. The tree seemed like a steadfast presence in my life, a silent guardian watching over me as I grew up. But in recent years, that sense of security has been shattered. The ash tree, once a symbol of strength and resilience, is now facing a devastating decline. The deadly emerald ash borer beetle has been spreading through North East and Cumbria, leaving a trail of destruction in its wake. The beetle lays its eggs on the bark of ash trees, and when the larvae hatch, they burrow into the tree and feed on its inner bark, disrupting the flow of nutrients and eventually killing the tree. I have watched in horror as once-healthy ash trees in parks, woodlands, and along roadsides have withered and died, their branches turning brittle and their leaves wilting and falling prematurely. It is a heartbreaking sight to see these majestic trees succumb to an invasive pest, their once-vibrant green foliage now a ghostly grey. The loss of ash trees is not just an aesthetic tragedy; it has far-reaching ecological implications. Ash trees are a vital component of our ecosystems, providing food and shelter for a wide variety of wildlife, from birds and insects to mammals and fungi. Their decline threatens the delicate balance of our natural world, putting entire ecosystems at risk of collapse. But despite the grim outlook, there is still hope. Scientists and conservationists are working tirelessly to find ways to combat the emerald ash borer and save the remaining ash trees from extinction. Some have developed innovative treatments and biocontrol methods to protect trees from the beetles, while others are conducting research to breed resistant ash trees that can withstand the onslaught. As I gaze upon the dying ash trees in my local area, I feel a sense of loss and helplessness. But I also feel a renewed sense of determination to do whatever I can to help save these precious trees from disappearing forever. The heartbreak of watching the slow death of ash trees is a stark reminder of the fragility of our natural world, and the urgent need to protect and preserve it for future generations.

title: Criminal injury compensation cuts to be reconsidered
text: The Ministry of Justice (MoJ) had wanted to restrict payments from the Criminal Injuries Compensation Scheme to those suffering serious injuries. This move was met with backlash from victims' rights groups and politicians who argued that it would unfairly penalize those who have experienced any form of trauma as a result of criminal activity. The MoJ's proposal was seen as a cost-cutting measure, aimed at reducing the amount of money paid out in compensation each year. The Criminal Injuries Compensation Scheme was established to provide financial support to victims of crime, helping them to cope with the physical, emotional, and financial impact of their experiences. In recent years, there have been concerns about the sustainability of the scheme, as the number of claims has increased while funding has remained stagnant. The MoJ's proposal to restrict payments was seen as a way to address this issue and ensure that the scheme could continue to support those in need. However, critics argued that the proposal went too far, potentially leaving many victims without the financial support they desperately need. They pointed out that even those with less serious injuries can suffer lasting trauma and may struggle to recover without adequate compensation. The proposal was seen as an attempt to prioritize more severe cases, but at the expense of those who may still be suffering in other ways. Following the backlash, the MoJ has announced that they will reconsider their proposed cuts to the Criminal Injuries Compensation Scheme. Justice Minister, Lucy Frazer, stated that they will take into account the concerns raised by victims' rights groups and politicians, and seek a more balanced approach. She emphasized the importance of supporting all victims of crime, regardless of the severity of their injuries, and ensuring that they have access to the help they need. Frazer's announcement has been welcomed by many, who see it as a step in the right direction towards ensuring that victims of crime are properly supported. The Criminal Injuries Compensation Scheme plays a crucial role in helping victims rebuild their lives and move forward after experiencing trauma. By reconsidering the proposed cuts, the MoJ has shown a willingness to listen to the concerns of those affected and take a more compassionate approach to supporting victims. Moving forward, it will be important for the MoJ to carefully consider how best to reform the Criminal Injuries Compensation Scheme to ensure that it remains effective and sustainable. By working with victims' rights groups and other stakeholders, they can develop a more balanced approach that provides fair compensation to all those who have suffered as a result of criminal activity. Victims deserve to be heard, supported, and compensated for the harm they have experienced, and the MoJ's reconsideration of their cuts is a positive step towards achieving that goal.

title: Harry Uzoka death: Three guilty of killing London model
text: George Koh, 24, stabbed fellow model Harry Uzoka in the heart after he went to settle the dispute, accompanied by two friends on 11 January. The tense confrontation between the two models was fueled by jealousy and competition in the competitive fashion industry. Uzoka, a rising star in the modeling world, had been making a name for himself with his striking looks and charisma, while Koh was desperate to emulate his success. The tragic incident took place in West London, not far from Uzoka's home. The court heard how Koh had enlisted his friends - Jonathan Okigbo and Merse Dikanda - to accompany him to the meeting with Uzoka, allegedly for support. However, things quickly escalated into a violent confrontation, ending in Uzoka collapsing on the street with a fatal stab wound. During the trial, the jury was shown evidence of messages exchanged between Koh and Uzoka leading up to the fatal encounter. The messages revealed a simmering rivalry between the two models, with Koh accusing Uzoka of spreading rumors about him and trying to sabotage his career. The tension between them had been mounting for some time, and the meeting to settle their differences quickly turned deadly. Koh, Okigbo, and Dikanda were found guilty of murder by the jury, who heard how they had planned the attack on Uzoka in a chilling display of premeditation. The judge described their actions as "cowardly" and "brutal", highlighting the senseless loss of life that occurred as a result of their actions. The families and friends of both Uzoka and Koh were left devastated by the tragic outcome of the dispute between the two young men. Uzoka's family described him as a "loving son and brother" who had a bright future ahead of him, while Koh's family struggled to come to terms with the fact that their son was capable of such a violent act. As news of the guilty verdict spread, there was an outpouring of grief and shock from the fashion industry and the wider community. Many expressed disbelief that such a senseless act of violence could occur in a world where appearance and image are so highly prized. In the aftermath of the trial, there were renewed calls for greater support for young people in the fashion industry, where competition and pressure can often lead to destructive behavior. The tragedy of Harry Uzoka's death serves as a stark reminder of the need for compassion, understanding, and accountability in an industry that can sometimes prioritize fame and success over human life.

title: Foster carers' concern for children's welfare with cuts
text: The Nationwide Association of Fostering Providers said the Welsh government consortium which buys their services is looking to renegotiate their contracts. Philip Sutton from the NAFP said, "This move threatens the stability and quality of care for vulnerable children in foster care. Foster carers are deeply concerned about the impact these cuts will have on the children they care for." Foster carers play a crucial role in providing a stable and loving environment for children who have experienced trauma and upheaval in their lives. They work tirelessly to ensure the well-being and safety of these children, often going above and beyond to meet their emotional, physical, and educational needs. However, with funding cuts looming, foster carers are worried about their ability to continue providing the high-quality care that these children deserve. Many foster carers feel under-appreciated and undervalued for the important work that they do. They already face significant challenges, from navigating the complex system of child welfare services to dealing with the emotional toll of caring for children who have been through traumatic experiences. The prospect of further cuts to their funding is a cause for serious concern among foster carers across Wales. In addition to the potential impact on children's well-being, the proposed cuts also raise questions about the long-term sustainability of the foster care system in Wales. Foster carers are already in short supply, and any further financial strain could push more carers to the brink of burnout or force them to leave the profession altogether. This would not only be detrimental to the children currently in foster care but could also exacerbate the existing crisis of children in need of placement. The NAFP is calling on the Welsh government to reconsider its approach and prioritize the welfare of children in foster care. They argue that cutting funding for foster carers is a shortsighted move that will ultimately cost more in the long run, both financially and in terms of the well-being of children. Foster carers provide a vital service to the most vulnerable children in society, and they deserve to be supported and respected for their invaluable contribution. As discussions continue between the NAFP and the Welsh government consortium, foster carers are left anxiously waiting to see what the future holds for themselves and the children in their care. The outcome of these negotiations will have far-reaching implications for the well-being of vulnerable children in foster care across Wales. It is crucial that the voices of foster carers are heard and their concerns are taken seriously in order to ensure the continued provision of high-quality care for children in need.

title: Meryl Streep: Golden Globes organisers endorse speech
text: The Hollywood Foreign Press Association (HFPA) described the actress as a "class act" after her speech at the ceremony on Sunday night. Streep criticised President-elect Donald Trump and said: "We need the principled press to hold power to account, to call them on the carpet for every outrage." Her impassioned speech at the Golden Globes has garnered widespread praise for its bold and unapologetic stance. Meryl Streep, a three-time Oscar winner and one of the most respected actresses in Hollywood, used her platform at the Golden Globes to address the current political climate in the United States. In a room filled with the biggest names in the entertainment industry, she took a stand against the incoming administration and appealed for unity and empathy. The HFPA, the organization behind the Golden Globes, has publicly endorsed Streep's speech, stating that they support her right to speak out on important issues. In a statement released following the ceremony, the HFPA praised Streep for using her voice to advocate for press freedom and accountability in government. Streep's speech has reignited a conversation about the role of artists and celebrities in the political arena. While some have criticized her for using a glamorous awards show as a platform for her views, others have applauded her courage and conviction. As a highly influential figure in the entertainment industry, Streep's words carry weight and have the potential to inspire others to speak out against injustice and oppression. Donald Trump, a prolific user of social media, responded to Streep's speech in a series of tweets, calling her "overrated" and "a Hillary flunky who lost big." The President-elect's comments have further fueled the debate surrounding Streep's speech, with many defending her right to express her opinions and criticize those in power. Despite the backlash from some quarters, Streep's speech has been widely praised for its eloquence and sincerity. Her call for unity and tolerance in the face of adversity struck a chord with many viewers, who see her as a beacon of hope and inspiration in a turbulent political climate. As the dust settles on the 74th annual Golden Globes, Meryl Streep's speech continues to reverberate throughout the entertainment industry and beyond. Her words serve as a reminder of the power of art and activism to effect change and shed light on important issues. In a time of uncertainty and division, Streep's courage and conviction serve as a beacon of hope and inspiration for us all.

title: Disputed £92m Lincoln Eastern Bypass scheme gets green light
text: Lincoln's controversial Eastern Bypass will link the A158 Wragby Road with the A15 Sleaford Road. Hundreds of people objected to the scheme which would close a route into the city from three villages. But the plans have received the green light despite the opposition. The £92m project has been a point of contention since it was first proposed, with concerns raised about the impact on the environment and local communities. However, supporters argue that the bypass is necessary to ease traffic congestion and improve access to the city. Councillor Richard Davies, executive member for highways at Lincolnshire County Council, defended the decision to move forward with the scheme. He said: "The Eastern Bypass will provide a vital link between the A158 and the A15, reducing congestion and improving journey times. It will also help to support economic growth in the area and enhance road safety." Construction is expected to begin later this year, with completion set for 2023. The bypass will include new roundabouts, bridges, and junctions to improve connectivity in the region. It is hoped that the project will not only benefit motorists but also create new opportunities for businesses and residents in Lincoln and the surrounding area. Despite the approval from local authorities, some residents remain unconvinced about the benefits of the bypass. Concerns have been raised about the impact on wildlife habitats, air quality, and noise levels in the area. Campaigners have vowed to continue fighting against the scheme, calling for more sustainable transport solutions to be explored. The controversy surrounding the Lincoln Eastern Bypass highlights the challenges of balancing the need for infrastructure development with concerns for the environment and local communities. As cities grow and populations expand, finding solutions to transport problems becomes increasingly complex. Ultimately, the success of the bypass will depend on how well it is integrated into the existing road network and how effectively it addresses the issues it was designed to solve. Only time will tell whether the £92m scheme proves to be a worthwhile investment in the future of Lincoln and its residents.

title: Channel migrants: More than 60 people found on Boxing Day
text: who had entered the UK illegally. The group of migrants, which included men, women, and children, were intercepted by Border Force officials on Saturday morning as they attempted to cross the English Channel. Despite the treacherous conditions of the sea, all individuals were brought safely to the shore. This incident is part of a larger trend of increasing numbers of migrants attempting the dangerous journey across the Channel in small boats. The Home Office has reported a significant rise in crossings this year, with over 8,000 people making the journey so far, compared to around 1,800 in the entire year of 2019. The reasons behind this surge in Channel crossings are complex and multifaceted. Many migrants are fleeing conflict, persecution, and poverty in their home countries, seeking a better life in Europe. The closure of legal routes for asylum-seekers, coupled with the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on global migration patterns, has exacerbated the situation. Despite the challenges of the journey, migrants are often willing to take the risk due to lack of alternative options. The dangerous nature of these crossings has led to tragic incidents in the past, with lives lost at sea. The UK government has come under criticism for its handling of the situation, with calls for more humane and effective responses to the crisis. In response to the latest incident, Immigration Minister Chris Philp stated that the government is working closely with French authorities to address the issue of Channel crossings. He emphasized the need for a comprehensive approach that includes tackling the root causes of migration, improving border security, and strengthening cooperation with other countries. The issue of Channel migrants remains a contentious and pressing challenge for the UK government. As more and more people risk their lives to make the dangerous journey across the sea, there is a growing urgency to find sustainable solutions that prioritize the safety and wellbeing of migrants while upholding the integrity of border controls. The Home Office has pledged to continue its efforts to prevent illegal crossings and to return those who enter the country unlawfully. However, the underlying drivers of migration must also be addressed in order to effectively manage this complex issue in the long term. Only through a coordinated and compassionate approach can the UK hope to find lasting solutions to the Channel migrants crisis.

title: Spy apprenticeship: Government launches new scheme
text: Foreign Secretary William Hague announced the scheme during a visit to Bletchley Park where codebreakers helped to shorten World War II. The new initiative aims to recruit and train a new generation of spies to tackle modern threats to national security. The spy apprenticeship program is a collaboration between the government and various intelligence agencies, with the goal of developing the next generation of intelligence officers. The program is designed to attract young, talented individuals who are passionate about serving their country and have a keen interest in intelligence work. Apprentices will undergo rigorous training in a wide range of skills, including intelligence gathering, analysis, cryptography, and counter-terrorism. They will also have the opportunity to work alongside experienced intelligence officers on real-life operations, gaining practical experience and an invaluable insight into the world of espionage. The scheme has been met with both excitement and skepticism. Some see it as a much-needed effort to revitalize the intelligence community and ensure that it remains at the forefront of national security. Others, however, have raised concerns about the potential risks of training inexperienced individuals in such sensitive and high-stakes work. In response to these concerns, Foreign Secretary William Hague emphasized the rigorous selection process that all apprentices will undergo. "We will only recruit the best and brightest individuals who have demonstrated a strong commitment to serving their country," he said. "Our intelligence agencies have a long history of excellence, and we are confident that this new generation of spies will uphold that tradition." The apprenticeship program is part of a broader effort by the government to modernize and strengthen the country's intelligence capabilities in the face of evolving threats. From cyber attacks to terrorism, the challenges facing the intelligence community are constantly changing, and the government is determined to ensure that its spies are equipped to meet these challenges head-on. As part of the program, apprentices will have the opportunity to work on a variety of projects, both domestically and internationally. They will also have access to cutting-edge technology and training facilities, ensuring that they are well-prepared for the demands of modern espionage. The government hopes that the new spy apprenticeship program will not only help to enhance national security but also inspire a new generation of individuals to pursue a career in intelligence. By fostering talent and passion in the field of espionage, the government aims to ensure that the UK remains a global leader in intelligence and security for years to come.

title: UK 'needs more bureaucrats for Brexit', says ex-diplomat
text: Sir Simon Fraser was a trade negotiator in Europe and permanent under-secretary at the Foreign Office until July 2015. "I believe the UK needs more bureaucrats to handle the complexities of Brexit," Fraser stated in a recent interview with the BBC. Fraser, who served in various high-ranking diplomatic roles, emphasized the importance of having experienced and knowledgeable civil servants to navigate the intricate process of leaving the European Union. With Brexit negotiations ongoing and the deadline looming, the demand for skilled bureaucrats has never been higher. As the UK prepares to forge new trade agreements and redefine its relationship with the EU, Fraser stressed that having a strong and capable civil service is vital for the country's future prosperity. "Brexit is a massive undertaking that requires meticulous planning and execution. Without the right people in place, we risk jeopardizing our economy and international standing," he warned. Fraser's sentiments were echoed by other former diplomats and experts in the field, who have also called for increased recruitment and training of civil servants to handle the challenges of Brexit. With so much at stake, the need for a competent and efficient bureaucracy has never been more apparent. The UK government has already taken steps to address this issue, with plans to expand the civil service and provide additional resources for Brexit-related work. However, critics argue that more needs to be done to attract top talent and ensure that the civil service is equipped to tackle the complexities of leaving the EU. Fraser's experience and insights have shed light on the importance of having a skilled and dedicated civil service to guide the country through this uncertain period. As the UK embarks on this historic journey, the role of bureaucrats will be more crucial than ever in shaping the nation's future. In conclusion, Sir Simon Fraser's call for more bureaucrats to handle Brexit highlights the pressing need for a competent and capable civil service. As the UK navigates the challenges of leaving the EU, having experienced and knowledgeable civil servants is essential for ensuring a smooth and successful transition. With the clock ticking and negotiations ongoing, the government must prioritize the recruitment and training of top talent to safeguard the country's interests and secure its place on the global stage.

title: Japan PM Abe condemns hostage 'death' video
text: Shinzo Abe demanded the release of a second hostage, purported to be Kenji Goto, shown in the video. Japan says it is trying to confirm the authenticity of the video, which appears to show the beheading of Goto's cellmate and fellow Japanese citizen, Haruna Yukawa. The gruesome video was released by the Islamic State (IS) group on Saturday, and has shocked the Japanese government and people. In response, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe condemned the act as "cruel and inhumane" and vowed to do everything in his power to bring the perpetrators to justice. Abe, who cut short his visit to the Middle East to deal with the crisis, expressed his firm determination to secure the safe return of Kenji Goto. "We will not yield to terrorism. We will always protect our people no matter what it takes," he declared in a televised address. The video, titled "A message to the Japanese government," features a masked IS militant holding a knife and standing next to a kneeling man in an orange jumpsuit. The militant delivers a message in both English and Japanese, accusing the Japanese government of supporting the US-led coalition against IS and demanding a ransom of $200 million for the release of the hostages. Haruna Yukawa, a self-styled security consultant, was captured by IS in August last year after entering Syria. Kenji Goto, a respected freelance journalist, reportedly went to Syria in October to try to secure his friend's release. Both men's lives now hang in the balance. The Japanese government has been in close contact with Jordan, which has been negotiating with IS for the release of another hostage, Jordanian pilot Muath al-Kasaesbeh. However, their efforts have so far not yielded any results. Despite the tragic turn of events, the Japanese people have rallied around the hostages and their families, expressing solidarity and hope for their safe return. A candlelight vigil was held in Tokyo on Sunday, with thousands of people gathering to pray for the hostages and condemn the brutality of IS. As the world waits with bated breath for further developments, the Japanese government is under intense pressure to secure the release of Kenji Goto and bring an end to this harrowing ordeal. The fate of the two hostages remains uncertain, but one thing is clear: Japan will not give in to the demands of terrorists, and will continue to fight for the safe return of its citizens.

title: Chinese firm set to buy House of Fraser
text: Sanpower Group was founded in 1993 by entrepreneur Yuan Yafei and has grown into a conglomerate with interests in industries ranging from healthcare to real estate. With a strong presence in China, Sanpower is now looking to expand its footprint in the global market by acquiring well-established Western brands. The acquisition of House of Fraser, a well-known British department store, marks a significant milestone for Sanpower. The deal not only gives the Chinese firm access to the lucrative UK retail market but also provides a platform for future expansion into other European markets. House of Fraser, which was founded in 1849, has faced financial challenges in recent years due to changing consumer shopping habits and increased competition from online retailers. The acquisition by Sanpower is seen as a lifeline for the struggling company, providing much-needed capital and resources to revitalize the brand and attract new customers. The move also reflects the growing trend of Chinese companies seeking to invest in Western brands as a way to diversify their portfolios and gain access to new markets. Over the past few years, Chinese firms have made significant investments in industries such as technology, entertainment, and real estate, signaling their ambition to become major players on the global stage. While the acquisition of House of Fraser by Sanpower has been met with some skepticism and concern by British consumers and industry experts, others see it as a positive development that could bring new opportunities and revitalization to the iconic retailer. With its deep pockets and ambitious growth plans, Sanpower is well-positioned to leverage its acquisition of House of Fraser to drive innovation, improve customer experience, and expand its market share both in the UK and beyond. As the deal moves forward, all eyes will be on Sanpower to see how it plans to leverage its investment in House of Fraser to achieve success in the highly competitive retail industry. The Chinese firm's track record of successful acquisitions and business expansion gives hope that it will be able to breathe new life into the historic British brand and secure its place in the ever-evolving global retail landscape.

title: Easyjet wants more women in the cockpit
text: By Rebecca Marston Business reporter, BBC News The Amy Johnson initiative named after the first female pilot to fly solo from the UK to Australia, prompted a surge in applications. Easyjet says it wants to increase the number further and has launched a new campaign to encourage more women to enter the cockpit. The airline announced that it aims to double the number of female pilots by 2020, from 6% to 12%. In order to achieve this goal, Easyjet is working on removing barriers that may be preventing women from pursuing a career as a pilot. One of the ways Easyjet is attempting to attract more women to the profession is through targeted outreach efforts. This includes partnering with schools and colleges to promote the pilot career path to young women who may not have considered it as an option before. By raising awareness and providing support early on, Easyjet hopes to inspire more young women to pursue a career in aviation. Furthermore, Easyjet is also working on increasing the representation of women in leadership positions within the company. By promoting diversity and inclusion, the airline hopes to create a more welcoming and supportive environment for female pilots. In addition to these efforts, Easyjet is also implementing changes to its recruitment process to make it more inclusive. This includes offering mentorship and training programs specifically tailored to women, as well as providing support for those who may face gender-related challenges in the workplace. Overall, Easyjet's commitment to increasing the number of female pilots is part of a wider industry push to address the gender imbalance within aviation. While progress has been made in recent years, women still make up a small percentage of the pilot workforce worldwide. The airline's initiative is not only about achieving greater gender diversity, but also about tapping into a talented pool of individuals who may bring different perspectives and skills to the cockpit. By encouraging more women to pursue a career as a pilot, Easyjet is not only breaking down barriers, but also improving the overall quality of its workforce. As the aviation industry continues to evolve, it is crucial that companies like Easyjet take proactive steps to ensure that all individuals, regardless of gender, have equal opportunities to succeed. With its new campaign and ambitious goals, Easyjet is setting a positive example for the rest of the industry and showing that the sky is truly the limit for female pilots.

title: Welsh Tory leader calls for parties to offer 'chance of change'
text: Thomas said Mr Davies had been in charge when the party lost seats in 2016 and the 2017 general election, and questioned his ability to lead a revival. However, Mr Davies said he had given the Conservatives a "beating heart again" and made them a party of government ahead of the 2021 poll. He said the party had a "real hunger" to make a breakthough in an election where it will need to make significant gains to have a chance of returning to government. "You have to look at the public perception of the Welsh Conservative party pre-Andrew Davies. There was parts of our party that were dead in the water," he said. "We had put our heart into this, we had put our being into it. We had put our everything into making the Welsh Conservatives a party of government. "The challenge for us is to stop talking among ourselves, stop making the same arguments among ourselves and start talking to the voters and listening to the voters and argue for that change in a coherent way and give people that hope that there is a real chance of change." He said his party would present a "clear and coherent offer" to the Welsh people. That would be in stark contrast to Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats, who he claimed were serving different interests. Mr Thomas, who is also the membership secretary, said Plaid was now "seemingly misleading" the electorate about their prospects at the 2021 election. "Why do you deceive the public that the Liberal Democrats or Plaid Cymru can form a government in Wales without governing when the reality is you can't?" he said. "People aren't daft. They can see through that and they want to know that the party has the honesty to tell them that. "My message to them is: tell us what you're going to do, tell us how you're going to do it, tell us what you're going to do differently and deliver for the people of Wales." The Welsh Conservative leader, Andrew Davies, has called for all parties to offer voters a "chance of change" at the upcoming assembly elections. He said it was crucial for politicians to connect with the public and present a coherent plan for the future if they wanted to win their support. Mr Davies acknowledged that under his leadership, the Tories had suffered setbacks in previous elections. However, he insisted that the party had made significant progress and was now in a strong position to challenge for power in Wales.

title: Ashya King 'not receiving chemotherapy'
text: that Ashya King still needs to receive chemotherapy as part of his treatment plan, despite his father's belief that the tumour is in remission. Professor Sarah Johnson, from the Royal Marsden Hospital in London, emphasized the importance of following medical advice when it comes to treating childhood cancer. Chemotherapy is a vital component of Ashya's treatment, as it helps to target and kill any remaining cancer cells that may still be present in his body. Without this crucial step, there is a risk of the cancer returning and spreading, potentially putting Ashya's life at further risk. Professor Johnson explained that while the tumour may appear to be in remission, there is still a need for additional treatment to ensure that all cancer cells are eradicated. She stressed the importance of completing the full course of chemotherapy as prescribed by medical professionals to give Ashya the best chance of recovery and long-term remission. Ashya's case has sparked a debate about the rights of parents to make decisions about their child's medical treatment. While it is understandable that parents want the best for their children, it is essential to trust in the expertise of medical professionals when it comes to complex and life-threatening conditions like cancer. In situations where there is a disagreement between parents and medical professionals, it is crucial to seek a resolution that prioritizes the well-being of the child. This may involve seeking a second opinion, engaging in open and honest discussions with healthcare providers, and ultimately making decisions based on what is in the best interests of the child. Ashya's father's decision to withhold chemotherapy may have been made out of a desire to protect his son from the side effects of treatment. Chemotherapy can be a challenging and taxing process, both physically and emotionally, but it is a necessary part of the journey towards recovery for many cancer patients. It is essential for Ashya's father to work collaboratively with medical professionals to ensure that he receives the care and treatment he needs to overcome his illness. By following the advice and guidance of experts in the field of childhood cancer, Ashya can give himself the best possible chance of beating the disease and leading a healthy and happy life. As the debate continues around Ashya's case, it is crucial to remember that the primary focus should always be on the well-being and health of the child. With ongoing medical support and treatment, Ashya can look towards a brighter future free from cancer and its devastating effects.

title: Winterton school stabbing: Girl held in attempted murder probe
text: The incident has shocked the small community of Winterton, located in North Lincolnshire. Residents have expressed their disbelief and concern over the violent attack that took place in broad daylight at the local school. According to witnesses, the 61-year-old woman, who is believed to be a member of staff at the academy, was stabbed multiple times in an office on the school premises. The motive behind the attack remains unclear, and investigators are working diligently to piece together the events leading up to the violent assault. Humberside Police have confirmed that a 16-year-old girl has been arrested on suspicion of attempted murder in connection with the incident. The teenager is currently in police custody, where she is being questioned by detectives to determine the circumstances surrounding the attack. In a statement released to the press, Detective Superintendent Charlotte Hilditch of Humberside Police emphasized the seriousness of the situation, stating, "This is clearly a very serious incident which has caused significant concern within the local community. We understand that incidents of this nature are incredibly distressing and concerning for the public, and we want to assure the community that we are doing everything we can to establish the facts and bring those responsible to justice." The school has been closed following the incident, with students and staff being sent home for their safety. The local community has been left reeling from the news of the stabbing, with many expressing their shock and disbelief over the violent attack that occurred within their midst. As the investigation into the incident continues, authorities are urging anyone with information to come forward and assist with the ongoing inquiry. The safety and well-being of the community remain a top priority for the police, who are working tirelessly to ensure that justice is served in this case. The Winterton school stabbing has sent shockwaves through the community, prompting calls for increased security measures and support for the victims involved. As the investigation unfolds, residents are left grappling with the aftermath of the violent attack, seeking answers and reassurance in the wake of this tragic event.

title: Google v Oracle: Supreme Court declares Google's code copying fair
text: Oracle, another tech titan, had sued Google in 2010 for copyright infringement over what it said was copied computer code. Android is now used on over 2.5 billion devices worldwide, making it one of the most popular operating systems in the world. The lawsuit centered around 11,500 lines of code that Google used in its Android operating system, which Oracle claimed was a violation of their copyrights. After more than a decade of legal battles, the Supreme Court has finally ruled in favor of Google, stating that the use of the code was protected under the doctrine of fair use. Fair use is a legal principle that allows for the use of copyrighted material without permission from the owner under certain circumstances, such as for purposes of criticism, comment, news reporting, teaching, scholarship, or research. The Supreme Court's decision is a major victory for Google and a blow to Oracle, which had been seeking billions of dollars in damages. Google argued that its use of the code was transformative and essential for the development of new technologies. The court agreed, stating that allowing Oracle to enforce copyright on the code would stifle innovation and competition in the tech industry. The ruling has far-reaching implications for the software industry, as it sets a precedent for how copyright law applies to software code. It gives developers more freedom to use existing code to create new products and services without fear of being sued for copyright infringement. This is particularly important in an industry where innovation is often built upon the work of others. The decision also highlights the ongoing debate over the balance between copyright protection and innovation in the digital age. While copyright law is important for protecting the rights of creators, it must also allow for the free flow of ideas and knowledge to foster innovation and competition. In a statement following the ruling, Google expressed its satisfaction with the decision, stating that it was a win for the entire software industry. Oracle, on the other hand, expressed disappointment and stated that it will continue to defend its intellectual property rights. As technology continues to evolve at a rapid pace, the intersection of copyright law and software development will remain a contentious issue. The Supreme Court's ruling in the Google v Oracle case is just one chapter in the ongoing debate over how best to balance the rights of creators with the need for innovation in the digital age.

title: Police warn of 'inadequate safety' at Greta Thunberg protest
text: Avon and Somerset Police say they expect thousands of people at the Bristol Youth Strike 4 Climate on College Green on Friday to hear the 17-year-old climate activist speak. The force said there was "potential for trips, slips, falls and other hazards" due to the large turnout and inadequate safety measures in place. Chief Superintendent Will White urged attendees to be mindful of their surroundings and to follow instructions from event stewards. He emphasized the importance of staying safe while exercising their right to protest and voice their concerns about climate change. "We want everyone to have a safe and enjoyable experience at the protest, but we also need to ensure that proper safety measures are in place to prevent accidents and injuries," Chief Superintendent White said. The police have been working closely with event organizers to address safety concerns and minimize the risk of incidents occurring during the demonstration. However, with such a large gathering expected, it is essential for attendees to take personal responsibility for their own safety. In addition to physical hazards, the police also warned of potential disruptions and delays to public transportation in the area due to the protest. Local residents and businesses have been advised to plan ahead and consider alternate routes to avoid traffic congestion. Greta Thunberg, who gained international acclaim for her activism on climate change, is scheduled to address the crowd at the Bristol protest. Her presence has drawn significant attention to the event, with activists and supporters from across the country expected to attend. Despite concerns about safety and logistics, organizers are hopeful that the protest will raise awareness about the urgent need for action on climate change. They are calling for government officials to listen to the voices of young people and take meaningful steps to address the environmental crisis facing the planet. As the day of the protest approaches, Avon and Somerset Police continue to work with all relevant stakeholders to ensure that the event runs smoothly and safely. They are reminding attendees to stay vigilant, follow instructions, and look out for one another to make sure that everyone has a positive and impactful experience at the Bristol Youth Strike 4 Climate.

title: Sri Lankan rights campaigner Jayalath Jayawardena dies
text: By Charles HavilandBBC News, Colombo He had a recent history of heart disease. Dr Jayawardena was a stalwart of the main opposition United National Party and widely admired for his rights work. He featured in Guinness World Records for his relentless campaigning on human rights issues in Sri Lanka, particularly focusing on the rights of minority communities. Dr Jayawardena was a fearless advocate for those whose voices often went unheard, including the Tamil and Muslim minorities in Sri Lanka. He was known for his tireless efforts in fighting for justice, equality, and accountability for all citizens, regardless of their ethnicity or religion. His passing has left a huge void in the human rights community in Sri Lanka. Many have taken to social media to express their condolences and pay tribute to his legacy. Sri Lankan President has also issued a statement praising Dr Jayawardena's dedication to the cause of human rights and his unwavering commitment to social justice. Dr Jayawardena's work extended beyond Sri Lanka, as he was also actively involved in international human rights campaigns. He was a regular speaker at conferences and events around the world, where he shared his experiences and insights on the challenges facing human rights defenders in Sri Lanka and beyond. Despite facing numerous threats and challenges, Dr Jayawardena never wavered in his mission to fight for a better, more just society. He was a beacon of hope for many in Sri Lanka and inspired countless others to take up the mantle of human rights activism. His legacy will live on through the countless lives he touched and the causes he championed. As we mourn his loss, we must also recommit ourselves to carrying on his work and ensuring that his vision of a more just and equal society becomes a reality for all Sri Lankans. In his memory, let us continue the fight for human rights and social justice, standing up for those who are marginalized and oppressed. Dr Jayawardena may be gone, but his spirit and his legacy will continue to inspire us to work towards a better future for all.

title: Alexander Vindman, witness 'bullied by Trump', quits US military
text: Lt Col Alexander Vindman was the victim of a "campaign of bullying, intimidation and retaliation" by the president, his lawyer said. Lt Col Vindman's "concern" over a phone call between Mr Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky in July led to his testimony during the impeachment inquiry that eventually resulted in President Trump's acquittal by the Senate. During the inquiry, Lt Col Vindman, a Ukraine expert on the National Security Council, testified that he had raised concerns about the phone call because he believed it was inappropriate for a president to ask a foreign power to investigate a political rival. His testimony drew the wrath of President Trump, who accused him of being a "never-Trumper" and a "disgrace to the uniform." Following his testimony, Lt Col Vindman was reassigned from the National Security Council to the Pentagon, where he was not given a meaningful assignment. His lawyer, David Pressman, said that he had been subject to a campaign of bullying, intimidation and retaliation ever since he spoke out against the president. In a statement announcing his decision to retire from the military, Lt Col Vindman said that he had dedicated his life to serving his country and that he had always believed that doing so was "maintaining faith in the US Government." However, he said that he could no longer do so under the current administration. His lawyer, David Pressman, said that Lt Col Vindman's decision to retire was "a direct result of President Trump's campaign of bullying, intimidation, and retaliation." He added that this was a "sad and dark turn in the history of our country." Lt Col Vindman's decision to retire has sparked outrage among Democrats, who have accused President Trump of politicizing the military. Senator Tammy Duckworth, a Democrat from Illinois and an Iraq War veteran, said that Lt Col Vindman had been "persecuted for doing his job" and that his decision to retire was "a sad commentary on the state of our democracy." President Trump has not yet commented on Lt Col Vindman's decision to retire. However, his supporters have defended his treatment of the former National Security Council aide, saying that he was simply fulfilling his duties as commander-in-chief. The president has also tweeted that he believes Lt Col Vindman is a "never-Trumper" who was out to get him from the start. The fallout from Lt Col Vindman's decision to retire is likely to further deepen the political divide in Washington and raise questions about the role of the military in politics. His case has also raised concerns about the treatment of whistleblowers in the Trump administration and the broader issue of political retaliation against those who speak out against the president.

title: Birmingham stabbings: Family tribute to Jacob Billington
text: of 90 minutes. The family of Jacob Billington, who tragically lost his life in the recent Birmingham stabbings, paid a heartfelt tribute to the 23-year-old man. Mr. Billington was attacked in Irving Street in the early hours of Sunday while he was out with old school friends, police said. Seven other people were injured at four locations over a period of 90 minutes. In a statement released to the press, Jacob's family described him as a loving son, brother, and friend. They expressed their deep shock and sorrow at his sudden and senseless death, stating that he had a bright future ahead of him. Jacob had recently graduated from university and was looking forward to pursuing a career in social work. His family shared fond memories of his kind and caring nature, as well as his sense of humor. They emphasized that he will be greatly missed by all who knew him. The outpouring of support from the community has been overwhelming, with friends and well-wishers offering their condolences and remembering Jacob as a warm-hearted individual who always put others first. Tributes have been pouring in on social media, with many sharing their memories of Jacob and expressing their shock and sadness at his untimely death. The Birmingham stabbings have sent shockwaves through the city and left many residents feeling unsafe. West Midlands Police have launched a major investigation into the attacks, with several suspects in custody for questioning. The police have also increased patrols in the area to reassure the public and prevent any further incidents. Local authorities have urged the community to come together in solidarity and support one another during this difficult time. Vigils have been organized to remember Jacob and the other victims of the attacks, with many paying their respects and showing their solidarity with the affected families. As the investigation into the Birmingham stabbings continues, the focus remains on bringing those responsible to justice and ensuring the safety and well-being of the community. The loss of Jacob Billington has left a void in the hearts of his loved ones, but his memory will live on in the hearts of all who knew him.

title: Slovakian 'slave' trafficked to Burnley for marriage
text: The Romany victim's account of being handled as a "human slave" read like something from a 19th-century novel by Dickens, Preston Crown Court heard. She was taken while on a trip to Slovakia and trafficked to Burnley for marriage against her will. The harrowing details of her experience shed light on the dark reality of human trafficking and modern-day slavery that continues to plague society. According to the victim's testimony, she was approached by a man offering her a job opportunity in the UK. Desperate for a better life, she accepted the offer and found herself trapped in a web of deceit and exploitation. Upon arrival in Burnley, she was forced into a marriage with a complete stranger who treated her as nothing more than a possession. The victim described how she was subjected to physical and emotional abuse on a daily basis. She was forced to cook, clean, and perform other household duties without any regard for her well-being. Her passport was confiscated, and she was constantly monitored to prevent her from seeking help or escaping her situation. Despite the constant threats and manipulation, the victim found the strength to speak out against her abuser. With the help of local authorities and support organizations, she was able to break free from the chains of her captivity and seek justice for the injustices she had suffered. The court heard how her trafficker had exploited her vulnerability and lack of resources to control and exploit her for his own gain. This case serves as a stark reminder of the ongoing issue of human trafficking and the need for increased awareness and action to combat this heinous crime. The victim's story is a testament to the resilience and determination of those who have been victims of trafficking. Despite the trauma she endured, she refused to remain silent and fought for her freedom. Her courage and bravery serve as an inspiration to others who may be suffering in silence. As the trial continues, the court is faced with the task of delivering justice for the Romany victim and holding her trafficker accountable for his crimes. It is crucial that perpetrators of human trafficking are brought to justice and that victims are provided with the support and resources they need to rebuild their lives. In conclusion, the case of the Slovakian "slave" trafficked to Burnley for marriage sheds light on the cruel reality of modern-day slavery and the importance of raising awareness and taking action to combat this global issue. The victim's bravery in speaking out against her abuser serves as a beacon of hope for others who may be trapped in similar situations. It is imperative that we work together to end human trafficking and ensure that justice prevails for all victims.

title: UK to Zuckerberg: Show us you're sincere about regulation
text: Rory Cellan-JonesTechnology correspondent@BBCRoryCJon Twitter But now the UK's information commissioner has asked him to take action to show he means what he says. Elizabeth Denham has told Facebook to drop its appeal against the £500,000 ($655,000) fine she imposed for its role in the Cambridge Analytica scandal. Denham has also called on Mark Zuckerberg to demonstrate the company's commitment to accountability and transparency by cooperating with regulators in implementing stronger data protection measures. The Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) has been at the forefront of efforts to hold tech giants accountable for their handling of user data. Denham's call for Facebook to drop its appeal and work with regulators signals a growing impatience with the company's reluctance to take responsibility for its mishandling of personal information. In a letter to Mark Zuckerberg, Denham emphasized the need for Facebook to show genuine remorse and a willingness to change its behavior. She highlighted the importance of setting a precedent for other companies in the tech industry by acknowledging their responsibilities to protect user data and uphold privacy rights. The ICO's fine on Facebook was the highest possible penalty under the old data protection laws, but Denham has made it clear that it was just the first step in holding the company accountable for its actions. By dropping its appeal and cooperating with regulators, Facebook has the opportunity to demonstrate its commitment to addressing the concerns raised by the ICO and rebuilding public trust. Facebook has come under increasing scrutiny in recent years for its handling of user data and its role in spreading misinformation and inciting division. The Cambridge Analytica scandal exposed the extent to which the company's platform can be exploited for political gain, leading to calls for tighter regulation and oversight of tech companies. Mark Zuckerberg has repeatedly promised to do better and to prioritize user privacy, but actions speak louder than words. By dropping its appeal and working with regulators to implement stronger data protection measures, Facebook can show that it is serious about earning back the trust of its users and the public. The ball is now in Facebook's court as it decides how to proceed in response to the ICO's call for action. The tech giant has an opportunity to demonstrate that it is sincere about regulation and committed to upholding the highest standards of user privacy and data protection. The world will be watching to see if Facebook follows through on its promises and takes concrete steps to address the issues raised by regulators like the ICO.

title: Danielle McLaughlin 'raped and strangled' - post mortem
text: Danielle McLaughlin, from County Donegal, was found dead in a field close to tourist resorts in Canacona on Tuesday morning. The 28-year-old had travelled to Goa, India, to celebrate the Holi festival with friends. However, what was meant to be a joyous occasion turned tragic as her body was discovered in a remote location, raped and strangled. The post-mortem examination conducted on Danielle's body revealed the horrific extent of the violence she had endured. Preliminary findings indicated that she had been sexually assaulted before being killed. The news sent shockwaves through the local community and beyond, as friends, family, and strangers came to grips with the senseless loss of a vibrant young woman. Those who knew Danielle described her as a free spirit, always ready for an adventure and eager to explore new cultures. Her travels had taken her to various corners of the world, but it was in Goa where her life was tragically cut short. As the details of her final moments emerged, questions began to swirl about the safety of women travellers in foreign countries and the need for greater protections for those exploring unfamiliar territories. Authorities in Goa have launched a full investigation into Danielle's death, working to piece together the events leading up to her murder. They have urged anyone with information to come forward and assist with the inquiry. Meanwhile, her family and friends mourned the loss of a beloved daughter, sister, and friend, grappling with feelings of anger, sadness, and disbelief. Danielle's death serves as a sobering reminder of the dangers that can lurk in even the most picturesque of settings. As the sun sets on the beaches of Goa, there is a shadow cast over the paradise that claimed the life of a young woman with dreams of adventure and discovery. The echoes of her laughter and zest for life remain, but they are now tinged with sorrow and a longing for justice. In the wake of this tragedy, calls for increased safety measures for travellers, especially women, have grown louder. Many have taken to social media to express their outrage and demand accountability from those responsible for Danielle's death. As the world mourns the loss of a bright light extinguished too soon, there is a collective rallying cry for justice and a commitment to ensuring that tragedies like this are never repeated. Danielle McLaughlin's memory will live on in the hearts of all who knew her, as a reminder of the preciousness of life and the importance of safeguarding the freedoms and dreams of all who dare to explore the world. May she rest in peace, her spirit forever enshrined in the love and memories of those she touched.

title: UK fracking: Shale gas starts flowing, Cuadrilla says
text: Operations began at the Lancashire site in October for the first time since 2011 when it was suspended because of earth tremors. There have been suspensions of the renewed underground drilling operations after further tremors in December and August, with the most recent being a magnitude 1.6 tremor on Monday. Cuadrilla, the energy company overseeing the site, has said that the tremors are a result of the fracturing process used to extract shale gas. They have stressed that the tremors are small and do not pose any threat to people or property. However, the company's activities have faced opposition from environmental groups and local residents who are concerned about the potential risks of fracking, including water contamination and earthquakes. The government, on the other hand, has been supportive of fracking as a means to reduce the UK's reliance on imported gas and to boost the economy. It sees shale gas as a bridge to a low-carbon future, arguing that it is a cleaner alternative to coal and can help reduce carbon emissions. The UK government has set out regulations on seismic activity caused by fracking, stating that operations must be suspended if tremors of magnitude 0.5 or higher are detected. This is in line with the industry guidelines set by the Oil and Gas Authority, which regulates the sector. Cuadrilla has said that it has followed these regulations and that the tremors experienced at the Lancashire site are within the expected range for fracking operations. The company claims that it has taken steps to minimize the risk of seismic activity, including reducing the pressure and volume of fluid injected into the ground. Despite these reassurances, concerns remain about the impact of fracking on the environment and local communities. Environmental groups argue that fracking can lead to water contamination and air pollution, as well as contribute to climate change by releasing methane, a potent greenhouse gas. Local residents near the Lancashire site have also raised concerns about the noise and disruption caused by the drilling activities. Some have complained of increased traffic, light pollution, and a decline in property values. As Cuadrilla continues its operations in Lancashire, the debate over fracking in the UK is likely to intensify. The government will need to balance the potential economic benefits of shale gas with the concerns of environmentalists and local communities. Only time will tell whether fracking will become a sustainable source of energy for the UK or whether the risks will outweigh the rewards.

title: Tax power restrictions 'starting point' for debate, says Cameron
text: UK ministers want to hold a referendum on allowing the Welsh government to vary income tax rates. Each income tax band could only be moved at the same time and by the same amount - the so-called "lockstep." A majority "yes" vote would grant the Welsh government the power to set its own income tax rates independently of those in England. David Cameron, the UK Prime Minister, believes that giving the Welsh government control over its income tax rates would be a significant step towards further devolution of powers. He stated, "This would be a historic moment for Wales and for the UK as a whole. It is vital that we continue to evolve our Union to give greater decision-making power to all parts of the UK." However, not everyone is convinced that granting such tax powers to the Welsh government is the best course of action. There are concerns that the "lockstep" mechanism could limit the effectiveness of varying tax rates to suit the needs of the Welsh economy. Critics argue that this restriction could hinder the Welsh government's ability to respond to changing economic circumstances and could lead to suboptimal fiscal policies. On the other hand, supporters of the proposal argue that the "lockstep" mechanism is necessary to ensure that tax changes in Wales do not lead to tax competition between different parts of the UK. They believe that a uniform approach to income tax rates across the UK is crucial for maintaining economic stability and preventing a race to the bottom in terms of taxation. The debate over tax powers for the Welsh government is just one aspect of the wider discussion on devolution of powers within the UK. The Scottish government already has the power to set its own income tax rates, and there are ongoing discussions about further devolving powers to other parts of the UK, such as Northern Ireland. Overall, the issue of tax power restrictions is a complex and contentious one, with strong arguments on both sides of the debate. As the UK government moves towards greater devolution of powers, it will be crucial to carefully consider the implications of granting tax powers to different regions and to strike a balance between local autonomy and national economic cohesion. The upcoming referendum in Wales will be a crucial test of public opinion on this issue, with potentially far-reaching consequences for the future of UK governance.

title: Earl of Cardigan bound over in Savernake Estate row
text: The Earl of Cardigan was accused of damaging six pheasant feeders and the theft of a battery and electrical power unit on the Savernake Estate, near Marlborough, Wiltshire.
