Its simplicity and elegance have made it a top pick for parents seeking a name that is both sophisticated and charming. The Registrar General for Scotland's report also revealed other popular names for babies born in 2010. Lewis, a classic and strong name, was a top choice for boys. Its Scottish origin and traditional appeal have made it a favorite among parents across the country. Additionally, Olivia, a timeless and elegant name, was a popular choice for girls. Its graceful and sophisticated sound has made it a top pick for parents looking for a name that is both traditional and stylish. Overall, the top baby names in Scotland for 2010 reflected a trend towards classic and timeless names. Jack and Sophie continued to reign supreme, while names like Oliver, Ella, Lewis, and Olivia also remained popular choices. These names have stood the test of time and continue to be beloved by Scottish parents for their simplicity, elegance, and strong heritage.

title: Lana Del Rey: Israel gig 'not a political statement'
text: The singer has been criticised since announcing her debut performance at the Meteor Festival, with some people calling it a "serious mistake". "I understand that some people may have strong opinions about the situation in Israel, but I want to make it clear that my decision to perform at the festival is not a political statement," Lana Del Rey said in an exclusive interview with the BBC. The controversy surrounding her upcoming gig in Israel has sparked a heated debate on social media, with many fans divided on whether or not she should go ahead with the performance. Some have even gone as far as to accuse her of supporting the Israeli government's policies, while others have praised her for promoting peace and unity through music. "I respect everyone's right to their own opinions, but I believe that music has the power to bring people together, regardless of their differences. My intention is to spread love and positivity through my music, and I hope that my performance in Israel can help bridge the gap between different communities," Lana explained. The singer also addressed concerns about the ongoing conflict in the region, acknowledging the complex nature of the situation. "I am not here to take sides or make a political statement. My only goal is to connect with my fans through my music and create a memorable experience for everyone who attends the festival," she added. Despite the backlash, Lana Del Rey remains determined to go ahead with her performance at the Meteor Festival, expressing excitement about the opportunity to connect with her Israeli fans. "I have always felt a strong connection to my fans in Israel, and I am looking forward to sharing this special moment with them. Music has the power to transcend boundaries and bring people together, and I believe that my performance at the festival can be a positive and unifying experience for everyone involved," she said. As the debate rages on, Lana Del Rey's decision to perform in Israel continues to spark controversy and divide public opinion. While some condemn her for what they see as a blatant disregard for the political situation in the region, others applaud her for using her platform to promote peace and unity through music. In the end, only time will tell the impact of her performance at the Meteor Festival and whether it will indeed serve as a bridge between conflicting communities.

title: Wisbech burnt body: Men jailed for killing Mindaugas Arlauskas
text: Mindaugas Arlauskas, 28, was found by a passer-by in Wisbech, Cambridgeshire on 9 May. Donatas Umbrasas, 27, of Wisbech, pleaded guilty to the murder of Arlauskas in a trial held at Cambridge Crown Court. The court heard how Umbrasas and another man, Mantas Staponka, 24, viciously attacked Arlauskas in a dispute over drugs. The two men beat Arlauskas to death before setting his body on fire to destroy evidence. The brutal and senseless murder sent shockwaves through the small town of Wisbech. During the trial, it was revealed that Arlauskas had been lured to a secluded area where Umbrasas and Staponka ambushed him. The attack was captured on CCTV footage, which showed the two men beating Arlauskas mercilessly as he begged for mercy. The prosecution described the attack as "savage" and "unprovoked". Umbrasas and Staponka were both sentenced to life in prison for the murder of Arlauskas. The judge described the crime as "heinous" and expressed his condolences to the victim's family. The court also heard victim impact statements from Arlauskas' loved ones, who spoke of their grief and loss. Detective Chief Inspector Sarah Johnson, who led the investigation, praised the work of her team in bringing the perpetrators to justice. She emphasized the importance of cooperation between law enforcement and the community in solving such crimes. Johnson also urged anyone with information about the case to come forward and help bring closure to Arlauskas' family. The sentencing of Umbrasas and Staponka brought some measure of closure to the Wisbech community, but the scars of Arlauskas' murder will remain for years to come. As news of the sentencing spread, residents expressed relief that justice had been served but also sadness for the loss of a young life. In the aftermath of the trial, questions were raised about the prevalence of drug-related violence in small towns like Wisbech. Community leaders called for greater support for vulnerable individuals struggling with addiction and for increased resources for law enforcement to combat drug trafficking. As Wisbech mourns the loss of Mindaugas Arlauskas, the town also looks to the future with a renewed sense of vigilance. The tragic murder serves as a reminder of the need to address the root causes of violence and to work together as a community to prevent such senseless crimes from happening again.

title: Regulator to investigate sale of online dating profiles
text: The Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) has said it will investigate the sale of online dating profiles after reports emerged that personal data from various dating websites has been sold to third-party companies without the consent of the users. The ICO said the sale of this information could be "a significant breach of data protection laws" and raised concerns about the privacy rights of individuals whose personal information is being sold without their knowledge or consent. The investigation comes in the wake of a recent report by the BBC which revealed that a company was offering to sell access to a database of millions of online dating profiles to marketers and other interested parties for a fee. The database reportedly included sensitive information such as users' sexual preferences, relationship status, and even messages exchanged between users. This kind of data breach could have serious consequences for individuals whose personal information is being shared without their permission. It raises concerns about the potential for identity theft, fraud, and other forms of online exploitation. The ICO has urged individuals who use online dating websites to be vigilant about the security of their personal information and to ensure that they are not unknowingly sharing sensitive data with third-party companies. In a statement, the ICO said: "We are concerned about reports of the sale of online dating profiles to third parties without the consent of the individuals concerned. This could represent a serious breach of data protection laws and we will be investigating this matter further." The investigation is likely to focus on the companies involved in the sale of the data, as well as the dating websites themselves. The ICO has the power to issue fines of up to £17.5 million or 4% of a company's annual global turnover for serious breaches of data protection laws. Online dating profiles contain a wealth of personal information about individuals, including their likes and dislikes, habits, and even intimate details about their romantic preferences. The unauthorized sale of this information represents a serious violation of privacy rights and could have far-reaching consequences for individuals whose information has been compromised. The ICO's investigation is a significant step towards holding companies accountable for their actions and ensuring that individuals' personal information is protected from unauthorized access and misuse. It is crucial that companies take their data protection responsibilities seriously and uphold the privacy rights of their users.

title: 'Fewer cars' as London congestion charge zone cut back
text: TfL said in the first three months of the year there was also a negligible impact on air quality and congestion despite the reduction of the congestion charge zone in London. The move to cut back on the zone came as a response to the decrease in the number of cars entering the area, reflecting changing trends in transportation usage in the city. According to data collected by TfL, the number of vehicles entering the congestion charge zone has decreased by 14% since the reduction of the zone. This suggests that fewer cars are being driven into central London, which aligns with the city's efforts to promote sustainable modes of transportation. The decision to cut back on the congestion charge zone was met with mixed reactions from Londoners. While some residents welcomed the move as a way to reduce traffic in the city center, others expressed concerns about the potential impact on businesses and commuters who rely on driving into the area. Despite these concerns, TfL remains optimistic about the long-term benefits of reducing the congestion charge zone. The agency believes that the move will encourage more people to use public transportation, cycle, or walk in the city center, leading to a decrease in traffic congestion and a healthier environment. However, critics argue that the reduction of the congestion charge zone may not be enough to address the underlying issues of air pollution and congestion in London. They suggest that more comprehensive measures, such as expanding public transportation options and implementing stricter emission standards for vehicles, are needed to tackle these challenges effectively. In response to these concerns, TfL has announced plans to invest in improving the city's public transportation infrastructure and promoting alternative modes of transportation. The agency also plans to work closely with local businesses and communities to ensure that the changes to the congestion charge zone are implemented smoothly and do not have a detrimental impact on the economy. As London continues to grapple with the issue of traffic congestion and air pollution, the reduction of the congestion charge zone represents a step towards a more sustainable and livable city. By encouraging fewer cars in the city center, TfL hopes to create a healthier environment for residents and visitors alike, while also addressing the long-term challenges of urban transportation. Overall, the cutback on the congestion charge zone in London signals a shift towards a more environmentally friendly and efficient transportation system. While there may be challenges ahead, TfL remains committed to finding solutions that benefit both the city and its residents in the long run.

title: Charity helps drug addicts set up their own businesses
text: By Chris DeardenBBC News Some residents at Penrhyn House - a rehabilitation centre in Bangor - have set up a carpet cleaning business while others are making jams and chutneys or cosmetics from beeswax. Organisers at the centre believe that providing the residents with opportunities to start their own businesses not only helps them financially but also gives them a sense of purpose and pride in their work. One of the residents, Mark, who struggled with addiction for many years, now runs his own carpet cleaning business. "Starting this business has given me a new lease on life," Mark said. "I never thought I would be able to run my own business, but with the support and guidance from the centre, I have been able to turn my life around." The residents at Penrhyn House not only learn valuable skills in entrepreneurship but also receive ongoing support and guidance from staff members and mentors. This holistic approach to recovery aims to address the underlying issues that contribute to addiction and provides individuals with the tools they need to build a successful and sustainable future. In addition to providing residents with the opportunity to start their own businesses, Penrhyn House also partners with local charities and organizations to give back to the community. Residents participate in fundraising events and volunteer their time to support various causes, further reinforcing the importance of giving back and making a positive impact on society. The success of the residents at Penrhyn House is a testament to the power of charity and support in helping individuals overcome addiction and rebuild their lives. By providing opportunities for residents to start their own businesses and giving them the tools they need to succeed, the centre is not only changing lives but also transforming communities. As the residents continue to grow their businesses and make a positive impact on their community, Penrhyn House remains committed to supporting them every step of the way. Through their dedication to providing holistic care and opportunities for growth, the centre is paving the way for a brighter future for all those affected by addiction. In conclusion, charity plays a vital role in helping drug addicts set up their own businesses and rebuild their lives. By providing opportunities for entrepreneurship, support, and guidance, organizations like Penrhyn House are making a significant difference in the lives of individuals struggling with addiction. Through their hard work and dedication, residents are not only transforming their own lives but also contributing to the betterment of society as a whole.

title: Covid in Scotland: 'Majority' of criminal trials on hold for lockdown
text: Until the end of February only the "most serious" trials will proceed, to reduce the number of people needed to attend court in person during the pandemic. This decision, made by the Lord Justice General, comes as Scotland continues to grapple with the challenges brought about by the ongoing Covid-19 crisis. The majority of criminal trials in Scotland have been put on hold, as the justice system navigates the restrictions imposed by the lockdown. This has inevitably led to a backlog of cases, causing delays and uncertainties for both victims and defendants. The prioritization of the most serious cases aims to ensure that justice is served in a timely manner, despite the challenging circumstances. The impact of the lockdown on the justice system has been significant, with courts having to adapt to new ways of operating in order to comply with public health guidelines. Remote hearings have become more common, but there are limitations to what can be achieved through virtual means, particularly in complex criminal cases that require witness testimony and cross-examination. The decision to put the majority of criminal trials on hold is not taken lightly, as it has serious implications for all those involved in the legal process. Victims of crime may have to wait longer for justice, and defendants may have to remain in limbo as their cases are delayed. The backlog of cases will also put a strain on an already overburdened justice system, which is facing unprecedented challenges due to the pandemic. In order to address these challenges, the Lord Justice General has called for a coordinated effort to prioritize the most serious cases and ensure that they are dealt with in a timely manner. This will require cooperation from all those involved in the justice system, including judges, prosecutors, defense lawyers, and court staff. While the lockdown has had a significant impact on the justice system in Scotland, efforts are being made to ensure that the administration of justice continues as smoothly as possible under the circumstances. The prioritization of the most serious cases is one such measure aimed at mitigating the challenges posed by the pandemic. As the situation continues to evolve, it remains to be seen how the justice system will adapt to the ongoing challenges brought about by Covid-19. In the meantime, all those involved in the legal process are urged to work together to ensure that justice is served, even in the face of unprecedented obstacles.

title: Tulsa shooting: Family of man killed by police call for protests
text: Authorities are investigating the death of Terence Crutcher, 40, who had his hands in the air when he was shot next to his car, relatives say. Police footage shows the moments leading up to the shooting, where Crutcher is seen walking towards his vehicle with his hands raised above his head. Despite complying with officers' orders, he was fatally shot by Officer Betty Shelby. The incident has sparked outrage in the local community and beyond, with many calling for justice and accountability. Crutcher's family has been vocal in their demands for a thorough investigation and for the officer involved to be held accountable for her actions. "We want justice for Terence. He was a loving father, son, and brother who did not deserve to die in such a senseless and violent manner," said Crutcher's sister, Tiffany. "We will not rest until those responsible for his death are brought to justice." Protests have erupted in Tulsa, with demonstrators calling for an end to police violence and for reforms to law enforcement practices. The Black Lives Matter movement has also joined the calls for justice, highlighting the systemic issues of racial bias and excessive use of force by police. In response to the growing unrest, the Tulsa Police Department has vowed to conduct a transparent and thorough investigation into the shooting. Chief Chuck Jordan has expressed his condolences to the Crutcher family and has promised to hold those responsible for the shooting accountable. "We understand the anger and frustration that many in our community are feeling right now. We are committed to conducting a fair and impartial investigation into this tragic incident," said Chief Jordan. "We will not tolerate any actions that violate the rights and dignity of our citizens." The shooting of Terence Crutcher is yet another tragic example of the need for meaningful reforms in our criminal justice system. It is imperative that we address the systemic issues that lead to the disproportionate use of force against communities of color and work towards building trust and accountability between law enforcement and the communities they serve. As the investigation into Crutcher's death continues, his family and supporters are calling for peaceful protests and for a thorough examination of the circumstances surrounding his shooting. They are determined to seek justice for Terence and to ensure that his death is not forgotten or dismissed.

title: Missing N American couple in 'Taliban' video
text: unknown source. The couple, who went missing in 2012 while backpacking in Afghanistan, were shown in the video pleading for the US government to intervene on their behalf. In the video, both Coleman and Boyle appeared gaunt and visibly distressed. Coleman, who is originally from Pennsylvania, clutched a piece of paper with a message to President Obama written on it. She spoke directly to the camera, begging for assistance in securing their release from captivity. Boyle, a Canadian national, sat silently next to her, his eyes downcast. The couple's whereabouts remain unknown, with the Taliban claiming responsibility for their abduction. The video, which was released on a known extremist website, raised concerns about the safety and well-being of the missing couple. The families of Coleman and Boyle have been desperately seeking answers since their disappearance over four years ago. This latest video has only added to their fears and uncertainties about the couple's fate. The US and Canadian governments have both stated they are aware of the situation and are working towards securing the couple's safe return. The Taliban, in a statement accompanying the video, demanded the release of several of their fighters in exchange for Coleman and Boyle. The militant group threatened to harm the couple if their demands were not met. This has further complicated efforts to negotiate their release. Coleman's parents, Jim and Linda, have made heartfelt pleas to the public for any information that may lead to the safe return of their daughter and son-in-law. They have expressed their anguish over the uncertainty surrounding the couple's whereabouts and condition. The US State Department has assured the families of Coleman and Boyle that they are doing everything in their power to resolve the situation. Secretary of State John Kerry has been briefed on the matter and is working closely with other government agencies to secure the couple's release. As the video continues to circulate online, the families of Coleman and Boyle remain hopeful that a diplomatic solution can be reached. They are hoping that President Obama and other world leaders will intervene to bring the missing couple home safely. The plight of Caitlan Coleman and Joshua Boyle has captured the attention of the world, with many expressing outrage at their abduction and calling for their immediate release. As the search for the missing couple continues, their families remain steadfast in their belief that they will be reunited with their loved ones soon.

title: Farage: May 'wilfully deceiving' people over Brexit deal
text: The Brexit Party leader told the BBC's Andrew Marr the PM's proposed Brexit deal was a "new European treaty". In a tense interview, Mr Farage said he would demand his party became part of the government in order to ensure that Brexit was delivered in the way that the British people had voted for. Mr Farage accused Theresa May of "wilfully deceiving" the British people by presenting her Brexit deal as the only option available. He argued that the deal on the table would keep the UK tied to the EU's rules and regulations without having any say in the decision-making process. "We were promised a clean break from the EU, but what the Prime Minister is offering is far from it. This is not Brexit, this is a new European treaty that will keep us shackled to Brussels for years to come," Mr Farage stated. The outspoken politician raised concerns about the Northern Ireland backstop, pointing out that it could potentially keep the UK in a customs union with the EU indefinitely. He expressed his belief that the backstop clause could undermine the integrity of the United Kingdom and create a permanent divide between Northern Ireland and the rest of the country. Mr Farage made it clear that his party was prepared to play a significant role in shaping the future of Brexit, even if it meant being part of the government. "We cannot let this betrayal of democracy go unchallenged. The Brexit Party will continue to fight for a true Brexit that respects the will of the people," he asserted. The interview with Andrew Marr highlighted the deepening rift within the UK's political landscape over the issue of Brexit. With the deadline for leaving the EU fast approaching, tensions are running high as politicians grapple with finding a way forward that can garner enough support in Parliament. As the debate over Brexit intensifies, the pressure is mounting on Theresa May to secure a deal that can pass through Parliament. However, with staunch critics like Nigel Farage voicing their opposition to her proposed agreement, the path to a successful Brexit outcome remains uncertain. As the clock ticks down to the Brexit deadline, all eyes are on Westminster to see how the political drama will unfold. Will Theresa May be able to secure a deal that satisfies both her critics and supporters, or will the UK find itself facing further uncertainty and division in the months to come? Only time will tell.

title: Israel eases restrictions following vaccine success
text: From Sunday, shops, libraries and museums can open but social distancing and masks are still required. The health ministry says it is the first stage of easing restrictions following the success of Israel's rapid vaccination campaign.  Israel has been praised for its efficient and effective vaccination rollout, which has seen over half of its population receive at least one dose of the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine. This has led to a significant decrease in the number of new cases and hospitalizations, prompting the government to start gradually lifting restrictions. In addition to the reopening of shops, libraries, and museums, Israel has also allowed schools to resume in-person classes for all age groups. However, strict guidelines are in place to ensure the safety of students and teachers, including mandatory mask-wearing and limited class sizes. Despite the progress in vaccination efforts, Israel remains cautious and is closely monitoring the situation to prevent a resurgence of the virus. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has urged the public to continue following health guidelines and to get vaccinated as soon as they are eligible. The success of Israel's vaccination campaign has not only benefited its own population but has also served as a model for other countries struggling to contain the spread of the virus. Israel's use of technology, a well-developed healthcare system, and a strong sense of community have been instrumental in its fight against COVID-19. As the country continues to roll out vaccines to more of its population, there is hope that life will soon return to a sense of normalcy. Businesses that have been shuttered for months are looking forward to welcoming back customers, and families are eager to reunite after being apart for so long. While there is still much work to be done to fully contain the virus and its variants, Israel's success in vaccinating its population is a beacon of hope for the rest of the world. With continued vigilance and adherence to public health guidelines, it is possible that we may soon see an end to the pandemic and a return to a more familiar way of life. As Israel moves forward with its gradual reopening, the government will continue to monitor the situation closely and make adjustments as needed. The health and safety of its citizens remain the top priority, and the success of the vaccination campaign has brought renewed optimism to the country as it looks towards a brighter future.

title: Henry Moore statue: Minister's concerns over sale plan
text: Len Tingle Political editor, Yorkshire Now her planned sale is provoking a national outcry and the lady is certainly not going quietly. This week there was even a debate in Parliament and Culture Minister Nadine Dorries expressed her concerns over the potential sale of the iconic Henry Moore statue.  The sculpture, affectionately known as "Draped Seated Woman" or "Old Flo", has stood in Yorkshire for over 60 years and has become a beloved landmark in the community. Many locals have fond memories of playing around the statue as children and seeing it every day as they go about their daily lives. But now, the local council is considering selling the statue to a private collector in order to generate much-needed funds. It's a decision that has sparked outrage among residents, art enthusiasts, and even politicians like Dorries, who fear that the statue will be lost to the public forever if it is sold. In her speech to Parliament, Dorries emphasized the importance of preserving cultural heritage and ensuring that iconic artworks like Henry Moore's statue remain accessible to the public. She urged the council to explore alternative options for raising funds, such as securing government grants or partnering with cultural institutions to keep the statue in public hands. The debate in Parliament brought attention to the wider issue of funding cuts to local councils and the challenges they face in maintaining public artworks and cultural spaces. Many feel that selling off valuable assets like the Henry Moore statue is a short-sighted solution to a complex problem and could have long-term consequences for the community's cultural identity. Local residents have started a petition to save the statue, with thousands of signatures already gathered in support. They are hopeful that their voices will be heard and that a solution can be found to keep the statue in its rightful place for future generations to enjoy. As the debate rages on, the fate of the Henry Moore statue hangs in the balance. Will it be sold to the highest bidder, or will the council reconsider and find a way to preserve this beloved piece of British art history? Only time will tell, but one thing is clear – the people of Yorkshire are not willing to let go of their iconic lady without a fight.

title: The Indian tribe that gave up hunting to save forests
text: At one time, Chaiyievi Zhiinyii was a skilled hunter. But he stopped hunting in 2001. The Angami tribe gave up what was an important source of livelihood some 20 years ago in order to create a sustainable future for their community and the forests they call home. The decision to give up hunting was not an easy one for the Angami tribe. For generations, hunting had been ingrained in their culture and way of life. It was a means of providing food and income for their families. But as the forests began to disappear at an alarming rate due to deforestation and overhunting, the tribe realized that they needed to change their ways in order to protect their environment for future generations. Chaiyievi Zhiinyii recalls the moment when the tribe made the collective decision to stop hunting. "It was a difficult choice to make, but we knew that if we continued hunting at the same rate, our forests would soon be gone," he says. "We had to think about the long-term sustainability of our land and the well-being of our people." Instead of hunting, the Angami tribe turned to alternative sources of income such as agriculture and eco-tourism. They began planting crops like rice, maize, and vegetables to feed their families and sell in local markets. They also started offering guided tours of their forests to visitors who wanted to learn more about their culture and traditions. The decision to give up hunting has paid off for the Angami tribe. The forests have started to regenerate, with native plant species returning and wildlife populations rebounding. The tribe has also seen an increase in eco-tourism, bringing in much-needed income to support their community. Chaiyievi Zhiinyii is proud of the progress the tribe has made since they stopped hunting. "Our forests are thriving once again, and we are able to provide for our families in a sustainable way," he says. "We may have had to give up hunting, but in return, we have gained so much more – a future where our forests are protected, and our people can thrive." The Angami tribe's decision to give up hunting serves as a powerful example of how indigenous communities can lead the way in conservation and sustainable living. By putting the health of their forests first, they have created a model for other tribes and communities around the world to follow.

title: NI political reaction to Birmingham pub bombing apology
text: Birmingham, England, killing 21 and injuring over 180 others. This apology from Hayes, a former member of the Provisional IRA, has sparked mixed reactions in Northern Ireland's political landscape. Unionist leaders have strongly condemned Hayes' apology, calling it insufficient and insincere. They argue that the victims and their families deserve more than just words from someone who was directly responsible for such a heinous act of terrorism. DUP leader, Jeffrey Donaldson, stated, "Hayes' apology is too little, too late. The pain and suffering caused by the Birmingham pub bombings can never be erased by a belated apology. Actions speak louder than words." On the other hand, nationalist politicians have welcomed Hayes' apology as a step towards reconciliation and healing. Sinn Féin leader, Mary Lou McDonald, expressed empathy for the victims and their families, acknowledging the deep wounds left by the Troubles. "It takes courage to confront the past and seek forgiveness. We must all strive to build a more peaceful and inclusive society," she said. The Alliance Party has called for a thorough investigation into the events leading up to the Birmingham pub bombings, in the hopes of shedding more light on the role of individuals like Hayes and preventing similar tragedies in the future. Party leader Naomi Long emphasized the importance of truth and accountability in the reconciliation process. "We owe it to the victims and their families to uncover the full truth behind this horrific attack and hold those responsible to account," she stated. The SDLP has emphasized the need for genuine remorse and a commitment to justice from former paramilitaries like Hayes. Party leader, Colum Eastwood, urged Hayes to cooperate with authorities and provide all relevant information about the Birmingham pub bombings. "Apologies are only meaningful if they are accompanied by actions to right the wrongs of the past," Eastwood noted. Overall, the political reaction in Northern Ireland to Michael Christopher Hayes' apology for the Birmingham pub bombings reflects the deep division and complex legacy of the Troubles. While opinions vary on the significance of his apology, there is a shared consensus on the importance of addressing the past in order to move forward towards a more peaceful and reconciled future.

title: Rio 2016: 'Welcome to Hell' warn police
text: By BBC Trending What's popular and why? Along with the relatives carrying flowers and taxi drivers waiting with name boards, there were lines of off-duty police with a stern warning for visitors arriving in Rio for the 2016 Olympics - "Welcome to Hell." This ominous message was plastered on a banner at Rio de Janeiro's main airport, alerting tourists and athletes alike to the chaos and danger that awaited them in the city. The police officers, frustrated with the lack of resources and support from the government, did not mince words when speaking to the media. They described a city on the brink of collapse, with rampant crime, political corruption, and crumbling infrastructure. They painted a bleak picture of Rio as a city where visitors could be at risk of muggings, kidnappings, and even death. But despite the dire warnings, Rio's residents were quick to defend their city. They pointed out that the "Welcome to Hell" banner was not representative of the entire city, and that there were many beautiful and safe areas to explore. They reassured visitors that with some common sense and caution, they could still have a great time at the Olympics. The police warnings did raise serious concerns, however. As the Games approached, reports of violence and crime in Rio continued to make headlines around the world. Tourists were advised to avoid certain areas, to be vigilant of their surroundings, and to keep a close eye on their belongings at all times. The situation was further complicated by the ongoing political turmoil in Brazil. Just weeks before the Olympics were set to begin, President Dilma Rousseff was impeached, adding to the sense of uncertainty and instability in the country. Some feared that the chaos in the streets could spill over into the Olympic venues, putting athletes and spectators at risk. Despite the challenges, the 2016 Olympics in Rio were a success in many ways. The city hosted a spectacular opening ceremony, showcasing Brazil's rich cultural heritage and vibrant spirit. Athletes from around the world competed fiercely, breaking records and inspiring millions of fans. But the legacy of the "Welcome to Hell" warnings lingered long after the Games had ended. Rio's problems with crime and corruption were not easily forgotten, and the city continued to grapple with these issues in the years that followed. The police warnings served as a stark reminder of the challenges that Rio faced, and the urgent need for change and reform in the city. As visitors departed Rio, they were left with a mix of emotions - awe at the beauty of the city, concern for its future, and gratitude for the experience of witnessing the Olympics in one of the most iconic and complex cities in the world. In the end, Rio 2016 was a reminder that even in the face of adversity, the spirit of competition and camaraderie could prevail.

title: Oxford Covered Market rent hike defended
text: A petition to "Save The Oxford Covered Market" has gathered more than 8,000 signatures since it started in March. The council said rents were currently "very low" considering the market's central location, but that cuts in funding meant they had no choice but to raise prices. The historic covered market, which has been in operation for over 200 years, is home to a variety of independent businesses selling everything from fresh produce to handmade goods. However, many traders have expressed concerns about the proposed rent hike, fearing that it could force them out of business. One such trader is Sarah Jenkins, who has been running a vintage clothing shop in the market for the past decade. She told BBC News that she was worried about the impact that the rent increase would have on her business. "I understand that the council needs to raise revenue, but I feel like they are not taking into account the impact this will have on us small traders. We already operate on tight margins, and any increase in rent could push us over the edge," Jenkins said. In response to the petition, a spokesperson for the council defended the decision to increase rents, citing the need to cover rising costs and maintain the market's facilities. "The Oxford Covered Market is a unique and valuable asset to the city, and we are committed to ensuring its continued success. The current rents are well below market value for a location as prime as this, and we believe that the proposed increase is necessary to ensure the long-term sustainability of the market," the spokesperson said. However, the petitioners argue that the council should explore other ways to generate revenue without burdening the traders. Some have suggested increasing footfall through marketing efforts or hosting more events in the market to attract visitors. The Oxford Covered Market has a rich history and is a cherished part of the city's cultural heritage. Local residents and tourists alike flock to the market to experience its unique charm and support the small businesses that call it home. As the debate over the rent hike continues, traders and supporters of the market are hoping for a resolution that takes into account the concerns of all parties involved. The future of the Oxford Covered Market hangs in the balance, and many are watching closely to see how this situation unfolds.

title: Dog microchipping to be compulsory in Wales by 2015
text: The move is seen as a way to improve animal welfare and develop responsible dog ownership by helping identify strays. It is estimated 190,000 dogs will need to be microchipped before the March 2015 deadline. Nearly half of all dogs in Wales are currently not microchipped, leaving them at risk of becoming lost or abandoned without a way to be traced back to their owners. Microchipping involves inserting a tiny chip under the skin, usually between the shoulder blades of a dog. The chip contains a unique identification number that can be scanned by a special device to retrieve the owner's contact information from a national database. This allows lost or stray dogs to be quickly reunited with their families, reducing the number of animals ending up in shelters or euthanized. Supporters of the new legislation believe that making microchipping compulsory will not only help decrease the number of stray dogs on the streets but also promote responsible pet ownership. By ensuring that all dogs are registered and have up-to-date contact information, owners can be held accountable for their pets' actions, such as attacks on other animals or humans. In addition to improving animal welfare, mandatory microchipping can also have health benefits for dogs by ensuring they receive proper medical care. With a registered chip, veterinarians can access the dog's medical history and vaccination records, making it easier to provide necessary treatment and prevent the spread of diseases. However, some critics argue that the cost of microchipping could be a barrier for low-income families or individuals with multiple pets. They also raise concerns about potential privacy issues related to the national database holding personal information about pet owners. Despite these challenges, the Welsh government remains committed to enforcing the new microchipping law in the hopes of creating a safer and more responsible environment for dogs and their owners. Failure to comply with the legislation could result in fines of up to £500 for dog owners, emphasizing the importance of taking proactive steps to ensure their pets' well-being. With the deadline fast approaching, animal welfare organizations across Wales are offering discounted or even free microchipping services to help dog owners meet the requirements of the new law. By working together to promote responsible pet ownership, the government and various stakeholders hope to make a positive impact on the lives of dogs and their owners throughout the country.

title: Iran nuclear deal: Rouhani says West has no right to make changes
text: The US and French leaders announced on Tuesday that they were working on a "new deal" that would expand and extend the terms of the 2015 accord. But Mr Rouhani said they had no "right" to renegotiate a deal that had already been agreed upon by multiple parties. Speaking on state television, President Rouhani reiterated his stance on the issue, stating that the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) was a carefully crafted agreement that should not be tampered with. He emphasized that the terms of the deal were agreed upon after extensive negotiations and any attempt to change them would be met with resistance. The Iranian president went on to say that the US and France were overstepping their bounds by attempting to alter the agreement without consulting all parties involved. He warned that such actions could jeopardize the stability of the region and lead to further tensions between Iran and the Western powers. Mr Rouhani also criticized the United States for its decision to withdraw from the JCPOA in 2018, a move that was widely condemned by the international community. He stated that Iran had complied with its obligations under the agreement despite the US withdrawal and re-imposition of sanctions, and expected the remaining parties to uphold their end of the deal. The Iranian leader urged the European signatories of the JCPOA, namely the UK, Germany, and France, to uphold their commitments to the agreement and resist pressure from the US to renegotiate the terms. He stressed the importance of maintaining diplomatic channels and dialogue in order to address any concerns or disputes that may arise. In response to the US and French efforts to renegotiate the nuclear deal, Iran's Foreign Ministry issued a statement reaffirming its commitment to the JCPOA and warning against any attempts to undermine or alter the agreement. The statement called on all parties to the deal to uphold their obligations and respect the terms that were agreed upon in 2015. Despite the ongoing tensions and disagreements surrounding the Iran nuclear deal, President Rouhani expressed hope that a resolution could be reached through diplomatic means. He reiterated Iran's willingness to engage in dialogue and negotiations with all parties in order to address any concerns and ensure the stability of the region. In conclusion, President Rouhani's comments underscored Iran's unwavering commitment to the JCPOA and its opposition to any attempts to alter the terms of the agreement. The future of the nuclear deal remains uncertain, but Iran's stance on the issue is clear: the agreement should be upheld and respected by all parties involved.

title: Protected status for flapper skate 'nursery' off Skye
text: The flapper skate "nursery" is in Skye's Inner Sound. The fish belong to the shark family and females can grow to 2.8m (9ft) in length. This area serves as a critical habitat for these majestic creatures, providing a safe environment for their young to grow and develop. Conservationists have long been concerned about the declining populations of flapper skate in Scottish waters. Overfishing and habitat destruction have taken a toll on these vulnerable species, pushing them to the brink of extinction. The designation of the flapper skate "nursery" off Skye as a protected area is a crucial step in ensuring the survival of these iconic fish. The Scottish government has recently announced plans to designate the flapper skate "nursery" as a Marine Protected Area (MPA), providing legal protection for this sensitive habitat. This designation will prohibit activities such as trawling and dredging, which can cause significant harm to the flapper skate and their nursery grounds. In addition to the MPA designation, the Scottish government is also implementing conservation measures to help restore flapper skate populations in the area. This includes monitoring populations, enforcing fishing restrictions, and working with local communities to raise awareness about the importance of protecting these endangered fish. The flapper skate "nursery" off Skye is not only important for the survival of these majestic creatures, but also for the health of the entire marine ecosystem. These fish play a key role in maintaining the balance of the underwater world, preying on smaller fish and helping to regulate populations. By designating the flapper skate "nursery" as a protected area, the Scottish government is taking a proactive approach to conservation and working to ensure the long-term sustainability of these vulnerable species. This is a positive step forward in the fight to protect Scotland's marine environment and preserve its rich biodiversity for generations to come. As we move forward, it is essential that we continue to prioritize the protection of our oceans and the incredible creatures that call them home. By working together and taking action to safeguard habitats like the flapper skate "nursery" off Skye, we can make a real difference in the preservation of our marine ecosystems. It is up to all of us to ensure that these precious resources are protected for future generations to enjoy.

title: How many migrant children cross the English Channel?
text: By William McLennan BBC News More than 7,400 people have stepped into small boats and navigated one of the busiest shipping lanes in the world to reach the south coast of England in 2020. At least six people are believed to have died trying to make the treacherous journey, including a five-year-old boy. These numbers highlight the dangerous desperation that some migrants are facing as they try to reach the UK. Among those making the journey are unaccompanied children, some as young as 10 years old. The number of migrant children crossing the English Channel has been steadily increasing over the past few years. In 2019, there were 1,890 migrant children who arrived in the UK by small boat, compared to just 39 in 2018. This sharp rise in the number of children making the journey is deeply concerning, as these vulnerable young people are putting themselves at risk in search of a better life. Many of these children are fleeing conflict, persecution, or poverty in their home countries. They often travel alone or with smugglers who promise them a safe passage to the UK. However, the reality is far from safe, as the journey across the English Channel can be perilous, with rough seas, strong currents, and overcrowded boats posing serious risks to those on board. Despite the dangers, many migrant children are willing to take the risk in the hope of finding safety and security in the UK. Once they arrive in the country, they face an uncertain future, as they navigate the complex asylum system and try to rebuild their lives in a foreign land. The UK government has been criticized for its handling of the migrant crisis, with critics saying that more needs to be done to protect vulnerable children and prevent them from making the dangerous journey across the English Channel. Charities and advocacy groups have called for increased support for migrant children, including better access to legal representation, mental health services, and accommodation. As the number of migrant children crossing the English Channel continues to rise, it is clear that urgent action is needed to address this humanitarian crisis. The UK government must work with international partners to tackle the root causes of migration, provide safe and legal routes for vulnerable children to reach the UK, and ensure that those who do arrive are given the support they need to rebuild their lives. In the meantime, charities and local communities are stepping up to provide emergency assistance to migrant children who arrive on the south coast of England. These grassroots efforts are essential in providing immediate support to those in need and highlighting the plight of vulnerable children who are risking their lives to seek safety and security in the UK.

title: Carney and the "no deal" Brexit threat
text: and the European Union would significantly worsen these effects. This is the warning from Mark Carney, the Governor of the Bank of England, in his recent speech at the London School of Economics. Carney highlighted the potential dangers of a "no deal" Brexit, where the UK leaves the EU without any agreements in place regarding trade, regulations, or other important aspects of the relationship. He emphasized that such a scenario could lead to disruptions in supply chains, higher prices for consumers, and increased financial uncertainty. The Governor also pointed out that the uncertainty surrounding Brexit has already had a negative impact on the economy, with businesses delaying investments and individuals reducing their spending. Carney suggested that a disorderly Brexit could make this situation even worse, potentially causing a recession in the UK. However, Carney did acknowledge that the Bank of England is prepared for various Brexit scenarios and has taken steps to mitigate the risks. He mentioned that the central bank has ensured that banks and other financial institutions are well-capitalized and able to withstand potential shocks to the system. Despite these preparations, Carney stressed that a "no deal" Brexit would still be a challenging situation for the UK economy. He urged policymakers to do everything they can to avoid such an outcome and to work towards a deal that minimizes the negative impact of Brexit on the country. The Governor's warnings come at a crucial time in the Brexit negotiations, as the UK and the EU are still struggling to reach a comprehensive agreement on the terms of their future relationship. With the deadline for Brexit rapidly approaching, the possibility of a "no deal" scenario is becoming more real, raising concerns among businesses, investors, and the public. In response to Carney's speech, government officials have reiterated their commitment to securing a good deal for the UK and ensuring a smooth transition out of the EU. Prime Minister Theresa May has emphasized the importance of reaching a mutually beneficial agreement with the EU and avoiding a disruptive Brexit. As the Brexit negotiations continue, the economic future of the UK remains uncertain. Mark Carney's warnings serve as a reminder of the potential risks of a "no deal" Brexit and the importance of finding a solution that protects the interests of the British people and the economy. Only time will tell how the Brexit process will unfold and what impact it will have on the UK and its relationship with the EU.

title: Ian Paisley challenges BBC over Maldives 'wrongdoing' evidence
text: He was speaking for the first time since a BBC Spotlight programme alleged that the government minister paid for part of the luxurious holidays enjoyed by politicians and their families in the Maldives. Ian Paisley, a Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) MP, vehemently denied the accusations, calling them "completely false and defamatory". During a press conference, Paisley challenged the BBC to provide concrete evidence to support their claims. "I categorically deny any wrongdoing and challenge the BBC to produce any shred of evidence to back up their outrageous accusations," he stated adamantly. The MP emphasized that he has always acted within the bounds of the law and has nothing to hide. The allegations started swirling after the BBC programme exposed how a government minister allegedly accepted lavish holiday accommodations in the Maldives, paid for by a wealthy businessman. The programme suggested that the minister failed to declare these luxurious trips, which would be a breach of parliamentary rules. Ian Paisley maintained his innocence, stating that he has always been transparent about his affairs and has never accepted any illegal gifts or favors. "I have never hidden my relationships with individuals or businesses, and I have never engaged in any corrupt activities," he asserted. The DUP MP criticized the BBC for what he perceived as a lack of journalistic integrity and accused the media outlet of trying to tarnish his reputation without any solid evidence. "The BBC should be held accountable for spreading baseless rumors and damaging my character without any proof," he declared. Paisley's defiant stance has stirred up controversy within political circles, with some calling for a full investigation into the allegations. The opposition parties have demanded transparency from the government and have urged Paisley to come clean if there is any truth to the accusations. As the debate rages on, the BBC stands by its reporting and maintains that it has solid evidence to support the claims made in the programme. The broadcaster has vowed to continue investigating the matter and uncovering the truth behind the alleged wrongdoing in the Maldives. As Ian Paisley faces mounting pressure to address the accusations head-on, the public eagerly awaits any further developments in this unfolding scandal. Only time will tell whether the BBC's allegations hold water or if the DUP MP's reputation will remain untarnished in the face of these serious claims.

title: Billy Caldwell: Campaigner's company sells cannabis oil
text: Charlotte Caldwell has been treating her severely epileptic son Billy, 12, with cannabis oil since 2016. His most recent supply was confiscated at Heathrow Airport. It was returned after a fierce campaign by Caldwell, who is an outspoken advocate for the use of cannabis oil to help manage epilepsy. Billy Caldwell's case has sparked a national debate about the use of cannabis oil for medical purposes. His mother argues that the oil has dramatically improved Billy's quality of life, reducing his seizures and allowing him to live a more normal childhood. However, the use of cannabis oil remains a controversial issue in the UK, where it is illegal to possess or supply cannabis for any purpose. Despite the legal restrictions, Charlotte Caldwell has become a vocal campaigner for the legalization of cannabis oil for medical use. She founded a company, Billy's Bud, which sells cannabis oil products online. The company claims that its products are made from organic, high-quality cannabis plants and are free from harmful chemicals or additives. Critics of Caldwell's company argue that selling cannabis oil as a medical treatment is irresponsible and dangerous. They point to the lack of scientific evidence supporting the use of cannabis oil for epilepsy and warn of potential side effects and risks associated with its use. The UK's Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) has also issued warnings about the safety and legality of buying unlicensed cannabis oil products. Despite the controversy surrounding Billy's Bud, Charlotte Caldwell remains committed to providing cannabis oil to families in need. She believes that the benefits of the oil far outweigh any potential risks and argues that the current laws are standing in the way of patients receiving life-saving treatments. In response to the growing demand for cannabis oil products, the UK government has launched a review of the current rules surrounding the use of medical cannabis. The review is expected to consider the evidence of the therapeutic benefits of cannabis oil and explore ways to make it more widely available to patients who could benefit from its use. While the debate over cannabis oil continues, Charlotte Caldwell will continue to fight for the rights of her son and others like him to access the treatments they need. Billy's story has put a spotlight on the issue of medical cannabis in the UK and has reignited calls for a change in the law to allow for the use of cannabis oil as a legitimate medical treatment.

title: Calls for more openness over enterprise zone jobs
text: have not been transparent enough about the exact nature of the jobs being created in enterprise zones across Wales. Enterprise zones were introduced in Wales in 2011 as a way to attract businesses and create job opportunities in areas that were struggling economically. The zones offer various incentives for businesses to set up or expand, such as reduced business rates and access to funding. While the Welsh government has touted the success of the enterprise zones in creating over 5,100 jobs, Plaid Cymru argues that there needs to be more transparency around the types of jobs being created. They claim that the public has a right to know whether these jobs are high-quality, well-paying positions or if they are low-wage, temporary roles. The Information Commissioner is currently investigating a complaint that accuses the Welsh government of not being forthcoming enough about the details of the jobs created in the enterprise zones. This complaint highlights the growing concern over accountability and transparency in government initiatives. Plaid Cymru leader Adam Price has called for more openness and scrutiny when it comes to the enterprise zones, stating that "the public deserves to know the full picture." He argues that without a clear understanding of the quality of the jobs being created, it is impossible to assess the true impact of the enterprise zones on the Welsh economy. In response, Economy Minister Ken Skates has defended the government's record, stating that the jobs created in the enterprise zones are diverse and varied. He emphasizes that the focus should be on the overall economic impact of the zones, rather than just the specifics of individual jobs. Despite this reassurance, calls for more transparency continue to grow. The Information Commissioner's investigation will hopefully shed light on the situation and provide clarity on the nature of the jobs being created in enterprise zones across Wales. As the debate rages on, it is clear that there is a need for better communication between the government and the public when it comes to economic initiatives like the enterprise zones. Transparency and accountability are crucial in building trust and ensuring that every citizen has access to accurate information about the state of the economy and the impact of government policies. Only through open dialogue and a commitment to transparency can we ensure that economic development benefits all members of society.

title: Tintin and the vanishing murals: Brussels races to save art
text: By Daniel Curtis BBC News, Brussels In the early 1920s, Hergé, then a 15-year-old Georges Remi, was a scout and student at Institut St. Boniface in Brussels. It was during this time that he first began to develop the character of Tintin, a young reporter who would go on to have countless adventures around the world. One of Tintin's most famous escapades was chronicled in The Castafiore Emerald, where he finds himself embroiled in a mysterious case involving a precious gem and a series of disappearing murals. Fast forward to present-day Brussels, and the city is facing a similar dilemma as the murals that inspired Hergé's iconic Tintin adventures are vanishing at an alarming rate. These murals, which were painted on the walls of buildings throughout the city, serve as a testament to both the character of Tintin and the artistic legacy of Brussels. The city is now racing to save these endangered works of art, which have become an integral part of Brussels' cultural heritage. Efforts are being made to preserve and restore the murals, ensuring that future generations will be able to enjoy them just as much as past ones have. One of the most striking murals at risk is located on the side of a building near Grand Place, depicting Tintin, Captain Haddock, and Snowy in one of their many adventures. The vibrant colors and intricate details of the mural have captivated visitors for years, but time and neglect have taken their toll. Local authorities have teamed up with art conservationists to develop a plan to protect these murals from further deterioration. This includes regular inspections, maintenance, and even digital documentation to create virtual replicas in case the originals are lost. But the challenges are immense. Many of the murals are located in busy urban areas, making them vulnerable to pollution, vandalism, and weather damage. Some have already been lost forever, fading into obscurity as the buildings they once adorned are demolished or renovated. Despite these obstacles, there is a renewed sense of urgency to save the remaining murals before it's too late. The Tintin murals are not just works of art; they are a part of Brussels' identity and history. To lose them would be to lose a piece of the city's soul. As the city races against time to preserve these vanishing murals, there is hope that future generations will continue to be inspired by the adventures of Tintin and the rich artistic heritage of Brussels. The challenge may be great, but the stakes are even greater - ensuring that these beloved murals endure for years to come.

title: Sarwar and Baillie out in Scottish Labour reshuffle
text: Anas Sarwar, who lost to Richard Leonard in last year's leadership contest, has been replaced as health spokesperson by Monica Lennon. And Jackie Baillie has lost her role as the party's economy spokeswoman. Ms Baillie backed Mr Sarwar during the leadership race, leading many to speculate that her demotion is a result of her allegiance to the former leader.  The Scottish Labour Party is undergoing a period of transition, with new leader Leonard making significant changes to his shadow cabinet. The reshuffle comes at a crucial time for the party, as they seek to regain ground lost to the SNP in recent years.  Monica Lennon, who has been a vocal advocate for healthcare reform in Scotland, is seen as a strong choice to take over the health portfolio. With her background as a nurse and a track record of standing up for vulnerable communities, Lennon is well-positioned to take on the responsibilities of the role.  On the other hand, Jackie Baillie's demotion has raised eyebrows among party members. Baillie, a respected figure within the party, was widely expected to retain her position as economy spokeswoman. Her support for Sarwar may have played a role in her removal, although party officials have not provided any specific reasons for the decision.  In a statement following the reshuffle, Leonard emphasized the need for unity within the party. "These changes are part of our ongoing effort to strengthen our team and focus on the issues that matter most to the people of Scotland," he said.  The reshuffle has also seen the promotion of several rising stars within the party, including Pauline McNeill, who has been appointed as the party's new economy spokeswoman. McNeill, a former journalist and trade unionist, is seen as a fresh face who can help the party connect with voters in urban areas.  Overall, the reshuffle reflects Leonard's efforts to shake up the party and present a new vision for Scottish Labour. With the next Scottish Parliament elections looming on the horizon, the party will need to work diligently to regain public trust and present a strong alternative to the SNP. The coming months will be crucial in determining the party's future direction and its ability to make gains in the Scottish political landscape.

title: Pisa literacy survey: Finland loses top spot to Asians
text: The tri-annual Programme for International Student Assessment (Pisa) survey of 15-year-olds ranked China's Shanghai region in first place. With Finland coming third, its education minister blamed a decline in reading, especially among boys. Pupils in Shanghai scored significantly higher in reading, math, and science compared to their peers in other countries, cementing their reputation for academic excellence. One of the key factors contributing to the success of students in Shanghai is the emphasis on early childhood education and parental involvement in their child's learning. Chinese parents place a high value on education and often invest heavily in extra-curricular activities and tutoring to ensure their children excel academically. This level of commitment from both parents and students has undoubtedly played a significant role in Shanghai's impressive performance in the Pisa survey. In contrast, Finland, which has long been regarded as a global leader in education, has seen a decline in its reading scores, particularly among boys. The Finnish education minister attributed this drop to a lack of focus on reading and literacy skills in the classroom, as well as a shift towards digital learning tools that may not be as effective in teaching essential reading skills. This decline in reading proficiency is a cause for concern, as literacy is a fundamental skill that underpins success in all other disciplines. Despite Finland's slip in the rankings, it is important to recognize that the country continues to perform well in other areas, including science and mathematics. Finnish schools are known for their innovative teaching methods, which focus on fostering creativity, critical thinking, and problem-solving skills in students. These qualities are increasingly important in a rapidly changing world where adaptability and lifelong learning are essential for success. While the Pisa survey results provide valuable insights into the strengths and weaknesses of education systems around the world, it is also important to remember that standardized tests can only capture a limited snapshot of a country's educational landscape. Factors such as socio-economic background, cultural attitudes towards learning, and teacher quality all play a role in shaping student outcomes and should be taken into account when interpreting the results of international assessments. As countries around the world continue to strive for excellence in education, it is essential that we learn from each other's successes and challenges. By sharing best practices and collaborating on innovative solutions, we can create a more equitable and effective education system that empowers all students to reach their full potential.

title: Lithuania country profile
text: Not much more than a decade after it regained its independence during the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1990, Lithuania was welcomed as a NATO member in late March 2004. The Baltic state had spent years working towards this goal, aligning its foreign and security policies with those of the West. Joining NATO was a significant milestone for Lithuania, as it brought the country under the collective security umbrella of the alliance. This move also signaled Lithuania's desire to strengthen its ties with Western Europe and the United States, further distancing itself from its Soviet past. In addition to joining NATO, Lithuania became a member of the European Union in May 2004, solidifying its position as a Western-leaning nation. EU membership brought economic benefits, as Lithuania gained access to the European single market and received funding for infrastructure and development projects. Despite these achievements, Lithuania faces challenges, both domestically and internationally. The country has a complex relationship with its powerful neighbor, Russia, which has raised concerns about security and energy dependence. Lithuania is working to diversify its energy sources to reduce its reliance on Russian natural gas, as well as strengthening its defense capabilities. Domestically, Lithuania faces economic challenges, including high levels of emigration and a shrinking population. The country has made efforts to attract investment and create a more business-friendly environment, but more needs to be done to ensure sustained economic growth. Culturally, Lithuania has a rich heritage, with a strong emphasis on music, literature, and art. The country is known for its traditional folk music and dance, as well as its vibrant contemporary arts scene. Vilnius, the capital, is a UNESCO World Heritage site, known for its well-preserved medieval old town. Lithuania's geography is diverse, with forests, lakes, and sandy beaches along the Baltic Sea coast. The country has several national parks and nature reserves, making it a popular destination for outdoor enthusiasts. In recent years, Lithuania has been at the forefront of efforts to counter disinformation and hybrid threats, particularly from Russia. The country has established a center to monitor and combat fake news and propaganda, as well as strengthening its cybersecurity defenses. Overall, Lithuania is a small but resilient country with a strong sense of national identity and a commitment to its Western allies. As it continues to navigate the challenges of the 21st century, Lithuania remains determined to build a prosperous and secure future for its citizens.

title: Spyware use in domestic violence 'escalating'
text: By Zoe KleinmanTechnology reporter, BBC News Tracking and listening devices, often disguised as everyday objects, retail online for under £50 and are easy to install, says cybersecurity experts. However, what was once seen as a tool for espionage and government surveillance has now found its way into the hands of domestic abusers, escalating the severity of intimate partner violence cases. Spyware, or spy software, is typically installed on a victim's device without their consent or knowledge, allowing the abuser to monitor their every move. This invasive technology can track a victim's location, read their messages, listen to their phone calls, and even access their camera and microphone without detection. The use of spyware in cases of domestic violence has become increasingly prevalent, with victims often unaware that their abuser is spying on them. This level of surveillance not only violates their privacy but also instills fear and a sense of powerlessness in the victim, further perpetuating the cycle of abuse. One survivor of domestic violence, who wishes to remain anonymous, shared her experience with spyware in an interview with the BBC. She recounted how her ex-partner installed spyware on her phone, allowing him to track her movements and listen in on her conversations without her knowledge. The sense of violation and fear she felt knowing that he was constantly monitoring her every move was profoundly unsettling. This survivor's story is not uncommon, with many victims of domestic violence falling prey to the insidious use of spyware by their abusers. In some cases, spyware has been used by abusers to stalk and harass their victims, causing immense distress and psychological harm. The widespread availability and affordability of spyware online have made it easier for abusers to access and deploy these tools against their victims. This puts vulnerable individuals at an increased risk of harm and perpetuates the cycle of abuse in abusive relationships. In response to this growing issue, cybersecurity experts are calling for greater awareness and education around the dangers of spyware use in cases of domestic violence. They emphasize the importance of securing devices, regularly checking for suspicious activity, and seeking help from support services if a victim suspects they are being monitored. It is crucial that victims of domestic violence are made aware of the potential risks associated with spyware and are empowered to take steps to protect themselves from digital surveillance. By raising awareness and advocating for the rights of survivors, we can work towards preventing the escalation of intimate partner violence through the use of spyware.

title: Energy firm's Cheshire plans refused by councillors
text: Cheshire West and Chester Council's planning committee voted 10 to 1 to reject IGas's plans for Ellesmere Port because of "climate change" concerns. Anti-fracking campaigner Matt Bryan, who has been leading the local opposition to the proposed energy firm's plans, hailed the decision as a victory for environmental conservation. Speaking to reporters outside the council chambers, Bryan emphasized the importance of taking a stand against unsustainable energy practices in the face of growing climate challenges. "We cannot afford to continue relying on fossil fuels like natural gas when we know the detrimental impact they have on our planet," he asserted. IGas had been seeking permission to explore for shale gas in the Ellesmere Port area, with plans to potentially extract the resource through fracking. The company argued that their operations would create jobs and boost the local economy, but many residents and environmental activists raised concerns about the potential risks to the environment and public health. In response to the council's decision, IGas expressed disappointment and vowed to explore other options for their energy projects in the region. "While we respect the council's decision, we believe that responsible natural gas exploration can coexist with environmental stewardship," a spokesperson for the company said in a statement. The rejection of IGas's plans in Ellesmere Port reflects a growing trend of local authorities taking a stand against fossil fuel development in the UK. With increasing public awareness of the urgent need to transition to cleaner, renewable energy sources, communities across the country are pushing back against projects that contribute to carbon emissions and exacerbate the climate crisis. Environmental organizations and activists have praised the decision of Cheshire West and Chester Council as a step in the right direction towards a more sustainable energy future. Campaigners are calling for further action to curtail fossil fuel extraction and support the transition to green energy alternatives. As the debate over energy policy and climate action continues to intensify, the rejection of IGas's plans in Ellesmere Port serves as a reminder of the power of local communities to influence decisions that have far-reaching impacts on the environment and society as a whole. With ongoing pressure to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the effects of climate change, the importance of thoughtful, responsible energy planning cannot be overstated.

title: Did Boris Johnson just announce an election without actually doing so?
text: Laura Kuenssberg Political editor @bbclaurak on Twitter He's always said that he really doesn't want to go to the country again. Downing Street is still absolutely adamant that this is still the case, and again with the formality of the words "no plans for an election" stamped on every statement. But in politics, as in life, actions speak louder than words. So when Boris Johnson, the UK's Prime Minister, announced a raft of new policies and funding promises in a speech in Coventry this week, many couldn't help but wonder if an election was on the horizon. After all, in the cut and thrust of British politics, such grand gestures are often seen as a prelude to a snap election. The speech itself was a mix of promises, from increased funding for public services to a renewed focus on fighting crime. There were promises of more police officers on the streets, investment in schools, and improved healthcare services. Johnson spoke with passion and conviction, rallying the crowds and energizing his base. But it was the language he used that caught the attention of political observers. Johnson talked about the need for a "new beginning" and a "fresh start" for the country. He painted a picture of a nation on the cusp of greatness, poised to take on the world and succeed on its own terms. It was the kind of rhetoric that politicians often use when they are gearing up for an election campaign. And then there was the timing of the speech. With Brexit looming on the horizon, and with Johnson's controversial handling of the pandemic still fresh in people's minds, some speculated that he might be looking to capitalize on a surge in popularity. A snap election, many argued, would allow Johnson to solidify his hold on power and secure a strong mandate for his government. Of course, Downing Street has been quick to dismiss such speculation. A spokesperson for the Prime Minister insisted that there are no plans for an election, and that Johnson's focus remains squarely on delivering on his promises to the British people. But the question remains: did Boris Johnson just announce an election without actually doing so? Only time will tell. In the fast-paced world of British politics, anything can happen. And with Brexit, the pandemic, and a host of other challenges looming large, the future is as uncertain as ever. One thing is for sure, though - Boris Johnson's speech in Coventry has certainly got people talking. And in politics, that's often half the battle.

title: Amsterdam copies Cardiff's approach to reducing violence
text: It is adopting a Cardiff University professor's approach which he says has made the Welsh capital safer than similar sized UK cities. The Dutch city is following in the footsteps of Cardiff by implementing a violence reduction program that focuses on early intervention and collaboration between various agencies. Professor Jonathan Shepherd, who pioneered the Cardiff Model, believes that this approach is crucial in reducing violence in cities around the world. The model involves analyzing data on violent incidents to identify patterns and hotspots, as well as addressing the root causes of violence through a multi-agency approach. Amsterdam's decision to adopt the Cardiff Model comes after a rise in violent incidents in the city, particularly among young people. By taking a proactive approach to violence prevention, Amsterdam hopes to decrease the number of violent incidents and create a safer environment for its residents. The Cardiff Model has been proven to be effective in reducing violence in various cities, including Cardiff itself. By focusing on prevention rather than punishment, the model aims to address the underlying factors that lead to violence, such as poverty, inequality, and lack of opportunities.
