The fact that these threats were made on a platform like Twitter, where hate speech and abuse often go unchecked, has highlighted the urgent need for better regulations and enforcement mechanisms to protect individuals from online harassment. Twitter has been criticized in the past for its lax approach to dealing with abusive and threatening behavior on its platform. Despite efforts to improve its reporting and enforcement tools, many users still feel that the platform is not doing enough to combat online harassment and abuse. The recent bomb threats only serve to underscore the seriousness of the issue and the need for more proactive measures to be taken. In response to the escalating situation, Twitter has issued a statement condemning the bomb threats and vowing to work with law enforcement to identify and hold the perpetrators accountable. The company has also reiterated its commitment to maintaining a safe and inclusive online environment for all users, pledging to take swift action against any form of harassment or abuse that violates its community guidelines. Meanwhile, the victims of the bomb threats have spoken out about the trauma they experienced as a result of the threats. Many have expressed their fear and anxiety over their safety and the safety of their colleagues and loved ones. Some have called for stronger legal protections against online harassment and threats, while others have urged social media platforms like Twitter to do more to combat abuse and hate speech on their platforms. As the police investigation into the bomb threats continues, it is clear that more needs to be done to address the issue of online harassment and abuse. The safety and well-being of individuals, especially women, who are often targeted with threats and abuse online, must be prioritized. It is crucial that social media platforms take a more proactive stance against online harassment and work together with law enforcement to ensure that those who engage in threatening behavior are held accountable for their actions.

title: Liberia warlord 'Jungle Jabbah' jailed for 30 years in the US
text: Mohammed Jabbateh, also known as "Jungle Jabbah," has been sentenced to 30 years in prison in the United States. The former Liberian warlord was found guilty of immigration fraud for lying to US authorities in the 1990s about his past involvement with armed groups in Liberia. Jabbateh had falsely claimed that he had never been a member of any armed group. However, evidence presented during the trial revealed that he had in fact been a brutal commander in the United Liberation Movement for Democracy in Liberia (ULIMO) and later in the rebel group ULIMO-K. During his time as a commander, Jabbateh committed numerous atrocities, including murder, rape, and the conscription of child soldiers. Prosecutors described him as a ruthless and merciless warlord who terrorized civilians in Liberia during the country's civil war in the 1990s. Jabbateh arrived in the United States in the late 1990s and settled in Pennsylvania, where he lived quietly for many years. However, in 2016, he was arrested by US authorities and charged with immigration fraud and perjury for lying about his past during his asylum application process. During the trial, several witnesses testified about Jabbateh's brutal actions during the civil war in Liberia. One witness described how Jabbateh had ordered his fighters to kill innocent civilians and to loot their property. Another witness recounted how Jabbateh had personally participated in the murder of women and children. In sentencing Jabbateh to 30 years in prison, the judge emphasized the seriousness of the crimes he had committed and the need to hold him accountable for his actions. The judge also noted the impact of Jabbateh's lies on the US immigration system, which is designed to protect those fleeing violence and persecution. The case of Jungle Jabbah has brought renewed attention to the atrocities committed during Liberia's civil war and the need for justice for the victims. By holding Jabbateh accountable for his crimes, US authorities have sent a powerful message that those who commit war crimes and human rights abuses will not escape justice, no matter where they are. As Jabbateh begins his 30-year sentence, the survivors of his brutal reign of terror can take some solace in knowing that he will never again have the opportunity to harm others. The conviction of Jungle Jabbah is a step towards justice for the victims of Liberia's civil war and a reminder that those who commit atrocities will eventually be held accountable for their actions.

title: Pakistan rules out offensive against Punjab militants
text: By M Ilyas KhanBBC News, Islamabad  His remarks came hours after he told a parliamentary committee that "Punjabi Taliban" were entrenched in southern parts of Punjab. Mr Malik said they were planning to destabilise the country. Few Pakistani officials have publicly acknowledged the presence of militant groups in Punjab, the country's most populous province and the political heartland of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif.  The interior minister's comments have raised concerns about the growing influence of extremist groups in the region. The Punjabi Taliban, an offshoot of the Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan (TTP), have been blamed for a number of high-profile attacks in recent years.  Despite this, Mr Malik ruled out the possibility of launching a military offensive against the militants in Punjab. He stressed the need for a more nuanced approach, highlighting the importance of pursuing political and social solutions to address the root causes of extremism.  The interior minister also emphasized the need for increased cooperation between intelligence agencies and law enforcement bodies in order to effectively combat the threat of terrorism.  While the government's reluctance to take military action against the militants in Punjab may raise some eyebrows, it reflects a broader shift in Pakistan's counterterrorism strategy. In recent years, there has been a growing recognition that the use of force alone is not sufficient to combat extremist ideologies.  Instead, there is a growing emphasis on addressing the underlying grievances that drive individuals to join militant groups in the first place. This includes addressing issues such as poverty, lack of education, and political marginalization.  Mr Malik's comments come at a time when Pakistan is facing increasing pressure from the international community to do more to combat terrorism. The government has been criticized for its perceived lack of action against militant groups, particularly those operating in Punjab.  The interior minister's acknowledgment of the presence of the Punjabi Taliban in the region is a significant step towards addressing this criticism. However, it remains to be seen whether the government will follow through on its commitment to pursue non-military solutions to the problem of extremism in Punjab.  In the meantime, the threat of terrorism continues to loom large in Pakistan, with militant groups operating with relative impunity in various parts of the country. The challenge for the government will be to strike a balance between using force where necessary and addressing the root causes of extremism in order to effectively combat the threat of terrorism.

title: Belfast to host Gradam Ceoil trad music awards until 2021
text: By Robbie Meredith BBC News NI Education Correspondent The announcement was made as the city hosted the awards and concert for the first time in its 21-year history. Sunday night's ceremony was staged at the Waterfront Hall. The decision to host the Gradam Ceoil trad music awards in Belfast until 2021 has been met with excitement and anticipation within the music community. This prestigious event recognizes and celebrates the finest traditional musicians from Ireland and beyond, and Belfast's vibrant music scene is sure to provide the perfect backdrop for the awards. The Waterfront Hall proved to be a fitting venue for the ceremony, with its state-of-the-art facilities and stunning views of the city. The atmosphere was electric as musicians, music enthusiasts, and industry professionals gathered to celebrate the rich tradition of Irish music. One of the highlights of the evening was the live performances from some of the most talented traditional musicians in the country. The music filled the auditorium, transporting the audience to a world of melody and rhythm. From soulful ballads to lively jigs and reels, the performers showcased the diversity and beauty of traditional Irish music. As the awards were handed out to the deserving winners, it was clear that Belfast was the perfect choice to host such a prestigious event. The city's rich musical heritage and welcoming atmosphere make it an ideal destination for music lovers from near and far. The decision to extend Belfast's tenure as the host city for the Gradam Ceoil trad music awards until 2021 is a testament to the city's commitment to supporting and promoting traditional music. With its thriving music scene and passionate community of musicians, Belfast is poised to continue showcasing the best of Irish music to the world. In the coming years, Belfast will have the opportunity to further cement its reputation as a hub for traditional music, attracting artists and audiences from around the globe. The city's cultural landscape will be enriched by the presence of such a prestigious event, as musicians and music lovers come together to celebrate the beauty and power of traditional Irish music. Overall, the decision to host the Gradam Ceoil trad music awards in Belfast until 2021 is a testament to the city's thriving music scene and passionate community of musicians. The future looks bright for Belfast as it continues to showcase the best of traditional Irish music to the world.

title: Tories and SNP clash over wind power support
text: The YouGov poll suggests that a majority of supporters of every party - including Tories - support wind power. But anti-wind farm campaigners arranged a protest outside the Scottish Parliament this morning, accusing the SNP of prioritizing wind power over local communities. The clash between the Tories and the SNP over wind power support has been escalating in recent months. The Conservatives have criticized the SNP's ambitious renewable energy targets, stating that they are unrealistic and will have a detrimental impact on the landscape and local communities. The SNP, on the other hand, has defended its support for wind power, arguing that it is essential to meet climate change targets and transition to a cleaner, more sustainable energy future. First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has reaffirmed her commitment to increasing Scotland's renewable energy capacity, including wind power, in order to reduce carbon emissions and combat climate change. However, the Tories have raised concerns about the impact of large-scale wind farms on rural communities, arguing that they can be visually intrusive and disrupt wildlife habitats. They have also expressed skepticism about the effectiveness of wind power in providing reliable energy supplies, highlighting the intermittency of wind as a power source. The clash between the two parties reflects broader divisions within Scottish society over the future of energy policy. While many Scots are supportive of renewable energy and see wind power as a key part of the country's energy mix, there are also concerns about the potential negative impacts of large-scale wind developments on the landscape and local communities. The debate over wind power support is likely to continue to heat up in the coming months, as the Scottish Government moves forward with its plans to increase renewable energy capacity. Both the Tories and the SNP will need to carefully navigate these tensions and find a balance between supporting renewable energy and addressing the concerns of local communities. In the meantime, anti-wind farm campaigners are likely to keep up their protests and advocacy efforts, seeking to influence government policy and ensure that their voices are heard in the ongoing debate over Scotland's energy future. As the clashes between the Tories and the SNP continue, it remains to be seen how the wind power debate will ultimately play out in Scotland's political landscape.

title: Havelock House: Residents welcome rejection of demolition plans
text: The building, on lower Ormeau Road, was vacated in 2018 ahead of a UTV move to new offices on City Quays. London company Olympian Homes bought it in a bid to redevelop the site into luxury apartments. However, local residents were firmly against the plans, citing the historical significance of Havelock House and its importance to the community. After months of deliberation and intense public pressure, the Belfast City Council recently announced its decision to reject the demolition plans. This news has been met with widespread relief and joy among the residents who have been fighting to preserve the iconic building. Havelock House holds a special place in the hearts of many in Belfast. It has been a central part of the city's broadcasting history, hosting UTV for decades. The building's distinctive design and charming features have made it a beloved landmark in the local area. Local resident, Mary O'Connor, expressed her happiness at the council's decision, stating, "Havelock House is not just a building, it's a symbol of our community. It would have been a tragedy to see it torn down and replaced with generic apartments. I'm thrilled that we can now continue to enjoy its presence for years to come." The rejection of the demolition plans is a win for both history and community spirit. It signals a victory for the residents who banded together to protect their heritage and ensure that future generations can appreciate the legacy of Havelock House. In response to the council's decision, Olympian Homes has indicated that they will now explore alternative options for the site. While their initial plans have been thwarted, there is hope that a compromise can be reached that satisfies both the company's development ambitions and the residents' desire to preserve Havelock House. The battle to save Havelock House has united the local community in a shared goal of protecting their heritage. It has demonstrated the power of collective action and the importance of valuing historical landmarks in the face of rapid urban development. As the future of Havelock House hangs in the balance, one thing is certain - the residents will continue to stand firm in their commitment to preserving this cherished building. The rejection of the demolition plans is a significant step forward in their fight to safeguard the legacy of Havelock House for generations to come.

title: Dog's dinner: DNA clue to how dogs became our friends
text: around 15,000 years ago, some wolves started scavenging for food around human settlements. This led to a mutually beneficial relationship, with the humans providing food scraps and the wolves offering protection and help with hunting. Over time, these wild wolf populations began to evolve into the friendly and loyal dogs we know today. A recent study, published in the journal "Nature," analyzed the genomes of ancient dogs and wolves to uncover the genetic changes that allowed dogs to adapt to a diet rich in starches. The researchers found differences in key genes related to the digestion of starches, particularly the gene AMY2B, which encodes an enzyme that breaks down starch into sugars. The study suggests that dogs developed a genetic adaptation to digest starches more efficiently than wolves, allowing them to thrive on the scraps of food provided by early farmers. This ability to digest starches may have played a crucial role in the domestication of dogs, as it allowed them to better utilize the resources available in human settlements. Dr. Erik Axelsson, co-author of the study from Uppsala University in Sweden, explains, "The ability to digest starches probably made it easier for dogs to make use of food that would otherwise have been wasted. It may have been a key factor in enabling dogs to form bonds with humans and become our companions." The findings also shed light on the unique evolutionary history of dogs, which sets them apart from their wild relatives, the wolves. While wolves are primarily carnivorous and have a diet high in protein and fat, dogs have evolved to thrive on a more varied diet that includes grains and vegetables. This study adds to the growing body of evidence that dogs have undergone significant genetic changes since their domestication, adapting to life alongside humans in ways that have shaped their behavior, appearance, and dietary preferences. By studying the genetic differences between dogs and wolves, researchers are gaining new insights into the complex and fascinating process of domestication. Understanding the genetic changes that have occurred in dogs over thousands of years can not only provide insights into their evolution but also help us appreciate the special bond that exists between humans and their canine companions. As we continue to uncover the secrets of dog domestication, we gain a deeper appreciation for the history and partnership that has shaped our relationship with man's best friend.

title: South East hospitals charged £1.5m for ambulance delays
text: Patient handovers should not take longer than 15 minutes. Hospitals are charged £2.44 for each extra minute. Jonathan Fox, from the Association of Professional Ambulance Personnel, said delays kept crews from responding to other emergency calls, putting lives at risk. South East hospitals have been charged a total of £1.5m for ambulance delays in the past year. These delays occur when ambulance crews arrive at hospitals to hand over patients but are forced to wait due to a lack of available beds or staff shortages. The issue of ambulance delays has been a long-standing problem for hospitals in the South East. The high charges imposed by the government are aimed at incentivizing hospitals to improve their handover processes and reduce delays. However, despite these financial penalties, delays continue to persist, putting strain on ambulance crews and impacting patient care. Ambulance crews are often left waiting for extended periods of time, sometimes hours, before they are able to hand over their patients to hospital staff. This not only affects the ability of crews to respond to other emergency calls but also contributes to a backlog of ambulances waiting outside hospitals, further exacerbating the problem. The £1.5m in charges levied on South East hospitals for ambulance delays is a stark reminder of the urgent need for reform in the way patient handovers are managed. The current system is inefficient and unsustainable, leading to increased pressure on both ambulance crews and hospital staff. In response to these challenges, Jonathan Fox has called for greater collaboration between hospitals and ambulance services to improve handover processes and reduce delays. He emphasizes the importance of effective communication and coordination between the two services to ensure that patients are transferred quickly and efficiently. The impact of ambulance delays on patient care cannot be understated. Every minute counts in an emergency situation, and delays in handovers can have serious consequences for patients requiring urgent medical attention. It is imperative that hospitals in the South East take action to address this issue and prioritize timely patient handovers. As the government continues to monitor and enforce penalties for ambulance delays, it is hoped that hospitals will be motivated to make the necessary changes to improve their handover processes. The health and safety of patients depend on swift and efficient care, and addressing the issue of ambulance delays is crucial in ensuring that those in need receive the timely assistance they require.

title: Fire-hit Harrington Junior School to be rebuilt on site
text: Harrington Junior School, in Long Eaton, Derbyshire, was gutted in the blaze on 28 May, started accidentally during refurbishment work. No children were on site when the fire broke out, and firefighters worked tirelessly to bring the inferno under control. The devastating fire left the school community in shock, as they watched their beloved school reduced to ashes. The school building, which dated back to the 1930s, held countless memories for both students and staff alike. For many, it was more than just a place of learning – it was a second home. In the days following the fire, the local community rallied together to support the school in any way they could. Donations poured in from businesses, residents, and former students, all eager to help in the school's time of need. The outpouring of support was a testament to the strong bonds that had been formed within the community over the years. As the smoke cleared and the extent of the damage became apparent, discussions began about the future of Harrington Junior School. While the loss was immense, there was a collective determination to rebuild and restore the school to its former glory. After careful consideration, it was decided that the school would be rebuilt on the same site. The decision was made not only for practical reasons but also as a symbol of resilience and renewal. The new school would rise from the ashes, a phoenix emerging from the fire, stronger and more resilient than ever before. Plans for the new school are already underway, with architects and builders working tirelessly to design a modern, state-of-the-art facility that will meet the needs of students and staff for years to come. The new Harrington Junior School will be a testament to the strength and determination of the community, a beacon of hope in the face of adversity. While the road ahead may be long and challenging, the school community remains united in their commitment to rebuilding their beloved school. The new Harrington Junior School will not only be a place of learning but a symbol of hope and resilience in the face of adversity. As the rebuilding process continues, the school community looks forward to the day when they can once again welcome students through the doors of their new school. Until then, they will continue to stand together, supporting one another and working towards a brighter future for all. The flames may have consumed the old Harrington Junior School, but they have not extinguished the spirit and determination of those who call it home.

title: New Brexit referendum would be 'divisive and hate-filled' warns Hague
text: The former foreign secretary warned of the risk of a "hate-filled" campaign if the government attempted to revisit the issue and tell people "they were wrong" when voting to leave in 2016. He said he would rather see politicians focus on finding a way to implement the result of the original referendum and move forward as a united nation. Lord Hague, who supported the Remain campaign during the 2016 referendum, acknowledged that there are strong feelings on both sides of the Brexit debate. He cautioned that holding another referendum could further divide the country and fuel animosity between supporters and opponents of Brexit. In a recent op-ed for a national newspaper, Lord Hague expressed his concerns about the potential consequences of a new Brexit referendum. He argued that such a campaign would be filled with "bile and bitterness" and could lead to lasting scars on the social fabric of the UK. While acknowledging the challenges of implementing Brexit, Lord Hague urged politicians to work together to find a solution that respects the will of the British people while also addressing the concerns of those who voted to remain in the EU. He emphasized the importance of compromise and unity in the face of a deeply divisive issue like Brexit. Lord Hague's warning comes amid ongoing debates within the UK government about the best way to move forward with Brexit. Prime Minister Boris Johnson has repeatedly stated his commitment to delivering Brexit by the October 31 deadline, with or without a deal. Some politicians have called for a second referendum as a way to break the deadlock in Parliament and allow the British public to have a say on the final Brexit deal. However, others, including Lord Hague, have raised concerns about the potential consequences of such a move. As the Brexit deadline looms large, the UK remains deeply divided over the issue of leaving the EU. The government faces the difficult task of finding a way to honor the result of the original referendum while also maintaining unity and stability within the country. Lord Hague's warning serves as a reminder of the challenges ahead and the need for politicians to approach the issue of Brexit with caution and foresight. As the debate continues to unfold, the UK must navigate the complexities of Brexit with care and consideration for the future of the nation.

title: MSPs back Scottish smacking ban proposals
text: A bill lodged by Green MSP John Finnie is designed to give children the same protection from assault as adults. MSPs voted overwhelmingly in favor of the proposal, with 84 members backing the bill and only 29 opposing it.  The bill seeks to ban the physical punishment of children in all circumstances, removing the legal defense of "justifiable assault" currently in place in Scotland. This move is in line with a growing consensus among child welfare and human rights organizations that physical discipline is harmful and ineffective.  Supporters of the ban argue that hitting children not only violates their rights but also fails to teach them appropriate behavior. They point to research showing that physical punishment can lead to aggression, antisocial behavior, and mental health problems in children.  However, opponents of the ban argue that it interferes with parents' rights to discipline their children as they see fit. They claim that a total ban on physical punishment could criminalize well-meaning parents and overburden social services with unnecessary interventions.  The bill now moves on to the next stage of the legislative process, where it will be subject to further scrutiny and debate. If passed, Scotland would become the first part of the UK to outlaw physical punishment of children.  The proposal has garnered significant public support, with a recent poll showing that 71% of Scots are in favor of the ban. Many parents, teachers, and child welfare experts have voiced their approval of the move, citing the need to protect children's rights and promote positive parenting practices.  Green MSP John Finnie, who has championed the bill, hailed the vote as a historic moment for children's rights in Scotland. He emphasized the importance of providing children with the same legal protections from assault as adults, arguing that no one should be above the law when it comes to physical violence.  The Scottish government has also expressed support for the proposed ban, with First Minister Nicola Sturgeon voicing her belief that children should be protected from all forms of violence. She praised the bill as a crucial step towards creating a safer and more respectful society for children in Scotland.  As the debate continues on the future of child discipline in Scotland, the passage of this bill marks a significant milestone in the ongoing efforts to promote children's rights and welfare in the country. It remains to be seen how the ban will be enforced and what impact it will have on parenting practices and child well-being in Scotland.

title: Algerian army 'kills jihadist behind Herve Gourdel beheading'
text: Abdelmalek Gouri and two associates were shot dead late on Monday in the town of Isser, a statement said. His group, Jund al-Khilafah, claimed responsibility for the beheading of French tourist Herve Gourdel in September 2014. The Algerian army launched a major operation targeting the group in the mountains of Kabylie, located east of the capital Algiers. The operation resulted in the deaths of Gouri and his associates, who were believed to be the masterminds behind the brutal killing of Gourdel. The beheading of Herve Gourdel shocked the world and raised concerns about the growing influence of jihadist groups in Algeria. Gourdel, a 55-year-old mountaineer, was abducted while hiking in the mountains of Kabylie and was later executed by Jund al-Khilafah in a gruesome video that was posted online. The Algerian government condemned the killing of Gourdel and vowed to bring the perpetrators to justice. The operation that led to the deaths of Gouri and his associates was seen as a major victory for the Algerian security forces in their fight against terrorism. Gouri, also known as Khaled Abu Sultan, was a veteran jihadist who had been involved in militant activities for years. He was believed to have close ties to Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) and was known for his extremist views and brutal tactics. The Algerian army has been engaged in a long-running battle against jihadist groups operating in the country, particularly in the remote and mountainous regions of Kabylie. The region has been a stronghold for several militant factions, including AQIM, which has carried out numerous attacks against security forces and civilians in the past. The death of Gouri and his associates is a significant blow to Jund al-Khilafah and a major setback for the jihadist movement in Algeria. It is hoped that their elimination will help to weaken the group's capabilities and disrupt its activities in the region. The Algerian government has reiterated its commitment to combating terrorism and maintaining security and stability in the country. The successful operation against Gouri and his associates is a testament to the determination and effectiveness of the Algerian security forces in tackling the threat posed by extremist groups. The killing of Abdelmalek Gouri and his associates marks a significant milestone in the fight against terrorism in Algeria. It is a reminder of the ongoing challenges faced by the country in confronting the menace of jihadist violence and the importance of sustained efforts to counter extremism and safeguard the lives of innocent civilians.

title: Wage inequality lowest in Wales, says ONS figures
text: worker, according to the latest figures from the Office for National Statistics (ONS). The data revealed that wage inequality in Wales is at its lowest since 2003, with the top 1% earning an average of £85,760 a year, compared to just £11,648 for the bottom 1%. This disparity is significantly smaller than the national average, where the top 1% earn around £75 per hour, eight times the average wage of the bottom 1%. Despite this positive trend, many experts believe that more needs to be done to address wage inequality in Wales. Dr. Rhys Davies, an economist at Cardiff University, stressed the importance of implementing policies that promote fair wages and reduce income disparities. "There is still a long way to go in terms of achieving true wage equality in Wales. While it's encouraging to see a decrease in wage inequality, we must continue to push for policies that address the root causes of income disparities," said Dr. Davies. One of the key factors contributing to wage inequality in Wales is the prevalence of low-paying jobs in certain industries, such as hospitality and retail. Workers in these sectors often struggle to make ends meet, despite working long hours. Sara Jones, a retail worker in Cardiff, shared her experience of trying to survive on a minimum wage salary. "I work full-time in a supermarket, but my hourly wage is just above the minimum wage. It's challenging to pay bills and afford basic necessities with such a low income," said Jones. In addition to addressing low wages in specific industries, experts also recommend increasing investment in education and training programs to help workers acquire the skills needed for higher-paying jobs. By equipping individuals with the necessary tools to succeed in the workforce, we can help reduce wage inequality and create a more prosperous society. The ONS figures also revealed a gender pay gap in Wales, with women earning an average of 18.4% less than men. This disparity highlights the ongoing challenges faced by women in the workforce and underscores the need for policies that promote gender equality in the workplace. Overall, while wage inequality in Wales has improved in recent years, there is still work to be done to ensure that all workers receive fair compensation for their contributions. By implementing targeted policies and initiatives, we can create a more equitable and inclusive economy for all residents of Wales.

title: Birmingham voters reject elected mayor plan
text: the elected mayor plan as well, including Manchester, Leeds, and Sheffield. The results are a blow to the government's efforts to devolve more power to local authorities, as elected mayors were seen as a way to provide strong, accountable leadership in major cities across England. The campaign against an elected mayor in Birmingham was led by local politicians and community groups who argued that the current system of council leadership, with a council leader elected by fellow councillors, was working well and did not need to be changed. Opponents of the elected mayor plan raised concerns about the potential for one individual to have too much power and influence in the city, arguing that decisions should be made collectively by elected representatives rather than by a single mayor. Supporters of the elected mayor plan, on the other hand, pointed to the success of elected mayors in other cities such as London and Bristol, where mayors have been able to drive forward ambitious agendas for economic growth, infrastructure development, and social integration. Despite the defeat of the elected mayor plan in Birmingham, there are still elected mayors in a number of cities across England, including Bristol, Liverpool, and London. These mayors have been able to implement significant changes and improvements in their cities, leading to increased investment, improved public services, and greater community engagement. The rejection of the elected mayor plan in Birmingham highlights the diversity of opinions and preferences among voters in different cities, as well as the need for local authorities to engage with their communities and listen to their concerns. The government has indicated that it will respect the results of the referendums and work with local authorities to ensure that the devolution agenda continues to move forward, even in the absence of elected mayors. This may involve providing additional resources and powers to local councils, as well as exploring alternative models of governance that can deliver effective and accountable leadership at the city level. Despite the setback in Birmingham, the government remains committed to devolving powers and responsibilities to local authorities as part of its broader agenda to strengthen democracy, promote economic growth, and enhance public services across England. The outcome of the mayoral referendums will undoubtedly shape the future direction of governance in cities across the country, as politicians and voters continue to debate the best way to deliver effective and responsive leadership in the 21st century.

title: Covid: Highest weekly deaths in Wales since pandemic began
text: the total number of deaths in Wales since the start of the pandemic. The latest figures from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) demonstrate the devastating impact that Covid-19 continues to have on the country. Despite the ongoing efforts to curb the spread of the virus through lockdown measures and vaccinations, the number of deaths in Wales has been steadily increasing. The 467 deaths recorded in the week ending 15 January marked the highest weekly death toll since the start of the pandemic. Health officials have warned that the coming weeks may see even higher numbers of deaths as the new variant of the virus spreads rapidly across the country. The increase in deaths has put additional strain on hospitals and healthcare systems, with many struggling to cope with the influx of patients. The Welsh government has urged people to continue following Covid-19 guidelines, including wearing masks, practicing social distancing, and staying at home as much as possible. The rollout of vaccines has provided hope for many, but officials stress that it will take time to vaccinate enough of the population to achieve herd immunity. In addition to the rising death toll, Wales is also facing significant challenges in terms of hospital admissions and intensive care unit capacity. Hospitals are now operating at near capacity, with many healthcare workers stretched to their limits. The situation has prompted calls for additional support and resources to help alleviate the strain on healthcare systems. The impact of the pandemic extends beyond just the physical health effects of the virus. Mental health issues, economic hardship, and social isolation have all contributed to the overall toll on society. The Welsh government has implemented various measures to address these challenges, including funding for mental health services and support for businesses affected by the pandemic. Despite the grim statistics, there is hope that the worst of the pandemic may soon be behind us. Vaccination efforts are ramping up, with thousands of people receiving their first doses every day. As more and more people are vaccinated, there is optimism that life may soon return to some semblance of normalcy. In the meantime, it is crucial for everyone to continue following public health guidelines and doing their part to slow the spread of the virus. By working together and supporting one another, we can overcome this crisis and emerge stronger on the other side.

title: Belarus: Journalists covering protests stripped of accreditation
text: Two journalists with the BBC's Russian service are among those affected. In a statement, the BBC said it condemned "in the strongest possible terms this stifling of independent journalism." The situation in Belarus has been deteriorating rapidly in recent weeks, with widespread protests against President Alexander Lukashenko erupting following the disputed election in August. Journalists have been targeted by authorities, with many facing harassment, intimidation, and even violence. The stripping of accreditation from journalists is just the latest in a series of actions taken by the Belarusian government to crack down on independent media. This move not only deprives journalists of their ability to report freely on the ground but also sends a chilling message to others in the media that their work could be next. The BBC has long been a proponent of independent journalism and has a history of standing up for press freedom around the world. The organization has called on the Belarusian authorities to reverse this decision and allow journalists to report on the events unfolding in the country without fear of reprisal. Despite the challenges faced by journalists in Belarus, many continue to bravely report on the protests and the crackdown by authorities. Their determination to shine a light on what is happening in the country is a testament to the importance of a free and independent press in holding those in power to account. The international community has also voiced its concern over the situation in Belarus, with the European Union imposing sanctions on individuals responsible for the crackdown on protesters and journalists. The United Nations has called for an investigation into reports of human rights abuses in the country, including the targeting of journalists. As the situation in Belarus continues to unfold, it is crucial that journalists be allowed to do their work freely and without fear of reprisal. The BBC and other media organizations will continue to monitor the situation closely and report on events as they happen, in an effort to ensure that the truth is not silenced in Belarus. In the face of adversity, journalists in Belarus are standing up for the principles of press freedom and democracy. Their courage and dedication to their profession are an inspiration to us all, and it is essential that they be allowed to continue their important work without interference. The world is watching, and we stand in solidarity with the journalists in Belarus who are fighting for the right to report on the truth.

title: Coronavirus: Over 300 patients refuse ambulance over Covid-19 fears
text: Toby Lewis, chief executive of Sandwell and West Birmingham NHS Trust, said hospitals are now "much clearer" about how to manage the infection. The trust has seen a significant increase in the number of patients refusing ambulance services due to fears of contracting Covid-19. Lewis stated that over 300 patients have refused ambulance transportation to hospitals in the past few months, citing concerns about the virus. This trend is a worrying development as it could potentially lead to delays in treatment for those in need of urgent medical attention. The fear and uncertainty surrounding the coronavirus pandemic have had a significant impact on how people perceive healthcare services. Many individuals are choosing to stay at home and avoid seeking medical help out of fear of being exposed to the virus in hospitals. However, Lewis emphasized that hospitals have implemented strict infection control measures to protect both patients and staff from the spread of Covid-19. He assured the public that hospitals are safe places to receive medical care and encouraged individuals not to delay seeking help when they need it. In light of the increasing number of patients refusing ambulance services, healthcare professionals are urging the public to trust in the healthcare system and seek medical assistance as needed. Delaying treatment for serious health conditions could have severe consequences and potentially worsen the outcome for patients. The pandemic has highlighted the importance of maintaining trust in the healthcare system and not allowing fear to prevent individuals from seeking necessary medical care. It is crucial for people to understand that hospitals are well-equipped to handle Covid-19 patients while also providing care for other medical conditions. Healthcare professionals are working tirelessly to ensure the safety of patients and staff in hospital settings. By following recommended guidelines and adhering to infection control measures, hospitals are able to offer the necessary medical care to those in need while minimizing the risk of spreading the virus. As the fight against Covid-19 continues, it is essential for the public to have confidence in the healthcare system and not let fear dictate their decisions regarding seeking medical treatment. By working together and trusting in the expertise of healthcare professionals, we can overcome the challenges posed by the pandemic and ensure the well-being of all individuals in need of medical assistance.

title: Hadiza Bawa-Garba: Suspension 'was correct decision'
text: Dr Hadiza Bawa-Garba was struck off due to mistakes in the care of Jack Adcock, six, after a criminal trial. The suspended pediatrician, who had been convicted of gross negligence manslaughter, has now spoken out to defend the decision to remove her from the medical register. In a recent interview, Dr Bawa-Garba stated that she believes her suspension was a correct decision, as she takes full responsibility for the errors that led to the tragic death of Jack Adcock. She acknowledged that her actions on the day in question were not excusable, and that she failed in her duty to provide the proper care for her patient. The case of Jack Adcock, who died of sepsis in 2011 under Dr Bawa-Garba's care, sparked a national debate about the pressures faced by healthcare professionals in the NHS. The court heard that the doctor had made several mistakes in the treatment of the young boy, including failing to correctly diagnose his condition and not reviewing his test results in a timely manner. Despite the controversy surrounding her case, Dr Bawa-Garba has remained resolute in her belief that she should not be allowed to practice medicine following the tragic outcome of Jack Adcock's treatment. She has expressed deep remorse for her actions and has accepted the consequences of her mistakes. Following her suspension, Dr Bawa-Garba has been actively involved in promoting patient safety and advocating for improvements in the healthcare system. She has spoken at numerous conferences and events, sharing her own experiences and highlighting the importance of learning from medical errors to prevent future tragedies. While some have called for Dr Bawa-Garba to be reinstated, arguing that she has shown considerable remorse and dedication to improving patient care, others believe that her removal from the medical register was the correct decision. The General Medical Council, which oversees the licensing of doctors in the UK, has defended its decision to strike off the suspended pediatrician, citing the seriousness of the charges against her and the need to maintain public trust in the medical profession. In the wake of the controversy surrounding Dr Bawa-Garba's case, there has been increased focus on the issue of doctor accountability and the need for systemic changes to prevent similar incidents from occurring in the future. It is a complex and challenging issue that raises important questions about the pressures faced by healthcare professionals, the importance of learning from mistakes, and the need for a culture of openness and transparency in healthcare.

title: EasyJet hopes to reopen 75% of route network by August
text: served onboard. Passengers will also be encouraged to use hand sanitizer and observe social distancing measures while on the aircraft. EasyJet is taking a cautious approach to resuming operations, ensuring the safety and well-being of both passengers and staff are the top priority. The airline is closely monitoring the evolving situation of the pandemic and is ready to adapt its plans accordingly. CEO of EasyJet, Johan Lundgren, expressed optimism about gradually reopening the route network by August. He emphasized that the airline is committed to providing a safe and reliable service for passengers who need to travel during these challenging times. The aviation industry has been hit hard by the pandemic, with many airlines facing financial struggles and implementing cost-cutting measures such as job cuts and fleet reductions. EasyJet, like many other airlines, has had to make some tough decisions to stay afloat in these unprecedented times. Despite the challenges, EasyJet remains hopeful for the future and believes that air travel will eventually bounce back. The airline is working closely with health authorities and regulatory bodies to ensure that its operations comply with the necessary health and safety guidelines. Customers who have been eagerly waiting to travel again can now look forward to the prospect of flying with EasyJet in the near future. The airline is gradually resuming services on select routes, with more destinations expected to be added as travel restrictions ease. As the world slowly begins to recover from the effects of the pandemic, EasyJet is committed to playing its part in helping aviation return to normalcy. The airline is well-positioned to capitalize on the pent-up demand for travel once the situation improves and hopes to regain the trust and confidence of passengers who may have been hesitant to fly in recent months. In conclusion, EasyJet's plans to reopen 75% of its route network by August is a significant step towards rebuilding the airline's operations in the post-pandemic world. With a focus on safety and customer satisfaction, EasyJet aims to emerge stronger from this crisis and continue to provide affordable and reliable air travel services for passengers worldwide.

title: Why we need internet jokes and memes more than ever
text: By Will ChalkNewsbeat reporter But how closely are the two linked and what does that say about our mindsets, the internet and our society? Yeah. We're living in a time where the world can feel like a pretty heavy place. Between political turmoil, global crises, and everyday stresses, it's easy to feel overwhelmed. That's where internet jokes and memes come in. They offer a much-needed escape from the chaos of the world, providing moments of levity and laughter in the midst of it all. In a way, they serve as a form of digital therapy, giving us a brief respite from the weight of reality. But it's not just about escapism. Internet jokes and memes also have a way of bringing people together. In a world that can often feel divided, they have the power to unite us through shared laughter and common experiences. Whether it's a viral video that everyone is talking about or a hilarious meme that captures a universal sentiment, these internet phenomena have a way of transcending boundaries and bringing people closer. Moreover, internet jokes and memes can serve as a powerful form of social commentary. They have a unique ability to satirize and critique the world around us, shining a light on absurdities and injustices in a way that is both humorous and thought-provoking. From political memes that skewer politicians to viral videos that challenge social norms, these digital creations have the power to spark important conversations and inspire change. In a time when disinformation and polarization run rampant, internet jokes and memes also play a crucial role in combating falsehoods and promoting critical thinking. By using humor and irony to expose the flaws in misinformation and propaganda, they help us become more discerning consumers of information and challenge us to think more critically about the world around us. But perhaps most importantly, internet jokes and memes remind us of the power of laughter. In a world that can often feel dark and bleak, they offer moments of joy and amusement that are essential for our mental health and well-being. Laughter has been shown to reduce stress, boost mood, and strengthen social connections, making it an invaluable tool for navigating the challenges of life. So, the next time you find yourself scrolling through your social media feed and come across a hilarious meme or joke, take a moment to appreciate the power of humor in our lives. In a world that can feel overwhelming and chaotic, internet jokes and memes are more than just a form of entertainment – they are a vital source of connection, commentary, and comfort in a digital age.

title: Belfast floods: Response to ordeal comes under fire
text: Regional Development Minister Danny Kennedy said the "flood line did not perform as it should have". The flood incident line is a vital resource used by residents in Belfast to report flooding incidents and receive assistance during emergencies. However, during the recent floods that hit the city, many residents expressed frustration over the lack of response and support from the authorities. Several residents took to social media to share their experiences, detailing how they called the flood line for help but received no response. Some even reported being stuck in their homes with rising water levels, feeling abandoned and helpless. This lack of support during a time of crisis has sparked outrage among the community and raised serious questions about the effectiveness of the flood response system in Belfast. In response to the criticism, Minister Kennedy acknowledged the shortcomings of the flood line system and promised to investigate the issue. He stated that improvements would be made to ensure that residents receive the help they need during emergencies. However, many are skeptical of these promises and are calling for concrete actions to be taken to prevent a similar situation from happening in the future. The flooding in Belfast has also raised concerns about the city's infrastructure and preparedness for extreme weather events. With climate change leading to more frequent and severe storms, it is essential that cities like Belfast have robust systems in place to deal with flooding and protect residents. The recent floods have exposed weaknesses in the city's drainage system and highlighted the urgent need for investments in infrastructure upgrades. Local officials have been urged to take proactive measures to prevent future flooding, such as improving drainage systems, building flood defenses, and implementing better communication strategies during emergencies. The community is demanding greater transparency and accountability from the authorities to ensure that such a crisis does not happen again. As the cleanup efforts continue in the aftermath of the floods, residents are hoping for swift action from the government to address the issues highlighted by this ordeal. The response to the flooding in Belfast has come under fire, but it serves as a wake-up call for the city to strengthen its resilience and protect its residents from the impact of extreme weather events in the future. Only time will tell if the authorities will follow through on their promises and make necessary changes to prevent a similar crisis from occurring again.

title: Big Bang Theory scoops Critics' Choice TV Awards
text: The show was named best comedy series, while its stars Simon Helberg and Kaley Cuoco were named best supporting actor and actress respectively. There was a tie for best drama, with the hit series "Breaking Bad" and "The Good Wife" sharing the honours. "The Big Bang Theory" has been a fan favourite since it first aired in 2007, with its quirky characters and clever writing earning it critical acclaim as well. The show, which follows a group of socially awkward scientists and their interactions with their more socially adept neighbour, has been praised for its humour and heartwarming moments. Simon Helberg, who plays the lovable Howard Wolowitz on the show, was overjoyed at receiving the award for best supporting actor. "It's such an honour to be recognized by the Critics' Choice TV Awards," Helberg said. "I'm grateful to all the fans who have supported us over the years and to the incredible cast and crew who make this show possible." Kaley Cuoco, who plays the charming and quirky Penny, was equally thrilled to win the award for best supporting actress. "I'm so grateful for this award and for the opportunity to play such a fun and dynamic character on 'The Big Bang Theory'," Cuoco said. "I couldn't be happier." As for the tie for best drama, "Breaking Bad" and "The Good Wife" both took home the top prize, showcasing the diversity and talent in the world of television. "Breaking Bad," which follows the transformation of a high school teacher into a ruthless drug kingpin, has been praised for its gripping storytelling and intense performances. On the other hand, "The Good Wife" is a legal drama that follows the life of Alicia Florrick, played by Julianna Margulies, as she navigates the challenges of working as a lawyer while dealing with personal and professional issues. The show has been praised for its strong female lead and complex storytelling. Overall, the Critics' Choice TV Awards highlighted the best and brightest in television, with "The Big Bang Theory" taking home top honours in the comedy category, and "Breaking Bad" and "The Good Wife" sharing the spotlight in the drama category. The awards show serves as a reminder of the talent and creativity present in the television industry, and the incredible work being done by television writers, actors, and producers.

title: Police inquiry over white-tailed eagle nest claim
text: The alleged discovery of a white-tailed eagle nest in the east of Scotland has sparked a police inquiry into potential wildlife crimes. Conservationists are claiming that this is the first known nest made by white-tailed eagles in this region in approximately 150 years, making it a significant finding for the local ecosystem. The white-tailed eagle, also known as the sea eagle, is one of Britain's largest birds of prey and was once widespread across the UK. However, due to habitat loss and persecution, their numbers declined drastically, leading to their extinction in many parts of the country, including the east of Scotland. The potential revival of the white-tailed eagle population in this region is a cause for celebration among conservationists, who have worked tirelessly to reintroduce these magnificent birds back into the wild. The species was successfully reintroduced to the west coast of Scotland in the 1970s, where they have since thrived and become a symbol of conservation success. The discovery of a nest in the east of Scotland is seen as a positive sign of the eagles' continued expansion and colonization of new territories. However, concerns have been raised about the potential threats they may face from human activities, such as disturbance, illegal persecution, and habitat destruction. Police have been called in to investigate the circumstances surrounding the alleged white-tailed eagle nest, including the possibility of any criminal activities that may have taken place. Wildlife crimes are taken very seriously in Scotland, with strict laws in place to protect endangered species and their habitats. Conservationists are hopeful that the police inquiry will shed light on the true nature of the situation and help ensure the safety and protection of the white-tailed eagles in this region. The birds are a vital part of the local ecosystem and play a crucial role in maintaining the balance of the environment. As the police investigation continues, wildlife experts and conservationists are working together to monitor the nest and ensure the well-being of the white-tailed eagle pair. Efforts are also being made to raise awareness about the importance of protecting these magnificent birds and their habitats, in the hopes of securing a brighter future for them in the east of Scotland. The discovery of the white-tailed eagle nest has reignited hope for the species' comeback in the region, and with the support of local communities and authorities, conservationists are optimistic about the eagles' prospects for the future. The police inquiry is a crucial step in safeguarding these majestic birds and preserving their place in the natural world.

title: Census 2020: US adds controversial citizenship question
text: government enforce the Voting Rights Act. Critics argue that the citizenship question is a thinly veiled attempt by the Trump administration to intimidate immigrants and minorities from participating in the census, which could lead to an undercount in states with large immigrant populations. This, in turn, could result in those states losing out on federal funding and representation in Congress. The controversy surrounding the citizenship question has taken center stage as the Census Bureau gears up for the 2020 survey. The last time a citizenship question was included on the census was in 1950, and many argue that adding it back now is unnecessary and harmful. The issue has also sparked a wider debate about the politicization of the census and the importance of ensuring an accurate count of the population. Census data is used to allocate federal funding, determine the number of seats each state has in the House of Representatives, and draw legislative districts. An undercount could have far-reaching consequences for the political and financial future of the country. Despite the legal challenges and controversy surrounding the citizenship question, the Trump administration remains steadfast in its decision to include it in the 2020 census. In response to the lawsuits filed by the states, the Justice Department has argued that the question is necessary to enforce the Voting Rights Act and protect the rights of US citizens. The outcome of the legal battles over the citizenship question remains uncertain, but one thing is clear: the debate over the 2020 census has become a battleground for issues of immigration, voting rights, and political power. As the census approaches, it will be crucial for the government, advocacy groups, and the public to work together to ensure an accurate and inclusive count of the US population. In the midst of the controversy and uncertainty surrounding the citizenship question, one thing is certain: the stakes for the 2020 census are higher than ever. The outcome of the legal battles and political debates will have far-reaching consequences for the future of the country, as well as for the millions of people who call the United States home. The 2020 census is shaping up to be a pivotal moment in American history, and how it unfolds will have a lasting impact on the nation as a whole.

title: No cause of death for Eric Garner after New York arrest
text: Eric Garner, 43, was forcibly detained on suspicion of selling untaxed cigarettes on Thursday. Video of the incident shows Garner complain he couldn't breathe as a police officer held him in a chokehold on the ground. Garner's repeated cries of "I can't breathe" became a rallying cry for protesters seeking justice for his death. Garner's death in 2014 sparked nationwide outrage and protests against police brutality. The officer involved in his arrest, Daniel Pantaleo, was not charged with Garner's death, and a grand jury declined to indict him. The lack of accountability in Garner's case highlighted the systemic issues of racism and excessive use of force within law enforcement. Now, nearly seven years after Garner's death, the New York City medical examiner's office has announced that there is no specific cause of death for Garner. The official autopsy report states that the manner of death was "undetermined," raising questions about the lack of accountability and transparency in the investigation into Garner's death. Garner's family and supporters have been demanding justice for years, calling for Pantaleo and other officers involved in the incident to be held accountable for their actions. The news of the inconclusive autopsy results has only reignited calls for justice and accountability in Garner's case. The lack of a clear cause of death for Garner raises concerns about the thoroughness of the investigation and the handling of the case by law enforcement officials. Garner's family has expressed frustration and disappointment with the lack of closure and accountability in their quest for justice. Despite the lack of a definitive cause of death, the medical examiner's report did note that Garner's death was caused by "compression of the neck (chokehold), compression of chest and prone positioning during physical restraint by police." These findings support the claims made by Garner and his family that the police officer's use of excessive force contributed to his death. The inconclusive autopsy results for Eric Garner serve as a grim reminder of the ongoing challenges faced by victims of police brutality and their families in seeking justice and accountability. The fight for justice for Garner continues, with activists and supporters vowing to keep his memory alive and to hold those responsible for his death accountable. The lack of closure in Garner's case underscores the urgent need for police reform and accountability to prevent future tragedies like his from occurring.

title: Health regulator problems 'persist'
text: CQC was "not yet a credible and authoritative regulator" in 2012, and recent reports suggest little has changed.  The regulator, responsible for inspecting and rating health and social care services in England, has faced a series of controversies and criticisms over the years. From allegations of cover-ups to concerns about its lack of independence, the CQC has struggled to gain the trust of both the public and healthcare providers. One of the main issues that continue to plague the CQC is its approach to inspection and enforcement. Critics argue that the regulator is often too lenient on poorly performing services, allowing them to slip through the cracks without proper intervention. This has raised concerns about the safety and quality of care provided to patients, particularly in vulnerable settings such as nursing homes and mental health facilities. In addition to its inspection practices, the CQC has also been criticized for its slow response to complaints and concerns raised by the public. Many individuals have reported feeling ignored or dismissed by the regulator when attempting to raise issues about the care they or their loved ones have received. This lack of transparency and accountability has further eroded the CQC's credibility in the eyes of the public. Furthermore, allegations of a culture of fear and secrecy within the CQC have cast a shadow over the organization's ability to effectively regulate health and social care services. Reports of staff feeling pressured to prioritize positive ratings over accurate assessments have called into question the integrity of the regulator's inspection process. Despite numerous attempts at reform and restructuring, the CQC continues to struggle with persistent challenges that undermine its effectiveness as a regulatory body. Calls for greater accountability, transparency, and independence have echoed throughout the healthcare sector, urging the government to take decisive action to address the ongoing issues within the CQC. As the need for strong, reliable regulation of health and social care services grows increasingly urgent, the future of the CQC remains uncertain. Without significant reforms and improvements to its approach, the regulator risks further erosion of public trust and confidence in its ability to ensure the safety and quality of care provided to individuals across England. Only time will tell if the CQC can overcome its persistent problems and emerge as a credible and authoritative regulator in the years to come.

title: Royal Cornwall Hospital 'neglected' woman who died in A&E
text: Katy Lowry, 30, who had chromosomal abnormalities and learning difficulties, was taken to Royal Cornwall Hospital on 13 December 2016. She had been vomiting every 15 minutes for nearly 24 hours. Coroner Andrew Cox told an inquest that Katy's death was "wholly avoidable" and that she had suffered neglect while in the care of the hospital. During the inquest, it was revealed that Katy had a history of medical issues, including a seizure disorder. Despite her medical history, she was left waiting in A&E for over four hours before she was seen by a doctor. She was then given anti-sickness medication, but her condition continued to deteriorate. The inquest heard that doctors failed to take Katy's vital signs or provide her with the appropriate level of care. She was left alone in a cubicle for several hours without any monitoring or supervision. It was only when a nurse finally checked on her that Katy was found unresponsive and not breathing. Katy's family expressed their shock and anger at the level of care she received at Royal Cornwall Hospital. Her mother, Sarah Lowry, said that Katy was a vulnerable person who had been let down by the very people who were supposed to care for her. In response to the coroner's findings, the hospital issued a statement expressing its condolences to Katy's family and acknowledging the failures in her care. The hospital stated that changes had been made to prevent a similar tragedy from occurring in the future. The inquest into Katy's death highlighted the importance of providing appropriate care for vulnerable individuals, especially those with complex medical needs. It raised questions about the level of training and support available to healthcare professionals who work with patients like Katy. The tragic case of Katy Lowry serves as a reminder of the need for better communication, coordination, and oversight within the healthcare system. The coroner's findings underscore the importance of ensuring that all patients, regardless of their medical history or vulnerabilities, are treated with the dignity, respect, and compassion they deserve. As the inquest concluded, Katy's family called for accountability and justice for their beloved daughter and sister. They hope that her death will lead to meaningful changes in the way vulnerable patients are cared for in hospitals across the country. The memory of Katy Lowry will live on as a beacon of hope for a healthcare system that prioritizes the well-being of all patients, no matter their circumstances.

title: Brexit: France warns UK of bitter trade negotiations
text: French Foreign Minister Jean-Yves Le Drian predicted the two sides would "rip each other apart" as they strove for advantage in the negotiations. He also said it would be tough. The warning comes as the deadline for the UK to leave the EU approaches, with both sides scrambling to secure the best possible deal. The UK has been pushing for a comprehensive trade agreement that would allow for relatively smooth trade between the two entities, while the EU has been pushing for a more restrictive deal that would protect its own interests. Le Drian's comments highlight the challenges ahead for both sides, as they seek to negotiate a post-Brexit relationship that works for all parties involved. With so much at stake, tensions are running high, and the negotiations are expected to be anything but easy. One of the key sticking points in the negotiations is likely to be the issue of access to the EU single market. The UK has been keen to maintain as much access as possible, in order to continue trading with its largest export market. However, the EU has been clear that it will not allow the UK to have the same level of access as before, as it seeks to protect its own interests and prevent the UK from gaining an unfair advantage. Another key issue is likely to be the future of the UK's financial services industry. The UK is home to one of the largest financial services industries in the world, and it is crucial for the UK economy that it maintains access to the EU market. However, the EU has been resistant to granting the UK the same level of access as before, as it seeks to prevent the UK from becoming a financial hub that could undermine the stability of the EU's financial markets. Despite these challenges, both sides have expressed a willingness to work towards a deal that benefits all parties involved. However, with time running out and tensions running high, the negotiations are likely to be long and difficult. As Le Drian warned, the two sides are unlikely to come to an agreement without a fight. In conclusion, the road ahead for the UK and the EU is likely to be a bumpy one, as they seek to navigate the complexities of Brexit and forge a new relationship that works for both parties. With so much at stake, the negotiations are sure to be tense and challenging. Only time will tell whether the two sides can come to an agreement that satisfies both parties and allows for a smooth transition post-Brexit.

title: Shakespeare's skull 'probably stolen' from Stratford grave
text: The discovery gives credence to a news report in 1879, later dismissed as fiction, that trophy hunters took the skull from his shallow grave in 1794. A team used a ground-penetrating radar (GPR) scan to look beneath the surface of the grave in the Holy Trinity Church in Stratford-upon-Avon, where the renowned playwright William Shakespeare was laid to rest in 1616. The shocking revelation has raised concerns among scholars and historians alike, as the missing skull could unlock new mysteries about Shakespeare's life and death. The church's vicar, Reverend Dr. Paul Edmondson, expressed his astonishment at the findings. "To think that someone would desecrate Shakespeare's final resting place in such a manner is truly appalling. We must do everything in our power to uncover the truth behind this heinous act," he said. With the support of the Church of England and local authorities, a full investigation has been launched to determine the extent of the theft and identify the perpetrators. The police have been called in to assist with the case, and forensic experts are analyzing the GPR data for any clues that may lead to the recovery of Shakespeare's missing skull. Meanwhile, historians have been poring over archives and historical records to piece together the events surrounding the alleged theft of Shakespeare's skull. Some believe that the playwright's remains were targeted by grave robbers seeking to sell his skull as a macabre souvenir, while others speculate that it may have been taken for more nefarious purposes. Dr. Emily Carroll, a Shakespearean scholar at the University of Oxford, is leading the research efforts to unravel the mystery. "The theft of Shakespeare's skull is a crime against literature and history. We owe it to his memory to find out what happened and ensure that his remains are laid to rest with dignity and respect," she stated. As the investigation continues, experts are considering the possibility of conducting a DNA analysis on any skeletal remains found within the grave to confirm their identity as Shakespeare's. This groundbreaking technique could provide conclusive evidence of whether the missing skull belongs to the playwright, shedding new light on his final days and the circumstances surrounding his death. The Shakespearean community is rallying together to support the authorities in their quest to recover the stolen skull and bring closure to this disturbing chapter in literary history. The search for Shakespeare's missing remains continues, as the world watches with bated breath to see if the truth will finally be uncovered.

title: Edinburgh trams: Leith Walk may be hit by 18 months of disruption
text: The closure of three lanes on Leith Walk would begin when construction on the £165.2m project, if approved, gets under way in the upcoming months. The controversial extension of the Edinburgh tram line to Newhaven has faced opposition from residents, businesses, and local politicians who fear the disruption it will cause to the busy Leith Walk thoroughfare. The proposed tram extension would see the line run from York Place in the city centre to Newhaven, a waterfront area in the north of Edinburgh. The project aims to improve public transport connections and stimulate economic development in the area, but concerns have been raised about the impact on local businesses and residents during the construction phase. City of Edinburgh Council has announced plans to close three lanes on Leith Walk to accommodate the construction work, which is expected to take up to 18 months to complete. This would mean significant disruption for commuters, pedestrians, and cyclists who use the busy route on a daily basis. Local residents have expressed their frustration with the potential disruption, with many voicing concerns about the impact on local businesses and the safety of pedestrians and cyclists. Some fear that the closure of three lanes on Leith Walk will lead to increased traffic congestion and delays for commuters travelling to and from the city centre. Business owners along Leith Walk have also raised concerns about the impact of the tram extension on their livelihoods. Many fear that the construction work will deter customers from visiting their shops and restaurants, leading to a drop in footfall and a loss of income. Despite the opposition, City of Edinburgh Council has defended the project, saying that the long-term benefits of the tram extension outweigh the short-term disruption. They argue that improved public transport links will make it easier for people to access the city centre and help to reduce congestion on the roads. The decision on whether to proceed with the tram extension is expected to be made later this year, following a consultation with local residents and businesses. In the meantime, the closure of three lanes on Leith Walk is set to go ahead as planned, with construction work due to begin in the coming months. As the debate rages on, residents, businesses, and local politicians will be watching closely to see how the project unfolds and what impact it will have on the Leith Walk community. Only time will tell whether the controversial tram extension will be a success or a source of ongoing frustration for those who use this bustling thoroughfare.

title: US warned Sri Lanka about Iran - wikileaks
text: The revelations published by the Telegraph newspaper in London on Tuesday say the US Embassy in Colombo had expressed its concerns about Sri Lanka's relationship with Iran. According to leaked diplomatic cables from WikiLeaks, the US warned Sri Lanka that its growing ties with Iran could have serious consequences for its international reputation and diplomatic relations. The cables reveal that US officials were particularly worried about Sri Lanka's military cooperation with Iran, including weapons deals and joint training exercises. The US Embassy in Colombo reportedly raised these concerns with top Sri Lankan officials, urging them to reconsider their close alignment with Tehran. The warning from the US came at a time when the international community was increasingly focused on Iran's nuclear program and its support for militant groups in the Middle East. The US, along with many of its allies, had been pressuring countries around the world to distance themselves from Iran and impose sanctions on the regime. Sri Lanka's response to the US warning is not entirely clear from the leaked cables, but it is likely that the government in Colombo took the concerns seriously. Sri Lanka, which relies heavily on international support and investment, would not want to jeopardize its relationships with key allies like the US and risk being isolated on the world stage. The leaked cables also shed light on the complex web of international relations in the region, with Sri Lanka navigating a delicate balancing act between the US, China, and India. While the US was warning Sri Lanka about its ties with Iran, China was simultaneously deepening its own relationship with the island nation, investing heavily in infrastructure projects and providing military assistance. The revelations from WikiLeaks have sparked a debate in Sri Lanka about the country's foreign policy choices and the implications of its alliances. Some analysts argue that Sri Lanka should heed the warnings from the US and distance itself from Iran to avoid being caught in the crossfire of international tensions. Others, however, believe that Sri Lanka has the sovereign right to pursue its own foreign policy objectives and should not be dictated to by external powers. They argue that the country's relationship with Iran is based on mutual interests and should not be sacrificed for the sake of appeasing the US or other Western nations. As the diplomatic fallout from the WikiLeaks cables continues to unfold, Sri Lanka finds itself at a critical juncture in its foreign relations. The country will need to carefully weigh its options and navigate the complex geopolitical landscape to ensure its own national interests are protected.

title: Stone Roses film ‘has band’s blessing’
text: By Kev Geoghegan Entertainment reporter, BBC News, in Cannes The film is part of a slate of projects announced by BBC Films in Cannes. It tells the story of a gang of young teenagers who try to make their mark on the music scene in Manchester during the late 1980s.
