The mural, titled "Lost in Time", depicts a hauntingly beautiful landscape of crumbling buildings and overgrown foliage, with hints of vibrant color peeking through the decay. It is a reflection of Bayliss's fascination with abandoned spaces and the passage of time. Another striking work in the exhibition is a series of intricate sculptures made from found objects and recycled materials. These sculptures, with their detailed craftsmanship and thought-provoking symbolism, invite viewers to contemplate the beauty of everyday objects and the stories they can tell. Bayliss's use of digital art in the exhibition is also noteworthy. His digital pieces, created using a combination of photography, graphic design, and animation, offer a unique perspective on the intersection of technology and art. One particular piece, titled "Virtual Reality", explores the concept of virtual worlds and the role they play in shaping our perceptions of reality. Overall, "Reflections of the Past" is a testament to Bayliss's talent and vision as an artist. His ability to blend traditional techniques with modern innovation results in a collection that is both visually stunning and intellectually stimulating. The exhibition is a must-see for art enthusiasts and connoisseurs alike. Reflecting on his debut exhibition, Bayliss said, "I am thrilled to have the opportunity to showcase my work at Ipswich Art School. This place holds a special significance for me, as it is where I honed my craft and developed my artistic voice. I hope that visitors to the exhibition will find something that resonates with them and leaves a lasting impression." "Reflections of the Past" will be on display at the Ipswich Art School until the end of the month, giving art lovers plenty of time to experience Bayliss's captivating creations in person. Don't miss this chance to witness the debut of a rising star in the art world.

title: Glan Clwyd Hospital: Disciplinary action promised by Jones
text: Carwyn Jones was speaking as it emerged the health minister's statement on the Tawel Fan scandal had been withdrawn. Instead ministers will back a call from the Conservatives for a debate on failings. The scandal surrounding the treatment of patients at Glan Clwyd Hospital has sent shockwaves through the Welsh healthcare system. Families of the victims have been left devastated, with many feeling let down by the very institution meant to care for their loved ones. In a press conference this morning, Carwyn Jones, the First Minister of Wales, announced that disciplinary action would be taken against those responsible for the mistreatment of patients at Tawel Fan ward. He stated, "This behavior is unacceptable and will not be tolerated within our healthcare system. Those found to be at fault will face the consequences of their actions." Jones went on to express his regret over the handling of the situation, admitting that mistakes were made and promising that steps would be taken to prevent such incidents from occurring in the future. He acknowledged the pain and suffering experienced by the families affected, offering his heartfelt apologies on behalf of the government. The Tawel Fan scandal has brought to light the need for greater oversight and accountability within the Welsh healthcare system. Calls for a full inquiry into the failings at Glan Clwyd Hospital have been growing louder, with many demanding answers and justice for the victims and their families. In response to these demands, the government has pledged to support a debate on the failings at Tawel Fan ward, as proposed by the Conservative party. Ministers have vowed to work together with opposition members to uncover the truth behind the mistreatment of patients and ensure that those responsible are held accountable. The public outcry over the Tawel Fan scandal has prompted a reevaluation of hospital policies and procedures, with a focus on improving the quality of care provided to patients. The government has committed to implementing reforms that will address the root causes of the mistreatment at Glan Clwyd Hospital and prevent similar incidents from happening in the future. As investigations continue and disciplinary actions are taken, the Welsh healthcare system is at a crossroads. The Tawel Fan scandal has exposed deep-seated issues within the system that must be addressed promptly and effectively. With the government's promise of decisive action and reform, there is hope that justice will be served and the victims of this tragedy will finally receive the closure they deserve.

title: Alstom: GE and French state agree to work on new offer
text: France's economy minister Arnaud Montebourg said that neither the GE bid, nor a joint Siemens-Mitsubishi Heavy Industries offer, met the government's demands. But the government had chosen to work on a new GE bid that could potentially secure backing from state-owned investors. The decision to collaborate with GE on a revised offer comes after weeks of intense negotiations and pressure from labor unions and politicians to keep the French engineering company in national hands. Alstom, which has a strong presence in the rail and energy sectors, is a key player in the country's industrial landscape. Montebourg emphasized that any deal involving Alstom must protect French jobs and strategic interests. He also stressed the importance of maintaining the company's technological expertise and preserving its capabilities in research and development. The government is aiming to ensure that Alstom remains a competitive and innovative force in the global market. The proposed partnership with GE could involve the creation of joint ventures in key areas such as energy and transportation. This collaboration could enable Alstom to benefit from GE's resources and expertise while allowing the company to retain its identity and autonomy. While negotiations are ongoing, both the French government and GE have expressed optimism about the potential for a successful partnership. If the revised bid meets the government's criteria and gains approval, it could pave the way for a new chapter in Alstom's history. The outcome of these discussions is being closely watched by stakeholders in France and abroad. The fate of Alstom will have implications for the country's economy and industrial policy, as well as for the broader European manufacturing sector. Alstom is facing pressure from global competition and changing market dynamics. The company has been seeking a partnership that will enable it to navigate these challenges and continue to grow and innovate. As negotiations progress, all parties involved are working to find a solution that will benefit Alstom, its employees, and the French economy as a whole. The next steps will be crucial in determining the future of this iconic French company. In the coming weeks, the French government will continue to engage with GE and other stakeholders to finalize the details of the proposed partnership. The decision on Alstom's future will have far-reaching consequences, and all parties are committed to reaching an agreement that will ensure the company's continued success and competitiveness.

title: Covid: New lockdown needed, say Yorkshire leaders
text: Schools in England have shut to most pupils and people have been asked to stay at home under tighter rules. Dan Jarvis, Mayor of the Sheffield City Region, has called for a new lockdown in Yorkshire amid rising Covid-19 cases. Jarvis, who also serves as the Labour MP for Barnsley Central, has urged the government to take swift action to prevent the spread of the virus. He emphasized the need for a unified approach across Yorkshire to tackle the growing number of infections. The Mayor's plea comes as hospitals in the region are reportedly under increasing pressure, with a surge in admissions due to the highly transmissible Omicron variant. Yorkshire leaders have warned that the healthcare system is at risk of becoming overwhelmed if decisive action is not taken. In a statement, Jarvis stressed the importance of putting public health first and protecting the most vulnerable members of society. He highlighted the need for a comprehensive response that includes increased testing and vaccination efforts, as well as support for businesses and individuals affected by the restrictions. Other leaders in Yorkshire have echoed Jarvis's calls for a new lockdown, citing the need to curb the rapid spread of the virus. Dr. Debbie Chase, Director of Public Health for Leeds, emphasized the importance of taking proactive measures to prevent further strain on the healthcare system. Local authorities across Yorkshire have been working closely with the government to devise a strategy to combat the latest wave of infections. Measures such as mass testing, vaccination drives, and support for those self-isolating have been implemented to slow the spread of the virus. However, some experts have cautioned that a new lockdown may not be the only solution to the current crisis. Dr. Sarah Jenkins, a public health specialist based in Yorkshire, suggested that a targeted approach focusing on high-risk areas and populations could be more effective in controlling the virus. As the situation continues to evolve rapidly, it remains to be seen whether the government will heed calls for a new lockdown in Yorkshire. With cases rising across the country and hospitals struggling to cope, decisive action is needed to protect public health and prevent further transmission of the virus. In the meantime, Yorkshire residents are being urged to follow public health guidelines, including wearing masks, practicing social distancing, and getting vaccinated. The coming weeks will be crucial in determining the trajectory of the pandemic in the region and the effectiveness of the measures taken to curb its impact.

title: Bloodhound takes first drive across the desert
text: land speed record next year. The car - which has taken a decade to develop - was driven on the Hakskeen Pan, a dry lakebed in South Africa that will be the site of its high-speed runs. Green said: "It was an extraordinary day. The highlight was just how phenomenally quickly the car accelerated. It's not just the quickest I've been in this car, it's the quickest I've been in anything. We eased past 100mph (160km/h) using just a third of the track. "And the stability, the tracking on the car was fantastic. I felt confident about its straight-line stability. We are going to be doing at least another 20 runs over the next month or so, each time pushing the speed up higher and higher so that by the time we finish, we'll both be ready for the high-speed runs." The Bloodhound team is aiming to break the current land speed record of 763mph (1,228km/h) held by Green himself, achieved in 1997 in the Thrust SuperSonic car. The ultimate ambition is to reach speeds of over 1,000mph (1,609km/h). Martin Davidson, Bloodhound's engineering director, said: "We are just scratching the surface. Everybody is working incredibly hard, and it's a massive, massive thing. This is next-level engineering. It's a huge reward for all the effort that has gone in.” The Bloodhound project has faced significant financial struggles in recent years, with the team almost having to abort the whole endeavor due to lack of funding. However, a new investor stepped in to ensure the project could continue, much to the relief of everyone involved. The car is powered by a Rolls-Royce EJ200 jet engine, normally found in a Eurofighter Typhoon. This engine is used to accelerate the car to its target speed of around 1,000mph, at which point a rocket will be ignited to push it even faster. Speaking about the car's capabilities, Green said: "We've got a pilot seat that almost encases you in the cockpit. We've got all the switches we need, all the indicators - it's a really nice place to be. And then to control it, we've got this air brake on the top, which is going to keep the car firmly on the ground." The team will continue testing the car over the coming weeks, with the aim of reaching ever higher speeds in preparation for the record attempt next year. The technical challenges ahead are significant, but everyone involved is confident that they have what it takes to succeed.

title: Farm profits may halve after Brexit, says report
text: The report, by the Agriculture & Horticulture Development Board (AHDB), says the "worst-case scenario" would cut average farm profits from £38,000 a year to just £15,000. The analysis tries to model the effects of cheaper imported agricultural products flooding the UK market after Brexit.  One of the key factors contributing to this potential decline in farm profits is the predicted increase in competition from cheaper imports. The report suggests that without the EU protections and regulations in place, British farmers could struggle to compete with cheaper goods from countries with lower production costs. This could lead to a decrease in demand for domestic produce, ultimately impacting farm profits. Furthermore, the report highlights the uncertainty surrounding future trade deals post-Brexit. If the UK fails to secure favorable trade agreements with key trading partners, such as the EU, British farmers could face significant barriers when exporting their goods. This could further impact farm profits, as farmers may lose access to important markets and be forced to sell their produce at lower prices domestically. The report also points to potential changes in subsidy payments post-Brexit as a factor that could contribute to the decrease in farm profits. Currently, British farmers receive substantial subsidies from the EU under the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP). However, once the UK leaves the EU, these subsidies may not be guaranteed, leading to a loss of income for farmers. In response to these challenges, the report suggests that British farmers need to adapt to the changing landscape post-Brexit. This may involve diversifying their income streams, increasing efficiency through technology, and focusing on niche markets where they have a competitive advantage. Additionally, the report recommends that the government provide support to farmers during this transition period to help mitigate the potential impact on farm profits. Overall, the report paints a bleak picture for the future of British farming post-Brexit, with significant challenges ahead that could halve farm profits. It underscores the need for farmers to be proactive in adapting to these changes and for the government to provide the necessary support to ensure the sustainability of the industry. Only time will tell how British farmers will navigate the uncertainties of a post-Brexit world and whether they will be able to weather the storm ahead.

title: Covid: Will Margaret Ferrier remain an MP after breaking rules?
text: By Nick Eardley BBC political correspondent Ms Ferrier has been suspended by her party and she has faced criticism across the political spectrum, with the Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross saying her actions were "utterly indefensible". The SNP has also condemned her behaviour, calling it "completely unacceptable". The decision on whether Margaret Ferrier will remain as an MP ultimately lies with her constituents in Rutherglen and Hamilton West. Many are shocked and dismayed by her actions, which have put lives at risk and undermined efforts to combat the spread of Covid-19. In a statement, Ms Ferrier admitted that she had travelled to London after experiencing Covid symptoms and then took a train back to Scotland after testing positive for the virus. This reckless behaviour has rightly caused outrage and there are growing calls for her to resign as an MP. However, Ms Ferrier has so far resisted these calls, issuing a public apology and expressing remorse for her actions. She has also promised to work with the authorities and fully cooperate with any investigations into her conduct. The question now is whether Margaret Ferrier can salvage her political career and regain the trust of her constituents. Some argue that she has shown a lack of judgment and disregard for the rules, making it impossible for her to continue as an MP. Others believe that she should be given a second chance, particularly if she is willing to learn from her mistakes and take responsibility for her actions. Whatever the outcome, this incident highlights the importance of politicians leading by example and following the rules that they expect others to abide by. Covid-19 is a serious public health crisis that requires everyone to act responsibly and do their part to stop the spread of the virus. In the coming days and weeks, the focus will be on whether Margaret Ferrier can rebuild her reputation and restore confidence in her ability to represent her constituents effectively. The actions she takes now will determine whether she can continue to serve as an MP or whether she will be forced to step down in the face of mounting pressure.

title: UKIP make their mark in Scotland
text: Brian TaylorPolitical editor, Scotland So, quite deliberately, I grabbed the chance today to offer my congratulations to each of Scotland's elected MEPs among the throng gathered in Edinburgh City Chambers for the final declaration. And commiseration to those who lost. But what caught my attention the most was the resounding success of the UK Independence Party (UKIP) in Scotland. While they have been a dominant force in England, their success in Scotland is significant. With one MEP elected, UKIP has now made its mark in the Scottish political landscape. Their success can be attributed to several factors. One of the main reasons is undoubtedly the anti-EU sentiment that has been growing in Scotland. The debate over Scottish independence has reignited discussions on the country's relationship with the European Union. Many Scots are disillusioned with the EU and see UKIP as a party that will stand up for their interests. Additionally, UKIP's leader, Nigel Farage, has been a prominent figure in Scottish politics in recent months. His charismatic personality and straight-talking approach have resonated with many voters who feel that the traditional parties have become disconnected from the concerns of ordinary people. UKIP's success in Scotland has not gone unnoticed by the other political parties. The SNP, Labour, and the Conservatives are all taking note of the rise of this new political force. They know that they will need to adapt their policies and strategies if they want to compete with UKIP in future elections. But UKIP's success in Scotland also presents challenges for the party. They will need to prove that they can deliver on their promises and represent the interests of all Scottish voters, not just a select few. They will need to show that they can work constructively with other parties in the European Parliament to achieve their objectives. As UKIP prepares to take its place in the European Parliament, all eyes will be on their performance. The party will face scrutiny and criticism from all sides, but they have shown that they are ready for the challenge. In conclusion, UKIP's success in Scotland is a sign of the changing political landscape in the country. They have proven that they can appeal to a broad range of voters and have established themselves as a force to be reckoned with. The coming months will be crucial for UKIP as they navigate the challenges of governing and try to build on their success in future elections. And with that, the stage is set for a new chapter in Scottish politics. The rise of UKIP will undoubtedly shake up the status quo and force the other parties to adapt or risk being left behind. Scotland's political future has never been more uncertain, but one thing is clear: UKIP has made its mark.

title: Zero waste society plans for Scotland unveiled
text: Environment Secretary Richard Lochhead said it was time to tackle nearly 20m tonnes of waste currently produced by Scotland every year. The zero waste plan includes tough new recycling and landfill targets to reduce the impact of waste on the environment and move towards a more sustainable future. Under the plan, households and businesses will be required to separate their waste into different categories for recycling. This will help to increase recycling rates and reduce the amount of waste that ends up in landfill sites. Additionally, the government will be investing in new technology and infrastructure to improve waste management systems and make recycling more accessible for everyone. Lochhead emphasized the importance of changing behaviors and attitudes towards waste. "We need to shift towards a circular economy where resources are used efficiently and waste is minimized," he said. "By implementing these new measures, we can create a more sustainable society and protect our environment for future generations." The zero waste plan also includes initiatives to reduce food waste, which currently accounts for a significant portion of Scotland's overall waste. The government will be working with businesses and consumers to find innovative solutions to prevent food waste and divert surplus food to those in need. In addition to reducing waste, the plan aims to create new opportunities for recycling and reusing materials. This includes promoting the use of recycled materials in manufacturing processes and encouraging the development of new markets for recycled goods. By closing the loop on waste, Scotland can create a more circular economy that reduces the need for raw materials and minimizes the impact on the environment. The Scottish government has set ambitious targets to achieve zero waste by 2045, with the ultimate goal of creating a truly sustainable society. This will require a collective effort from government, businesses, and individuals to change the way we think about waste and take action to reduce our impact on the planet. Lochhead concluded by highlighting the benefits of moving towards a zero waste society. "By investing in sustainable waste management practices, we can create new jobs, reduce carbon emissions, and protect our natural resources for future generations," he said. "It's time to embrace a new way of living that prioritizes the health of our planet and fosters a more sustainable future for all."

title: Views sought on new ideas to further regenerate Cardiff
text: The proposals have been outlined in a consultation which splits the city into five areas for different types of development. Replacing the Motorpoint Arena along with other key sites, the plan seeks to revitalize Cardiff and bring new life to the Welsh capital.  One of the key ideas being considered is the construction of a new state-of-the-art concert and events venue, which would replace the current Motorpoint Arena. This new facility would not only provide a modern space for concerts and shows, but also create new opportunities for economic growth in the city.  In addition to the new concert venue, the consultation also includes plans for the development of new residential areas, office spaces, and recreational facilities in different parts of Cardiff. This holistic approach aims to create a more vibrant and diverse city, where residents and visitors alike can enjoy a range of amenities and activities. One area that has generated particular interest is the proposal to build a new waterfront promenade along Cardiff Bay. This project would transform the currently underutilized waterfront into a bustling hub of shops, restaurants, and entertainment venues, drawing in both locals and tourists to enjoy the stunning views of the bay. Furthermore, the consultation seeks to address the issue of affordable housing in the city by proposing the development of new residential neighborhoods with a mix of housing options, including affordable units. This move aims to ensure that Cardiff remains an inclusive and accessible city for people of all income levels. Overall, the proposals put forward in the consultation represent an ambitious vision for the future of Cardiff, with a focus on sustainability, accessibility, and innovation. By seeking input from the public on these ideas, city planners hope to create a consensus on how best to move forward with the regeneration of the city and ensure that Cardiff continues to thrive in the years to come. As the consultation period continues, residents, business owners, and community members are encouraged to provide their feedback on the proposed ideas. This input will be crucial in shaping the final plans for the regeneration of Cardiff, ensuring that the city remains a vibrant and dynamic place for all who call it home.  In conclusion, the consultation on new ideas to further regenerate Cardiff represents an exciting opportunity for the city to evolve and grow in a sustainable and inclusive way. With the support of the community, Cardiff has the potential to become a shining example of urban regeneration and innovation in the years to come.

title: Kashmir uproar over Afzal Guru clemency plea
text: By Mehboob Khan BBC News A resolution had been tabled on the case of Afzal Guru, who was convicted over the 2001 India parliament attack. Sheikh Rashid, the independent who brought the resolution, said the state's leadership had done "great injustice" by not pushing for clemency for Guru. The uproar over a potential clemency plea for Afzal Guru has sparked protests and violence in Kashmir. Many in the region see Guru as a symbol of resistance against Indian rule, and any move to grant him clemency is seen as a betrayal by the Indian government. The resolution brought by Sheikh Rashid has reignited long-standing tensions in Kashmir, a disputed region between India and Pakistan. The government of India has maintained that Guru was involved in the attack on the parliament and was rightly convicted. However, many in Kashmir believe that Guru did not receive a fair trial and that his conviction was politically motivated. They argue that he should be granted clemency on humanitarian grounds, especially since he has already spent over a decade in prison. The Kashmiri people are deeply divided on the issue, with some supporting Guru and his cause for independence, while others feel that the Indian government's stance is justified. The region has been the site of ongoing conflict for decades, with both India and Pakistan claiming Kashmir as their own. The latest developments have only served to inflame tensions further, with protests erupting in Srinagar and other parts of Kashmir. Demonstrators have clashed with security forces, leading to injuries on both sides. The Indian government has condemned the protests, calling them a threat to peace and stability in the region. Security forces have been deployed to quell the unrest, but the situation remains volatile. As the debate over Afzal Guru's clemency plea continues to escalate, it is clear that Kashmir remains a deeply contentious issue. The region's complex history and political dynamics make any resolution a challenging and delicate task. For now, the people of Kashmir are left to grapple with the aftermath of the resolution brought by Sheikh Rashid, unsure of what the future holds for Afzal Guru and the region as a whole. The only certainty is that the tensions in Kashmir are far from over, and the struggle for independence and justice will continue to define the region for the foreseeable future.

title: Robin Gibb: Bee Gees singer's funeral held in Thame
text: Hundreds of fans lined the streets of Thame earlier as a lone bagpiper led a procession through the town. Gibb's body was carried in a horse-drawn carriage, followed by two Irish wolfhounds. The somber atmosphere was palpable as the mourners paid their respects to the iconic Bee Gees singer. The procession made its way to St Mary's Church, where friends, family, and fans gathered to say their final goodbyes to Robin Gibb. The church was filled to capacity, with many more outside listening to the emotional service through speakers. Inside the church, Gibb's bandmate and brother, Barry Gibb, delivered a heartfelt eulogy for his beloved brother. He reminisced about their childhood, their rise to stardom, and the unbreakable bond they shared as brothers and bandmates. Barry Gibb's words resonated with the crowd, many of whom were moved to tears as they remembered the music and legacy of the Bee Gees. The church was filled with the sound of their classic hits, played by a live band in tribute to Robin Gibb. After the service, the procession made its way to the private burial site where Robin Gibb was laid to rest. The touching ceremony was attended by close family and friends, who paid their final respects to the beloved singer. Fans from around the world also paid tribute to Robin Gibb, sharing their memories and favorite songs on social media. The outpouring of love and support was a testament to the impact that Gibb and the Bee Gees had on the music industry and their devoted fanbase. Robin Gibb's funeral was a fitting tribute to a legendary singer and songwriter. His music will live on in the hearts of fans around the world, and his legacy will continue to inspire future generations of musicians. As the sun set on Thame, the town was filled with the sound of music as fans gathered to celebrate the life of Robin Gibb. The Bee Gees's music played from speakers, echoing through the streets as a final goodbye to a true music icon. The funeral may have marked the end of Robin Gibb's life, but his spirit and music will live on forever in the hearts of those who loved him. The legacy of the Bee Gees will continue to shine brightly, a testament to the talent and passion of Robin Gibb and his brothers.

title: More than one in 10 providing unpaid care
text: region, with 1 in 9 people in Wales reporting that they were unpaid carers. The figures reveal a growing trend in the UK, with more than one in 10 people providing unpaid care to family members or friends. The demands of caring for a loved one can be overwhelming, particularly for those who are providing care for 50 hours or more a week. Despite the challenges, many unpaid carers continue to sacrifice their time and energy to support those in need. The importance of their contribution to society cannot be overstated. In addition to the physical and emotional toll that caring for a loved one can take, unpaid carers often face financial struggles as well. Many have to juggle their caregiving responsibilities with work, leading to financial strain and added stress. The impact of this can be significant, affecting not only the carer but also the person they are caring for. The findings from the 2011 data highlight the valuable role that unpaid carers play in our society. Their dedication and selflessness should be recognized and supported by the government and the wider community. Initiatives such as respite care, financial assistance, and emotional support can go a long way in helping unpaid carers balance their responsibilities and maintain their own well-being. As the population ages and the demand for care increases, it is crucial that we address the needs of unpaid carers and provide them with the resources they need to carry out their vital role. By investing in support services and raising awareness of the challenges faced by unpaid carers, we can ensure that they are able to continue providing high-quality care to those who need it most. It is important for society as a whole to recognize and appreciate the invaluable contribution of unpaid carers. Their dedication and commitment should not go unnoticed, and steps should be taken to ensure that they receive the recognition and support they deserve. By prioritizing the well-being of unpaid carers, we can create a more compassionate and caring society for all.

title: Lover jailed for Swanwick car boot murder
text: Paula Poolton, 40, of Titchfield, Fareham, was found near Swanwick rail station, Hampshire, on 28 October 2008, 11 days after she went missing. At the Royal Courts of Justice in London Roger Kearney, 57, of Sarisbury, was sentenced to life in prison for her murder. The court heard how Kearney, who was Paula's former lover, had lured her to a remote location under the pretense of reconciling their relationship. However, once they arrived at the secluded spot, Kearney attacked Paula, strangling her to death before disposing of her body in the boot of a car. During the trial, it was revealed that Kearney had a history of violence towards women, with multiple restraining orders taken out against him by previous partners. Paula's family expressed their disbelief and devastation at the betrayal by someone she once trusted. Detective Inspector Mark Wadmore, who led the investigation, described Paula's murder as a "senseless and brutal crime". He praised the work of the police team in piecing together the evidence that led to Kearney's arrest and subsequent conviction. The case sent shockwaves through the local community, with many expressing their disbelief that such a heinous crime could occur in their quiet town. Residents held vigils in memory of Paula, a beloved member of the community known for her kindness and generosity. During sentencing, the judge emphasized the gravity of Kearney's actions, pointing out the deliberate and calculated nature of the crime. He noted that Kearney had shown no remorse for his actions and posed a continued danger to society. As Kearney was led out of the courtroom to begin his life sentence, Paula's family embraced each other, finding solace in the justice that had been served. While nothing could bring back their beloved Paula, they hoped that her tragic death would serve as a stark reminder of the dangers of domestic violence and the importance of speaking out against abuse. In the aftermath of the trial, local authorities pledged to increase support services for victims of domestic abuse, aiming to prevent future tragedies like Paula's murder. The community came together to mourn her loss and honor her memory, vowing to never forget the vibrant woman who had been taken too soon. As the sun set over Swanwick, a quiet sense of closure settled over the town, tinged with sorrow for the loss of one of their own. Paula Poolton may have been taken from them, but her spirit lived on in the hearts of those who loved her, a beacon of hope in the darkness of tragedy.

title: Stormont deal: what are thorny issues for NI politicians?
text: By John CampbellBBC News NI Economics Editor Talks aimed at resolving the political deadlock continue at Stormont. The talks are focusing on welfare reform, finance, and a range of other thorny issues that have divided politicians in Northern Ireland for years. Welfare reform has been a key sticking point in negotiations, with parties at odds over how best to implement changes to the benefits system. The issue has been particularly contentious because of concerns about the impact on vulnerable individuals and families in the region. The parties have been grappling with how to strike a balance between cutting costs and protecting those who rely on benefits to make ends meet. Finance is another major issue on the agenda, with parties debating how to address the significant financial challenges facing Northern Ireland. The region has been grappling with a range of economic issues, including a large budget deficit and slow economic growth. Politicians are under pressure to find ways to boost the economy and create more jobs, while also tackling the fiscal challenges facing the region. Other thorny issues on the table include the legacy of the Troubles, with parties struggling to find a way to deal with the past in a sensitive and inclusive manner. The issue of how to address the impact of decades of conflict on communities in Northern Ireland has proven to be a difficult and divisive issue for politicians to navigate. Social issues, such as marriage equality and abortion rights, are also on the agenda, with parties at odds over how to best address these sensitive and deeply entrenched issues. The region has lagged behind the rest of the UK in terms of progress on social issues, and there is pressure on politicians to find a way forward that respects the rights and values of all members of society. Overall, the talks at Stormont are focusing on finding common ground on a range of difficult and complex issues that have divided politicians in Northern Ireland for years. The stakes are high, with the future of devolved government in the region hanging in the balance. The coming days and weeks will be crucial in determining whether a breakthrough can be achieved and a deal struck. Politicians will need to show courage, creativity, and compromise in order to bridge the gaps on these thorny issues and move Northern Ireland forward towards a more stable and prosperous future. The people of Northern Ireland will be watching closely to see if their elected representatives can rise to the challenge and deliver a lasting and meaningful agreement.

title: Balfour Beatty boss quits after profit warning
text: it would be taking a £30m charge in its UK construction business due to issues with a number of contracts. The firm's CEO, Leo Quinn, announced his resignation in the wake of the profit warning. Quinn took over as CEO in 2015, with the aim of turning around the struggling company. During his tenure, he implemented a number of cost-cutting measures and streamlined operations in an attempt to boost profits. Despite these efforts, the firm has continued to struggle, with a number of projects facing delays and cost overruns. In a statement, Balfour Beatty said: "We are disappointed to announce this profit warning, which is due to a combination of issues in our UK construction business. We are taking steps to address the problems and ensure that our projects are delivered on time and on budget." The news of Quinn's resignation comes as a blow to the company, which had been hoping to turn its fortunes around under his leadership. His departure raises questions about the firm's future direction and how it will deal with the challenges facing the construction industry in the UK. Analysts have warned that Balfour Beatty's problems are not unique, with many other construction firms facing similar issues. The industry is currently grappling with a number of challenges, including Brexit uncertainty, rising costs, and a shortage of skilled labor. Despite these challenges, Balfour Beatty remains confident that it can weather the storm and emerge stronger. The firm is currently focusing on its core markets, such as infrastructure and building, and is looking to streamline its operations further to improve efficiency. In a bid to reassure investors, Balfour Beatty said that it remains committed to delivering value for shareholders and will continue to focus on its core business areas. The company's shares have taken a hit in the wake of the profit warning, but analysts believe that it still has the potential to bounce back. Looking ahead, Balfour Beatty will need to address its contract issues and ensure that its projects are delivered successfully. The firm will also need to find a new CEO to lead the company through these challenging times. With the right leadership and a clear strategy, Balfour Beatty can overcome its current difficulties and return to profitability.

title: Sea lice and disease behind Marine Harvest bid to save £44m
text: euros (£67m) in the same period a year earlier. The salmon farming industry in Scotland is facing numerous challenges, including sea lice infestations and disease outbreaks that have significantly impacted production and profitability. Marine Harvest, the world's largest producer of farmed salmon, has been particularly hard hit by these issues, leading to a loss of £44m in its Scottish operations. Sea lice are parasitic crustaceans that feed on the blood and skin of fish, causing significant damage to salmon populations. In recent years, sea lice infestations have become increasingly common in Scottish salmon farms, leading to decreased production and increased mortality rates. This has resulted in significant financial losses for companies like Marine Harvest, which rely on high volumes of healthy fish to maintain profitability. In addition to sea lice, disease outbreaks have also been a major issue for the salmon farming industry in Scotland. Infectious diseases such as Infectious Salmon Anaemia (ISA) and Pancreas Disease (PD) can spread rapidly through fish populations, leading to high mortality rates and reduced production. These outbreaks not only impact the financial viability of salmon farms but also pose a threat to the overall sustainability of the industry. Marine Harvest has been working to address these issues through a combination of measures, including improved management practices and investment in new technology. The company has been exploring alternative methods of controlling sea lice, such as using cleaner fish to eat the parasites off of salmon, and implementing stricter biosecurity protocols to prevent disease outbreaks. Despite these efforts, Marine Harvest's Scottish operations continue to face significant challenges. The loss of £44m in the final three months of last year highlights the ongoing impact of sea lice and disease on the company's bottom line. The company's ability to address these issues will be critical to its long-term success in the Scottish salmon farming industry. In conclusion, sea lice and disease outbreaks are major challenges facing the salmon farming industry in Scotland. Companies like Marine Harvest are working to address these issues through improved management practices and investment in new technology. However, the financial impact of these challenges is significant, as evidenced by Marine Harvest's £44m loss in its Scottish operations. The future success of the industry will depend on the industry's ability to effectively manage these challenges and ensure the sustainability of salmon farming in Scotland.

title: Myanmar coup: India asked to return police officers who crossed border
text: Indian officials said the officers and their families had crossed the border in recent days. In a letter, Myanmar authorities asked for their immediate return, citing concerns over their safety and the violation of international norms. The Indian government has yet to make a formal announcement regarding the situation, but sources within the Ministry of External Affairs have confirmed that they are in discussions with their counterparts in Myanmar to address the issue. The incident comes amid escalating tensions in Myanmar following the military coup that took place on February 1st. The military junta has cracked down on pro-democracy protests, leading to widespread violence and human rights abuses. India, a key regional ally of Myanmar, has come under pressure from the international community to take a strong stance against the military junta. However, the Indian government has been cautious in its approach, citing the need to maintain stability and security in the region. The return of the police officers could potentially further strain relations between India and Myanmar, as the military junta seeks to assert its authority and crack down on dissent. The Indian government is now faced with a difficult decision on how to proceed. While there is a commitment to upholding international norms and respecting the sovereignty of other nations, the safety and well-being of the police officers and their families must also be taken into consideration. India is likely to tread carefully in this delicate situation, balancing its strategic interests in the region with its commitment to democracy and human rights. The government will be closely monitoring developments in Myanmar and working closely with international partners to find a peaceful resolution to the crisis. As tensions continue to rise in Myanmar, the international community is closely watching how India responds to the military junta's crackdown on pro-democracy protesters and the violation of international norms. The return of the police officers will be a critical test of India's commitment to upholding democracy and human rights in the region. The government must navigate this challenging situation with care and diplomacy to ensure the safety and well-being of all involved.

title: Chagos legal status sent to international court by UN
text: be part of the British Indian Ocean Territory until it was separated in 1965. The Chagos Islands have been a point of contention between the UK and Mauritius for decades, with Mauritius claiming sovereignty over the archipelago. The decision to bring the legal status of the Chagos Islands to the International Court of Justice in The Hague marks a significant turning point in the long-standing dispute. The UK government has faced criticism for its treatment of the Chagossian people, who were forcibly removed from their homeland to make way for a US military base on Diego Garcia, the largest island in the archipelago. The Chagossians have fought for decades to return to their homeland, but successive British governments have resisted their efforts. The UK government argued that the Chagos Islands are a strategic military asset and that the presence of the US military base is essential for global security. However, Mauritius and other countries have challenged the UK's sovereignty over the Chagos Islands, arguing that the separation of the islands from Mauritius was illegal under international law. The UN General Assembly vote reflects growing international pressure on the UK to address the legal status of the Chagos Islands. The UK government has expressed disappointment with the UN vote and has reiterated its commitment to upholding its sovereignty over the Chagos Islands. However, the decision to bring the dispute to the International Court of Justice means that the legal status of the Chagos Islands will be subject to international scrutiny. The Chagos Islands hold significant ecological value, with diverse marine life and coral reefs that are considered to be some of the most pristine in the world. The Chagossian people have a deep cultural and historical connection to the islands, and their forced removal has had a lasting impact on their community. As the legal battle over the Chagos Islands continues to unfold, the international community will be watching closely to see how the UK and Mauritius navigate this complex and sensitive issue. The decision of the International Court of Justice could have far-reaching implications for the future of the Chagos Islands and the people who call it home.

title: Ysgol Coed Menai school, Bangor, closure plan is backed
text: Ysgol Coed Menai near Bangor - formerly called Ysgol Treborth - provides education for pupils who have social, emotional and behavioural problems. Gwynedd council said it had developed plans to support the pupils at local schools, and in a statement on Tuesday, they confirmed that the closure plan has been backed. The decision to close the school has been met with mixed reactions from parents and the community. Some believe that the closure is necessary in order to provide better support for the students, while others are concerned about the impact it will have on the pupils who rely on the specialized services that Ysgol Coed Menai provides. The council has said that they will work closely with parents, staff, and other stakeholders to ensure a smooth transition for the students. They have also committed to providing additional resources and support for the pupils who will be transferring to other schools in the area. Councillor Cemlyn Williams, Gwynedd Council's cabinet member for education, expressed his support for the closure plan, stating that it is in the best interest of the students. He emphasized the council's commitment to ensuring that the pupils receive the support they need to succeed in their new educational setting. Ysgol Coed Menai has been operating for many years, providing a crucial service to students with complex needs. The school has a dedicated staff who are experienced in working with students who require additional support, and they have built strong relationships with the pupils and their families. Despite the closure of Ysgol Coed Menai, the council has assured parents and the community that they remain committed to providing high-quality education for all students in Gwynedd. They have pledged to continue working with local schools to ensure that the needs of vulnerable students are met. As the closure plan moves forward, the council will be working closely with stakeholders to address any concerns and make sure that the transition is as smooth as possible for the students. They are also exploring options for repurposing the school site in order to meet the needs of the community in the future. Overall, the decision to close Ysgol Coed Menai is a difficult one, but the council believes that it is the right step to ensure that all students in Gwynedd have access to the education and support they need to thrive. The focus now is on supporting the students through this transition and providing them with the resources they need to succeed in their new schools.

title: Covid: Moray moving to level two 'hugely welcome'
text: said the move to level two for Moray was "hugely welcome" after weeks of restrictions aimed at controlling the spread of Covid-19 in the region. She acknowledged the sacrifices made by the people of Moray and praised their efforts in driving down infection rates. The decision to lift Moray to level two comes as part of the Scottish government's gradual easing of restrictions across the country. Sturgeon emphasized the need to continue following guidelines to prevent a resurgence of the virus, urging people to remain cautious and vigilant. Business owners in Moray were relieved at the news, as the move to level two allows for more economic activity to take place. Restaurants, pubs, and other hospitality venues can now serve alcohol indoors until 10:30 pm, with a maximum of six people from three households permitted to meet. Residents in Moray expressed their relief at the easing of restrictions, with many looking forward to reconnecting with loved ones and enjoying a greater sense of normality. The move to level two is a positive step towards a return to pre-pandemic life for the people of Moray. Despite the move to level two, health officials in Moray continue to urge caution and vigilance in the face of Covid-19. They emphasize the importance of maintaining social distancing, wearing masks, and practicing good hand hygiene to prevent the spread of the virus. The Scottish government has emphasized the need for continued adherence to Covid-19 guidelines to ensure the success of the gradual easing of restrictions. Sturgeon warned that any sudden increase in infection rates could result in a reversal of the progress made in Moray and other parts of the country. Overall, the move to level two for Moray is being met with optimism and relief by residents and businesses in the region. The gradual easing of restrictions is seen as a positive sign of progress in the fight against Covid-19, but the need for continued vigilance and caution is still paramount to prevent a resurgence of the virus. As Moray transitions to level two, residents are hopeful that a return to normality is on the horizon. With vaccination efforts well underway and infection rates decreasing, there is a sense of optimism in the air as the region looks towards a brighter future post-pandemic.

title: Microsoft seeks to clean up Xbox game chat with AI
text: It is introducing customisable filters that let gamers choose the vocabulary they see in messages from friends and rival players. The four levels of filtering range from child-friendly through to entirely unfiltered. Initially the filters cover just text chat, but Microsoft plans to extend them to voice chat in the future. The move comes amid growing concerns over toxic behaviour and harassment in online gaming communities. Microsoft hopes that by giving players the ability to filter out offensive language, they can create a more welcoming and inclusive environment for all gamers. The filters are powered by artificial intelligence, which scans messages for inappropriate language and flags them for review. Users can also manually block specific words or phrases that they find offensive. In addition to the new filters, Microsoft is also cracking down on abusive behavior in Xbox Live. The company has implemented a new system that automatically detects and issues warnings to players who engage in toxic behavior, such as hate speech, harassment, or cheating. "We want Xbox Live to be a place where everyone feels safe and welcome," said a Microsoft spokesperson. "By giving players the tools to control their own gaming experience, we hope to foster a more positive and enjoyable community for all." The move has been met with praise from many gamers who have long been frustrated by the toxic behavior that can sometimes occur in online games. "I can't tell you how many times I've been called racist or homophobic slurs while playing online," said one Xbox Live user. "Having the ability to filter out that kind of language is a game-changer for me." However, some have raised concerns about the potential for the filters to be used to censor legitimate speech. "While I understand the need to combat toxic behavior, I worry that these filters could end up stifling free expression," said another gamer. Microsoft has assured users that the filters are fully customizable, allowing players to control the level of filtering that is appropriate for them. The company also plans to continue refining the filters based on user feedback to ensure they are as effective and fair as possible. Overall, Microsoft's efforts to clean up Xbox game chat with AI are a positive step towards creating a more inclusive and enjoyable gaming environment for all players. By giving users more control over their gaming experience, the company hopes to make Xbox Live a safer and more welcoming place for gamers of all backgrounds.

title: Preparations 'on track' for Glasgow 2014 Games
text: In its first progress report, the committee said venues were starting to take shape and key infrastructure was being put in place. The total cost of the Games is now expected to be about £523.6m. Earlier this year, concerns were raised about potential delays and budget overruns, but the committee's latest update suggests that preparations are on track. One of the key venues for the Games is the newly constructed Royal Commonwealth Pool, which will host swimming and diving events. The pool has undergone a major renovation to meet the standards required for international competition. In addition, construction on the Emirates Arena, which will host badminton and cycling events, is also progressing well. The committee has praised the efforts of contractors and workers for their dedication to ensuring that the venues are completed on time. Infrastructure projects, such as road improvements and public transportation upgrades, are also moving forward smoothly. The Glasgow City Council has invested in new bus lanes and bike paths to make it easier for spectators to travel to and from the various venues. Additionally, the city's subway system is undergoing renovations to accommodate the increased passenger traffic during the Games. Security measures are also being implemented to ensure the safety of athletes, officials, and spectators. The committee is working closely with local law enforcement agencies to develop a comprehensive security plan that will address potential threats and emergencies. Training exercises and drills are being conducted to test the readiness of security personnel for any potential scenarios that may arise during the Games. Volunteer recruitment is another area where progress has been made. Thousands of individuals have signed up to assist with various aspects of the Games, from event coordination to hospitality services. Training sessions are being organized to prepare volunteers for their roles and responsibilities during the Games. The committee has expressed gratitude for the overwhelming response from the community and is confident that the volunteers will play a crucial role in the success of the event. Overall, the committee remains optimistic about the progress of preparations for the Glasgow 2014 Games. With just a few months to go until the opening ceremony, the focus is now on fine-tuning the details and ensuring that everything is in place for a successful and memorable event. The excitement is building among athletes and fans alike, and anticipation is high for what promises to be a spectacular showcase of sportsmanship and camaraderie.

title: Merged Isle of Wight prison criticised in report
text: An inspection of HMP Isle of Wight found "degrading" sanitation provision, high use of force and inmates seeking sanctuary in a segregation unit. Inspectors found a quarter of prisoners were locked in their cells during the day in what they described as "unacceptable" conditions. The Isle of Wight prison, which was formed through the merger of two separate facilities last year, has been under scrutiny since the consolidation. The report highlighted issues with the new system's ability to effectively manage the increased population, leading to overcrowding and escalated tensions among inmates. One of the most concerning aspects of the inspection was the sanitation provision, which was described as degrading and unhygienic. Inspectors found that many cells did not have access to adequate sanitation facilities, with some prisoners having to wait hours to use the toilet. This lack of basic necessities was deemed unacceptable by the inspection team, who called for immediate improvements to be made. The use of force by prison staff was also a major point of contention in the report. Inspectors noted that there was a high level of force used against inmates, often in situations where it was not necessary. This aggressive approach was seen as contributing to the overall atmosphere of fear and intimidation within the prison, further exacerbating the already volatile situation. Inmates seeking sanctuary in the segregation unit was another troubling finding. The report stated that many prisoners felt unsafe in the general population and sought refuge in the segregation unit, where conditions were even worse. This highlighted the pervasive sense of insecurity and vulnerability felt by many inmates, further emphasizing the urgent need for changes to be made. Overall, the inspection painted a bleak picture of HMP Isle of Wight, highlighting a multitude of issues that needed to be addressed promptly. The merging of the two facilities seemed to have only exacerbated existing problems, rather than providing a solution. The report called for immediate action to improve conditions within the prison, including better sanitation facilities, reduced use of force, and increased support for inmates who felt unsafe. The Ministry of Justice has responded to the report, acknowledging the issues raised and pledging to work with the prison management to implement the necessary changes. However, the gravity of the situation at HMP Isle of Wight is clear, and urgent action is needed to ensure the safety and well-being of all inmates within the facility.

title: Coronavirus: MPs see surge in online petition numbers
text: Labour MP Catherine McKinnell, who chairs the Petitions Committee, said they had highlighted issues that "may have been overlooked" by politicians. The surge in online petition numbers during the Coronavirus pandemic has shed light on a variety of concerns affecting individuals and communities across the country. As the virus continues to impact lives and livelihoods, people are turning to petitions as a way to make their voices heard and push for change. One such petition that has gained significant traction calls for increased financial support for self-employed individuals, who have been hit hard by the economic repercussions of the pandemic. With many self-employed workers facing financial uncertainty and struggling to make ends meet, the petition has struck a chord with thousands of people who are calling on the government to provide more assistance. Another hot topic among the recent wave of petitions is the issue of mental health. The lockdown measures and social isolation brought on by the pandemic have taken a toll on the mental well-being of many individuals. Petitions advocating for improved mental health services and increased funding for mental health initiatives have garnered widespread support, as people seek to address the growing mental health crisis exacerbated by the pandemic. Furthermore, petitions calling for better protection for essential workers, including healthcare workers, grocery store employees, and delivery drivers, have also gained momentum. These frontline workers have been putting themselves at risk to ensure the functioning of essential services during the pandemic, and many are calling for more comprehensive measures to protect their health and safety. As the Petitions Committee continues to review and respond to the surge in online petition numbers, MPs are faced with the task of considering the diverse range of issues and concerns being brought to their attention. The pandemic has underscored the importance of listening to the voices of the public and responding to their needs during these challenging times. In the words of Labour MP Catherine McKinnell, "These petitions are a vital tool for democracy, allowing people to raise their concerns and hold the government to account. It is crucial that we listen to the voices of the public and take action to address the issues that matter most to them." As the online petition numbers continue to surge, it is clear that the Coronavirus pandemic has not only highlighted the vulnerabilities within our society but also the resilience and unity of the people who are coming together to push for change and create a better future for all.

title: Stafford and Cannock hospitals' services 'unsustainable'
text: Recommendations that Stafford Hospital and Cannock Chase Hospital should be downgraded have been made in a report for regulator Monitor. Some services should be carried out by neighbouring trusts, the report said. They highlighted the unsustainable nature of the current services being provided at the hospitals, citing concerns about staffing levels, financial viability, and quality of care. The report pointed out that both hospitals have been struggling to meet the demands of the local population, leading to long waiting times, inadequate resources, and a lack of specialist care. It recommended that certain services, such as maternity care and paediatrics, should be transferred to larger, more well-equipped hospitals in the region to ensure better outcomes for patients. The proposal to downgrade Stafford and Cannock hospitals has sparked controversy among local residents and healthcare workers, who fear that the move would lead to reduced access to healthcare services in the area. Many have voiced their concerns about the potential impact on vulnerable populations, such as the elderly and those with complex medical needs, who rely on the hospitals for essential care. However, supporters of the recommendations argue that downsizing the hospitals is necessary to address the underlying issues of poor performance and financial instability. They believe that by redistributing services to larger, more efficient facilities, patients will receive better care and outcomes will improve across the board. In response to the report, Monitor has announced that it will be conducting a thorough review of the recommendations before making any final decisions. The regulator has assured the public that the welfare of patients is their top priority and that any changes to hospital services will be made with the best interests of the community in mind. Meanwhile, hospital administrators have acknowledged the challenges facing Stafford and Cannock hospitals and have committed to working closely with Monitor and other stakeholders to find sustainable solutions. They have pledged to explore all options for improving services, including potential partnerships with neighbouring trusts and healthcare providers. As the debate over the future of Stafford and Cannock hospitals continues, residents are being urged to stay informed and participate in the ongoing discussions. The fate of these hospitals will have far-reaching implications for the local community, and it is essential that all voices are heard in the decision-making process. In the end, the goal is to ensure that patients in Staffordshire have access to high-quality, sustainable healthcare services that meet their needs effectively. By working together, hospital staff, regulators, and the public can strive to create a better future for healthcare in the region.

title: Fears raised 'free NHS' will come to an end
text: By Nick TriggleHealth correspondent, BBC News Nearly half of the 78 health and care leaders surveyed by the Nuffield Trust felt the status quo would not remain because of the growing fears that the "free NHS" could soon come to an end.  The survey revealed that many leaders believe the NHS faces a crisis point in terms of funding and resources, which could lead to a significant shift towards a more privatized healthcare system. This comes amid ongoing discussions about the sustainability of the NHS and concerns about its ability to meet the increasing demands placed upon it. There is a sense of urgency among healthcare professionals, who are worried about the implications of potential changes to the NHS. The prospect of the NHS moving away from its founding principles of providing free healthcare for all is a cause for concern, particularly among those who rely on the service for their medical needs. One of the key factors contributing to these fears is the ongoing pressure on NHS finances. With increasing demand for healthcare services, coupled with limited resources and funding, many are worried that the current model of healthcare provision may not be sustainable in the long term. Additionally, the COVID-19 pandemic has further highlighted the vulnerability of the NHS and the need for adequate investment and support. The strain placed on the healthcare system during the pandemic has exposed weaknesses that need to be addressed to ensure the continued delivery of high-quality care to patients. Many health and care leaders are calling for urgent action to address the funding and resource challenges facing the NHS. They are urging the government to provide sufficient funding to ensure the sustainability of the healthcare system and to protect the principle of free healthcare for all. However, there is a sense of uncertainty and anxiety about the future of the NHS, with concerns that the government may prioritize cost-cutting measures over the needs of patients. The potential consequences of such actions are causing widespread apprehension within the healthcare sector. In conclusion, the fears raised by health and care leaders about the possible end of the "free NHS" are a reflection of the challenges facing the healthcare system. It is crucial that these concerns are addressed promptly and effectively to safeguard the future of the NHS and ensure that it continues to provide high-quality care to all who need it.

title: Being a couch potato could be genetic say Aberdeen scientists
text: Scientists from Aberdeen University, working with colleagues in China, have been looking at why some people are less inclined to exercise and more likely to put on weight. The team said that their research has revealed a surprising link between genetics and sedentary behavior, shedding light on why some individuals may be more prone to a couch potato lifestyle. Through a series of studies conducted on both humans and animal models, the researchers identified specific genetic variations that may predispose individuals to prefer sedentary activities over physical exercise. These genetic differences were found to affect various neurotransmitters and hormones in the brain, ultimately influencing an individual's motivation and reward response to physical activity. Dr. Sarah Thompson, lead researcher on the study, explained the implications of their findings, stating, "Our research suggests that there may be a genetic component to why some people find it more difficult to stay active and maintain a healthy weight. By understanding the biological basis of sedentary behavior, we can potentially develop more targeted interventions to help individuals overcome their genetic predispositions and lead a more active lifestyle." The study also found that individuals with certain genetic variations appeared to have a higher tendency to seek out high-fat and calorie-dense foods, further exacerbating the risk of weight gain and obesity. This genetic predisposition to both sedentary behavior and unhealthy eating habits highlights the complex interplay between genetics, lifestyle choices, and overall health outcomes. While the researchers acknowledge that genetics is just one piece of the puzzle when it comes to understanding obesity and physical inactivity, their findings provide valuable insights into the underlying mechanisms that may contribute to these common health concerns. By identifying specific genetic markers associated with sedentary behavior, future interventions could potentially be tailored to individuals based on their unique genetic profiles. Professor Zhang Wei, a collaborator on the study from the Chinese Academy of Sciences, commented on the global implications of the research, noting that "Understanding the genetic basis of sedentary behavior could have far-reaching implications for public health initiatives aimed at reducing obesity and promoting physical activity. By targeting individuals with a genetic predisposition to sedentary behavior, we may be able to develop more effective strategies for preventing and managing weight-related health problems." Overall, the research from Aberdeen University and their colleagues in China provides a fascinating glimpse into the intricate relationship between genetics, behavior, and health outcomes. While being a couch potato may not solely be determined by genetics, this study suggests that certain individuals may indeed have a genetic predisposition to sedentary behavior and weight gain.

title: Poster wars breaking out across Europe
text: By Piers ScholfieldBBC News, Brussels In Britain, the UK Independence Party has certainly got the publicity it was hoping for from its new poster campaign - and expects it to encourage a higher turnout from their supporters in the upcoming European Parliament elections. The controversial posters, featuring slogans such as "Stop the EU Invasion" and "Take Back Control", have sparked heated debates and divided opinions across the nation. But the poster wars are not limited to the UK. Across Europe, political parties are ramping up their propaganda efforts as the election date draws near. In France, the National Rally party, led by Marine Le Pen, has launched its own series of provocative posters aimed at stirring up anti-EU sentiments. With images of a crumbling EU flag and warnings of the dangers of unchecked immigration, the party is hoping to capitalize on the growing disillusionment with the European project. Meanwhile, in Germany, the far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD) party has rolled out a series of posters calling for "Germany First" and urging voters to "Protect our borders". The party, which has been steadily gaining support in recent years, is using the posters as a platform to push its nationalist agenda and challenge the mainstream political establishment. In Italy, the populist League party, led by Matteo Salvini, has taken a more subtle approach with its posters, focusing on themes of national pride and sovereignty. Their posters feature messages such as "Italy, not Brussels" and "Italians First", tapping into the anti-EU sentiments that have been brewing in the country. The poster wars have also spread to Eastern European countries like Poland and Hungary, where nationalist governments are locked in a battle with the EU over issues such as immigration and the rule of law. In Poland, the ruling Law and Justice party has launched a campaign highlighting the country's sovereignty and independence, while in Hungary, Prime Minister Viktor Orban's Fidesz party has plastered the streets with messages promoting a "Strong Hungary" and a "Europe of Nations". As the poster wars intensify across Europe, the battle for hearts and minds is heating up. Political parties are using every tool at their disposal to sway voters and shape public opinion in the run-up to the European Parliament elections. With the rise of nationalist and populist movements, the outcome of these elections could have far-reaching implications for the future of the European Union.

title: Viagogo threatened with fresh court action
text: order to overhaul its business practices and make changes to its website. Despite the court ruling, Viagogo has failed to fully comply with the requirements set out by the CMA, prompting the watchdog to consider taking further legal action against the ticket reseller. Viagogo has faced widespread criticism for its practices, which have often left consumers feeling exploited and ripped off. The company has come under fire for a number of issues, including hidden fees, misleading pricing, and inadequate customer service. In some cases, customers have reported being denied entry to events after purchasing tickets through Viagogo, while others have found themselves paying vastly inflated prices for tickets that were falsely advertised as sold out. The CMA's previous court action against Viagogo was a significant step towards holding the company accountable for its actions. However, it seems that this action has not been enough to force Viagogo to change its ways. As a result, the watchdog is now considering launching fresh legal proceedings to ensure that the ticket seller complies with consumer protection laws. Viagogo has defended its practices, claiming that it is committed to providing a secure and reliable platform for buying and selling tickets. The company has argued that its business model allows customers to access a wide range of events and helps to prevent ticket fraud. However, critics argue that Viagogo's practices are unethical and harmful to consumers, and have called for greater regulation of the ticket resale industry. The CMA has warned Viagogo that it must take immediate action to address its non-compliance with consumer protection law. Failure to do so could result in further legal action being taken against the ticket reseller, potentially leading to significant financial penalties. The watchdog has also called on consumers who have had negative experiences with Viagogo to come forward and share their stories, in order to help build a stronger case against the company. Ultimately, the CMA's actions against Viagogo serve as a warning to other ticket resale platforms that disregard consumer protection laws. The watchdog is determined to hold companies accountable for their actions and ensure that consumers are treated fairly and transparently. As the battle between Viagogo and the CMA continues, it remains to be seen whether the ticket reseller will finally be forced to change its practices and provide a better service for its customers.

title: Coronavirus: New Bank of England boss pledges prompt action
text: Faisal Islam Economics editor @faisalislam on Twitter  Andrew Bailey took over from current Bank governor Mark Carney on Monday. Mr Bailey was speaking hours after the Bank of England unveiled an emergency cut to interest rates in response to the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak.  In his first speech as governor, Mr Bailey pledged to take prompt action to support the economy during this challenging time. He emphasized the Bank's willingness to do whatever it takes to stabilize markets and protect the financial system.  The decision to cut interest rates from 0.75% to 0.25% was made to help mitigate the effects of the coronavirus on the economy. The move was coordinated with the UK government's announcement of a package of measures to support businesses and individuals affected by the outbreak.  Mr Bailey acknowledged that the economic outlook has deteriorated significantly in recent days and emphasized the need for swift and decisive action to address the situation. He emphasized that the Bank of England is prepared to take further steps if necessary to ensure the stability of the financial system and support economic growth.  The new governor also stressed the importance of coordination between central banks and governments to respond effectively to the challenges posed by the coronavirus. He highlighted the need for a united front to address the economic impact of the outbreak and ensure that businesses and individuals are supported during this difficult time.  Mr Bailey's appointment comes at a critical moment for the UK economy, which is facing unprecedented challenges due to the coronavirus outbreak. His experience as the former chief executive of the Financial Conduct Authority will be crucial in guiding the Bank of England through this turbulent period. As the coronavirus continues to spread around the world, governments and central banks are facing difficult decisions about how to support their economies and protect their citizens. The Bank of England's decision to cut interest rates is just one of many measures being taken to address the economic impact of the outbreak. In his speech, Mr Bailey emphasized the need for a coordinated response to the challenges posed by the coronavirus. He acknowledged that the situation is evolving rapidly and stressed the importance of remaining flexible and responsive to developments. Overall, Mr Bailey's pledge to take prompt action to support the economy and stabilize financial markets during this challenging time will be closely watched by businesses, investors, and policymakers alike. The coming days and weeks will be critical in determining how the UK economy weathers the storm of the coronavirus outbreak.

title: NHS contaminated blood scandal victims urged to come forward
text: Welsh AM Julie Morgan expressed her relief at this long-awaited announcement, stating, "The contaminated blood scandal has had a devastating impact on thousands of lives across the UK, including here in Wales. It is crucial that those affected finally get the answers and justice they deserve." The contaminated blood scandal dates back to the 1970s and 1980s when patients were treated with infected blood products, leading to the spread of deadly viruses such as HIV and hepatitis C. Many of those infected were haemophiliacs who relied on regular blood transfusions to manage their condition. For years, victims and their families have been fighting for justice and accountability, as well as compensation for the immense physical, emotional, and financial toll the contaminated blood has taken on their lives. The public inquiry, with its carefully defined terms of reference, will be a crucial step towards uncovering the truth behind this tragic chapter in NHS history.
