In the face of growing challenges, Taiwan's resilience and determination to uphold its sovereignty and defend its democratic way of life will be put to the test. The international community must stand in solidarity with Taiwan in the face of coercion and intimidation from Beijing, and support its efforts to maintain its status as a free and independent nation.

title: Prison staff misconduct investigations rise by third
text: Inspectorate's annual report highlighted several key findings, including concerns about the treatment of inmates and the working conditions of prison staff. The report noted that there is a growing trend of staff misconduct investigations, which is a worrying development for the prison system. One of the main issues raised in the report was the use of unnecessary force by prison staff. This includes cases where staff have been found to have used excessive force when dealing with inmates, leading to injuries and even deaths in some extreme cases. The report also highlighted concerns about the use of restraint techniques, which can sometimes be seen as abusive or inhumane. Furthermore, the report highlighted a significant number of cases involving the breach of security within prisons. This can include staff members bringing in contraband such as drugs, weapons, or mobile phones, which can pose a serious threat to the safety and security of both staff and inmates. The report also raised concerns about the lack of accountability and oversight in some cases, which can lead to a culture of impunity among prison staff. In response to the findings of the report, the Ministry of Justice has pledged to take action to address the issues raised. This includes improving training for prison staff on the appropriate use of force and restraint techniques, as well as implementing stricter policies and procedures to prevent the breach of security within prisons. The Ministry of Justice has also committed to increasing oversight and accountability measures to ensure that staff are held accountable for their actions. However, some critics argue that more needs to be done to address the underlying issues that contribute to staff misconduct in prisons. This includes addressing the high levels of stress and burnout among prison staff, as well as improving working conditions and support systems for those working in the prison system. Overall, the rise in staff misconduct investigations is a concerning trend that highlights the need for greater oversight and accountability within the prison system. It is essential that steps are taken to address the root causes of staff misconduct and to ensure that the safety and security of both staff and inmates are protected. Failure to do so could have serious consequences for the prison system as a whole.

title: Theresa May warning over police targets 'comeback'
text: May emphasized the importance of allowing police officers to use their professional judgement and discretion when carrying out their duties. She highlighted that setting arbitrary targets can hinder their ability to respond effectively to changing circumstances and can lead to unintended consequences. The Prime Minister acknowledged that there is a fine balance between accountability and allowing police officers the freedom to do their jobs without unnecessary bureaucratic restrictions. She reassured the Police Superintendents' Association that the government is committed to supporting law enforcement agencies in their efforts to keep communities safe. Ms. May also addressed the issue of public perception of police performance, noting that it is crucial for the public to have confidence in the police and their ability to protect and serve. She stressed the importance of building trust between the police and the communities they serve, emphasizing the need for transparency and accountability in police operations. The Prime Minister's speech comes at a time when the police service is facing increasing challenges, including rising crime rates and budget constraints. Her message of support and encouragement for police officers was well-received by the audience, who welcomed her commitment to empowering law enforcement agencies to do their jobs effectively. In conclusion, Theresa May's warning over the potential resurgence of police targets serves as a reminder of the importance of allowing law enforcement agencies the flexibility they need to respond to changing security threats and crime trends. By scrapping top-down diktats and focusing on building police confidence, the government is sending a clear message that it values the professionalism and expertise of the men and women who serve on the front lines of law enforcement. As the Prime Minister continues to navigate the complex landscape of policing and security challenges, her words of caution and encouragement will undoubtedly resonate with police officers across England and Wales. The government's commitment to supporting law enforcement agencies in their efforts to uphold the rule of law and protect communities is a reassuring sign of its dedication to ensuring public safety and security in an ever-changing world.

title: West Midlands submits bid for Channel 4 relocation
text: 4 relocating to the West Midlands would be a game-changer for the region, offering significant economic benefits and driving further growth. The bid outlines how the relocation would create thousands of jobs, attract new businesses, and boost the creative industries in the area. Andy Street emphasized that the West Midlands is a thriving and diverse region, with a rich cultural heritage and a strong creative sector. He highlighted the region's excellent transport links, affordable housing, and high-quality of life as key factors that would make it an attractive location for Channel 4. The bid also focuses on the region's commitment to diversity and inclusion, with plans to work closely with local communities and stakeholders to ensure that Channel 4's programming reflects the experiences and voices of people in the West Midlands. This aligns with Channel 4's own ethos of championing diversity and representing all parts of the UK. Additionally, the WMCA is offering support and incentives to Channel 4 to make the transition as smooth as possible. This includes assistance with finding suitable office space, access to talent and skills development programs, and opportunities for collaboration with local universities and creative organizations. The move comes as Channel 4 faces increasing pressure to decentralize its operations and better reflect the diversity of the UK. The government consultation is part of broader efforts to promote regional growth and rebalance the economy away from London and the South East. Some critics have raised concerns about the potential impact of relocating Channel 4, arguing that it could disrupt the broadcaster's operations and lead to job losses in London. However, supporters of the move believe that it presents an exciting opportunity for the West Midlands to showcase its creative talent and solidify its position as a hub for media and entertainment. Overall, the bid for Channel 4 relocation represents a bold and ambitious vision for the West Midlands' future. If successful, it could have far-reaching benefits for the region, transforming its economy and cultural landscape for years to come. With the government consultation underway, all eyes are now on Channel 4 to consider the opportunities and challenges of making the move to the heart of England.

title: Bristol friends raise £5,500 after free school meal upset
text: Chloe and Imogen Wood were shocked to see the lack of food given to families for free school meals packages. In one week they raised £3,460 online and more than £2,000 offline, filling a dozen trolleys with nutritious items to distribute to those in need in their community in Bristol. The sisters, aged 12 and 14, were moved to take action after seeing images shared on social media of meager food parcels being given to families who rely on free school meals to feed their children. Determined to make a difference, they set up an online fundraiser and shared it with their friends and family. The response was overwhelming, with donations pouring in from across the country. People were touched by the girls' compassion and drive to make a difference in their community. Chloe and Imogen were amazed at the generosity of strangers who wanted to help them in their mission to ensure that no child goes hungry. With the money they raised, the girls went on a shopping spree, filling their carts with staples like pasta, rice, canned goods, fresh fruits and vegetables, and other essentials. They also purchased treats like cookies and chocolates to bring some joy to the families they were helping. Armed with their trolleys full of food, Chloe and Imogen set out to deliver the packages to families in need. They went door-to-door, handing out the food with big smiles and kind words for the recipients. The families were grateful for the girls' efforts, and many were moved to tears by their generosity. In addition to the online donations, Chloe and Imogen also collected cash donations from friends, family, and neighbors. They organized a bake sale in their community and set up a donation box outside their local grocery store. The outpouring of support was truly heartwarming, and the girls were thrilled to see how much they were able to accomplish with the help of their community. Thanks to Chloe and Imogen's hard work and dedication, they were able to raise a total of £5,460 to help families in need. The sisters were overjoyed by the success of their fundraiser, and they have already begun planning their next project to continue making a difference in their community. For these two young girls, the experience has been a lesson in the power of community, compassion, and perseverance. They have shown that even the smallest acts of kindness can make a big impact, and they have inspired others to join them in their mission to help those in need. Chloe and Imogen are proof that age is no barrier to making a difference in the world.

title: Ronan Kerr's brother attacks Tom Elliott 'scum' remarks
text: Tom Elliott hit out at people waving Irish flags at Omagh Leisure Centre, calling them the "scum of Sinn Fein". On his Twitter account, Cathair Kerr said that Mr Elliott's comments were "prejudiced". He added: "People need to move forward. In response to the controversial remarks made by Tom Elliott, Cathair Kerr, the brother of slain police officer Ronan Kerr, took to social media to express his disapproval. Kerr, whose brother was killed by dissident republicans in 2011, condemned Elliott's derogatory comments towards those displaying Irish flags. The incident occurred during a local sporting event at Omagh Leisure Centre, where spectators were seen waving Irish flags. In a public statement, Tom Elliott, a former leader of the Ulster Unionist Party, criticized the individuals waving the flags as supporters of Sinn Fein, a nationalist political party in Northern Ireland. His remarks sparked outrage among many, including Cathair Kerr. Kerr, who has been a vocal advocate for peace and reconciliation in the region since his brother's tragic death, condemned Elliott's comments as divisive and inflammatory. In a series of tweets, he called for unity and understanding, urging people to move beyond the divisive rhetoric that has plagued Northern Ireland for decades. "Mr Elliott's remarks are not only prejudiced but also harmful to the ongoing efforts for peace and reconciliation in our community," Kerr wrote. "We must strive to build bridges, not burn them. It is time for us to move forward together, with respect and tolerance for all." The controversy surrounding Tom Elliott's comments highlights the deep-rooted divisions that still exist within Northern Ireland. The region has a history of sectarian violence and political strife, with tensions often running high between unionist and nationalist communities. Despite the progress that has been made towards peace and reconciliation in recent years, incidents like this serve as a reminder of the work that still needs to be done. Cathair Kerr's response to the situation underscores the importance of dialogue and understanding in moving towards a more peaceful and inclusive society. As the fallout from Tom Elliott's remarks continues to unfold, it is clear that more must be done to promote unity and reconciliation in Northern Ireland. Cathair Kerr's advocacy for peace and understanding serves as a powerful reminder of the importance of overcoming division and working towards a shared future for all.

title: New Treasury Chief Secretary Danny Alexander
text: The appointment of Mr Alexander to his second Cabinet post in less than a month marks the next step in his rapid political rise. Virtually unknown outside the Westminster bubble, his profile shot up during the election campaign as he emerged as a key figure in the Liberal Democrats' new-look front bench. With the departure of Vince Cable, the former Business Secretary, Mr Alexander was swiftly promoted to the role of Chief Secretary to the Treasury. This move raised eyebrows among many political commentators who questioned his lack of experience in such a crucial economic role. However, supporters of Mr Alexander point to his background as Chief of Staff to party leader Nick Clegg and his work on economic policy during the coalition government as evidence of his suitability for the position. As Chief Secretary to the Treasury, Mr Alexander will face a number of challenges. The UK economy is still recovering from the effects of the global financial crisis and government spending remains a highly contentious issue. With the general election just around the corner, Mr Alexander will need to prove himself capable of managing the Treasury's budget effectively while also working to deliver the coalition government's economic priorities. One of Mr Alexander's first tasks in his new role will be to address the issue of government spending cuts. The coalition government has pledged to continue to reduce public spending in order to eliminate the deficit, but the scale and speed of these cuts remain hotly debated. Mr Alexander will need to work closely with the Chancellor of the Exchequer to formulate a comprehensive plan that balances the need for fiscal discipline with the demands of public services and welfare provision. Mr Alexander's appointment as Chief Secretary to the Treasury has been met with a mixed response from across the political spectrum. While some have praised his intelligence and dedication, others have raised concerns about his lack of experience in economic matters. As he settles into his new role, Mr Alexander will need to work hard to prove his critics wrong and demonstrate that he is up to the challenge of steering the UK economy through the turbulent waters ahead. In the coming months, all eyes will be on Mr Alexander as he grapples with the complex and demanding task of managing the UK's finances. His performance in this key government role will not only shape his own political future but also have a profound impact on the economic prospects of the country as a whole. As a relative newcomer to the world of high finance, Mr Alexander faces a steep learning curve, but his supporters believe that his intelligence, work ethic and determination will see him through. Only time will tell if he is up to the task.

title: Childcare recruitment 'catastrophe' looms, say campaigners
text: By Judith Burns Education reporter New recruits to key jobs must have at least GCSE C grades in the subjects, with alternative equivalent qualifications no longer accepted. The Save our Early Years campaign says that this new requirement is leading to a childcare recruitment "catastrophe" that could have significant impacts on the sector. The campaign argues that the strict educational criteria are limiting the pool of potential candidates, making it difficult for childcare providers to find qualified staff to fill their vacancies. This is particularly worrying as the demand for childcare services continues to rise, with families increasingly needing access to high-quality early years education and care. According to the campaign, many talented individuals who have the necessary skills and experience to work in the childcare sector are being excluded because they do not meet the new academic requirements. This is leading to staff shortages and increased workloads for existing employees, putting added pressure on an already overstretched workforce. In addition, the campaign warns that the lack of flexibility in the recruitment process is discouraging diversity in the sector. By narrowing the criteria for entry-level positions, childcare providers are missing out on the opportunity to recruit individuals from different backgrounds and with varied experiences, which could enrich the quality of care and education provided to children. The Save our Early Years campaign is calling on the government to review the new recruitment guidelines and consider alternative ways to assess candidates' suitability for childcare roles. They argue that a more holistic approach, taking into account a broader range of skills and qualifications, would be more effective in identifying the best candidates for the job. In response, a Department for Education spokesperson stated that the government is committed to improving the quality of early years education and ensuring that all childcare providers have access to a highly skilled workforce. They acknowledged the concerns raised by the campaign and confirmed that they are currently reviewing the impact of the new recruitment criteria on the sector. It is clear that the childcare recruitment "catastrophe" is a pressing issue that requires urgent attention. Without swift action to address the barriers faced by potential candidates, the sector risks facing significant challenges in meeting the growing demand for high-quality childcare services. Only by working together to find innovative solutions can we ensure that every child has access to the care and education they deserve.

title: #ElPasochallenge: Boy responds to shooting to help community heal
text: By Rozina Sini BBC News Ruben Martinez is the youngster behind the #elpasoCHALLENGE. He wants people to carry out 22 random acts of kindness to honor the 22 victims of the mass shooting in El Paso, Texas. The 11-year-old was deeply impacted by the tragic event that unfolded in his community, and he decided to take action to help his city heal. "I wanted to do something to help those who were affected by the shooting," Ruben said. "I believe that kindness can bring people together and create positive change." His #elpasoCHALLENGE quickly gained traction on social media, with people from all over the world participating in spreading kindness in honor of the victims. From paying for someone's groceries to leaving a kind note for a stranger, the acts of kindness varied, but the message remained the same - unity and compassion in the face of tragedy. Ruben's initiative not only brought the community together but also shed light on the power of small gestures in making a big impact. As the #elpasoCHALLENGE continued to gather momentum, Ruben became a symbol of hope and resilience for his community. People were inspired by his selfless actions and commitment to spreading positivity in the wake of such a heart-wrenching event. Ruben's parents expressed their pride in their son's efforts, stating that he has always had a compassionate heart and a drive to help others. The impact of the #elpasoCHALLENGE extended far beyond the borders of El Paso, resonating with people around the world who were moved by Ruben's story. Messages of support poured in from various countries, with individuals sharing their own acts of kindness inspired by the young boy's initiative. Despite the tragedy that struck his community, Ruben's actions serve as a reminder that there is still goodness and light in the world. His unwavering optimism and dedication to spreading kindness in the face of adversity have inspired many to do the same, fostering a sense of unity and compassion in a time of grief. As the #elpasoCHALLENGE continues to gain momentum, Ruben remains committed to his mission of bringing people together through acts of kindness. He hopes that his initiative will not only honor the memory of the victims but also serve as a beacon of hope for a community healing from a devastating loss. Ruben's simple yet powerful message resonates loud and clear - in the face of darkness, kindness will always prevail.

title: NSA workers disciplined over Snowden leaks
text: The employee was among three NSA workers sanctioned over the incident, according to an NSA memo. It is said to be the first disciplinary action taken over the breach, which saw Mr Snowden leak details of US electronic surveillance programmes. The memo, which was leaked to the press, revealed that the three workers had been found to have violated agency policies by improperly accessing and disclosing classified information. The employee in question was identified as a contractor who had been working at the NSA for several years. The sanctions imposed on the workers included reprimands, suspensions, and in the case of the contractor, the termination of their contract. The memo stated that the actions of the employees had "weakened national security" and "compromised the integrity of the agency". In response to the disciplinary action, the NSA released a statement saying that it took "very seriously" the responsibility to protect classified information and would not tolerate any breaches of security. The agency also reiterated its commitment to ensuring that all employees and contractors adhere to the highest standards of professionalism and integrity. The NSA has faced intense scrutiny and criticism since the Snowden leaks in 2013, which exposed the extent of the agency's surveillance activities both domestically and internationally. The revelations sparked a global debate about privacy, security, and the role of government in collecting and monitoring electronic communications. Edward Snowden, a former NSA contractor, had worked at the agency for several years before fleeing to Hong Kong and then Moscow to avoid prosecution in the United States. He has been hailed as a hero by some for exposing what they see as government overreach and violations of civil liberties, while others consider him a traitor for compromising national security. The fallout from the Snowden leaks continues to reverberate, with ongoing legal battles, congressional hearings, and public debates about the balance between security and privacy. The disciplinary action taken against the three NSA workers is just the latest chapter in a saga that has fundamentally changed the way the world thinks about surveillance and the power of governments to monitor their citizens. As the debate rages on, one thing is clear: the Snowden leaks have had a profound impact on the NSA and its employees, leading to increased scrutiny, oversight, and accountability. Only time will tell how the agency and its workers will adapt to the new realities of a post-Snowden world.

title: Government won't be rushed on Swansea tidal on lagoon, says minister
text: Business minister Lord Henley spoke more than a year after a government-commissioned report backed the scheme. "A decision will be taken at the appropriate time," he said. The proposed Swansea Bay tidal lagoon project has been a topic of much debate and discussion in recent years, with its potential to harness renewable energy from the tides proving both promising and controversial. The project, which involves constructing a six-mile breakwater wall around Swansea Bay and installing turbines to generate electricity from the ebb and flow of the tides, has been hailed as a pioneering venture in sustainable energy. Proponents argue that it could provide clean, reliable power to thousands of homes and help reduce the UK's carbon footprint. However, critics have raised concerns about the costs involved in building and maintaining the lagoon, as well as its impact on the local environment and wildlife. Some have questioned whether the project is financially viable, given the significant upfront investment required and uncertainties over future energy prices. Despite these challenges, the government-commissioned Hendry Review in 2017 concluded that the benefits of the Swansea Bay tidal lagoon outweighed the costs, describing it as a "no regrets policy". The review highlighted the potential of tidal lagoons to contribute to the UK's energy mix and help meet climate change targets. Since then, there has been growing pressure on the government to make a decision on the project, with supporters calling for swift action to unlock the lagoon's potential and demonstrate the UK's commitment to renewable energy. However, Lord Henley's recent comments suggest that the government is taking a cautious approach and will not be rushed into a decision. "We need to carefully consider all the evidence and implications of the Swansea Bay tidal lagoon project before making a decision," Lord Henley said. He emphasized the need to balance the potential benefits of the lagoon with concerns over its costs and environmental impact, highlighting the complexity of the decision-making process. As the debate over the Swansea Bay tidal lagoon continues, stakeholders on all sides are eagerly awaiting the government's final verdict. The decision will not only have significant implications for the future of renewable energy in the UK but also set a precedent for similar projects around the world. In the meantime, the government remains committed to exploring a range of energy options to meet the country's growing demand for power while reducing its reliance on fossil fuels. The Swansea Bay tidal lagoon project could play a key role in this transition, but only time will tell whether it will become a reality.

title: Manila district police force removed after teen deaths
text: Albayalde's announcement came after two unarmed teenagers were killed in separate incidents by Caloocan police officers earlier this month. The first case involved 17-year-old Kian Loyd delos Santos, who was shot dead during a raid on a shanty town. CCTV footage later showed officers dragging the teenager away before shooting him. The second case involved 19-year-old Carl Angelo Arnaiz, whose body was found in a morgue after he allegedly robbed a taxi driver and engaged in a shootout with police. However, witnesses and Arnaiz's family disputed the police's version of events, leading to calls for a thorough investigation into both incidents. The deaths of these teenagers have reignited public outrage over the conduct of the police force in the Philippines, particularly in relation to Duterte's brutal anti-drugs campaign. Since taking office in June 2016, the President has waged a deadly war on drugs that has claimed thousands of lives, most of them from the country's poor and marginalized communities. Activists and human rights groups have long accused the police of carrying out extrajudicial killings and targeted assassinations under the guise of the anti-drugs campaign. The deaths of delos Santos and Arnaiz have further galvanized calls for accountability and reform within the Philippine National Police. Albayalde's decision to retrain and reassign the entire Caloocan district police force is a step in the right direction, but many are skeptical of whether this move will address the deeper systemic issues within the police force. Critics argue that Duterte's uncompromising rhetoric and encouragement of violent tactics have created a culture of impunity within law enforcement, leading to abuses of power and human rights violations. The Philippine Commission on Human Rights has launched an investigation into the deaths of delos Santos and Arnaiz, and has called for the prosecution of those responsible for their killings. The international community has also expressed concern over the deteriorating human rights situation in the Philippines, with several countries and organizations calling for an independent inquiry into the extrajudicial killings and other abuses linked to Duterte's war on drugs. As the Philippines grapples with the fallout from these tragic incidents, the question remains whether the retraining of police officers and the promise of reforms will be enough to restore public trust in the police force and bring justice to the victims of extrajudicial killings. Only time will tell if the Philippine government is truly committed to upholding the rule of law and protecting the rights of all its citizens.

title: Stars stay silent in X Factor protest
text: By Ian Youngs Entertainment reporter, BBC News Madness star Suggs and dance acts Orbital and Pendulum were among those who did nothing in a recording studio on Monday night, in a protest against what they see as the unfair treatment of contestants on ITV's The X Factor. The musicians, along with several other artists, remained silent throughout the recording session, refusing to sing or play their instruments. They held signs that read "Justice for all X Factor contestants" and "Stop the exploitation" as they stood in solidarity with the contestants who have faced criticism and backlash from judges and viewers alike. The protest comes after a series of controversial moments on the show, including judges' harsh criticisms of contestants and the public backlash against certain performers. Many fans of The X Factor have taken to social media to express their frustration with the judges' comments, calling for a more supportive and positive environment for the contestants. Speaking to BBC News, Suggs explained the reasons behind the protest: "We feel that the contestants on The X Factor are being unfairly judged and criticized for simply trying to pursue their dreams. It's important to remember that these are real people with real feelings, and they deserve to be treated with respect and encouragement, not ridicule and scorn." Orbital and Pendulum also voiced their support for the protest, emphasizing the need for a more compassionate and understanding approach to talent shows like The X Factor. "We believe that music should be a platform for creativity and expression, not a battleground for harsh judgment and negativity," they said in a joint statement. The protest drew attention from passersby and onlookers, with many showing their support for the musicians' stance. Some fans even joined in the silence, standing alongside the artists with signs of their own. As the recording session came to an end, the artists broke their silence and shared a message of solidarity with the contestants of The X Factor. They urged viewers and critics to think about the impact of their words and actions on the contestants' mental health and well-being. The protest marks a significant moment in the ongoing debate around reality talent shows and their treatment of contestants. With stars like Suggs, Orbital, and Pendulum using their platform to speak out against injustice, it is clear that change is needed in the industry to ensure a more supportive and nurturing environment for aspiring musicians and performers. As the stars left the studio, their message rang loud and clear: it's time for The X Factor and similar shows to listen and learn from the voices of those who are most affected by their actions. Only then can real change be achieved in the world of reality TV competitions.

title: Monmouthshire and Newport get 30 new electric car points
text: A new scheme will provide free installation to 20 businesses, thanks to funding from the EU, Welsh Government, and Monmouthshire Council. Ten more will be installed in Newport, as part of a joint effort to boost electric car usage in the region. This initiative aims to encourage more people to switch to electric vehicles by making it easier for them to charge their cars while they are out and about. Currently, Monmouthshire has just a handful of electric car charging points, making it difficult for drivers of electric vehicles to find convenient places to charge up. By adding 30 new charging points to the area, the hope is that more people will feel confident in making the switch to electric cars, knowing that they will have access to charging facilities wherever they go. The new charging points will be installed in strategic locations throughout Monmouthshire and Newport, including popular tourist spots, shopping centers, and business districts. This will make it even easier for people to charge their cars while they are at work, running errands, or exploring the local area. In addition to the free installation of the charging points, the scheme will also provide financial incentives for businesses that choose to install a charging point on their premises. This will not only benefit the businesses themselves by attracting more customers who drive electric vehicles but will also help to create a network of charging points that covers the entire region. Local authorities in Monmouthshire and Newport are excited about the potential benefits of this scheme. They see it as a way to reduce air pollution, combat climate change, and support the growth of the electric vehicle industry. By investing in electric car infrastructure now, they hope to set a positive example for other regions and encourage more people to make the switch to electric vehicles in the future. The project is set to begin in the coming months, with the first charging points expected to be installed by the end of the year. Local residents and businesses are encouraged to provide input on where the charging points should be located, to ensure that they are easily accessible to everyone who needs them. Overall, this new scheme represents a significant step forward in the efforts to promote sustainable transportation in Monmouthshire and Newport. By investing in electric car infrastructure and creating a network of charging points, these communities are setting themselves up for a greener, more sustainable future.

title: The Apprentice: Series launch down 900,000 viewers
text: Thursday evening's opening episode on BBC One attracted an average of 5.5 million viewers, a 26.3% share of the available viewing audience. The Apprentice: Series launch down 900,000 viewers compared to last year's premiere, signaling a potential shift in audience interest for the long-running reality show. Despite the decline in viewership, The Apprentice continued to provide its signature mix of drama, tension, and one-liners from business mogul Lord Alan Sugar. The contestants, vying for a chance to work alongside Lord Sugar and potentially win a £250,000 investment in their own business, faced their first challenge in the form of a chocolate-making task. As the candidates scrambled to impress Lord Sugar with their business acumen and creativity, tensions ran high and alliances began to form. The pressure of the boardroom loomed over the contestants, with each decision and mistake scrutinized by Lord Sugar and his trusted aides, Karren Brady and Claude Littner. While the premiere episode set the stage for what promises to be a competitive and entertaining series, the drop in viewership is a concern for producers. The Apprentice has been a staple of the BBC's programming for over a decade, with viewers tuning in each year to watch aspiring entrepreneurs navigate the challenges of the business world. The reasons behind the decline in viewership are not immediately clear, but some critics have pointed to the saturation of reality TV shows in the current market. With an abundance of competition from streaming services and alternative forms of entertainment, viewers may be opting to tune into other programs instead of The Apprentice. Despite the challenges of retaining viewers in a rapidly changing media landscape, The Apprentice remains a popular and enduring series for the BBC. Lord Sugar's no-nonsense approach to business, combined with the high-stakes challenges and dramatic boardroom firings, continues to attract a loyal fan base who eagerly await each new season. As the series progresses and the remaining candidates compete for Lord Sugar's investment, it remains to be seen whether The Apprentice can regain lost viewership and capture the attention of a new generation of viewers. With its unique blend of competition, drama, and business acumen, The Apprentice is sure to keep audiences guessing and entertained until the final episode.

title: Jlloyd Samuel death: Footballer's body 'too burnt' for visual ID
text: Warrington Coroner's Court heard Samuel died when his Range Rover crashed with another vehicle in Cheshire last May, but the crash was not suspicious. Coroner Alan Moore concluded that the cause of death was multiple injuries due to a road traffic collision. The court also heard that Samuel's body was so badly burnt in the fire that followed the crash that visual identification was not possible. Samuel, 37, was a former professional footballer who played for Aston Villa and Bolton Wanderers. He was born in Trinidad and Tobago but represented England at youth level. His sudden and tragic death shocked the football community and left his family, friends, and fans in mourning. The collision occurred on a quiet country road in High Legh, near Warrington, on the morning of May 15th. Samuel's Range Rover collided head-on with a van, and both vehicles caught fire. Despite the efforts of emergency services, Samuel was pronounced dead at the scene. The court heard from witnesses who described the harrowing scene of the crash and the subsequent fire. One witness, who was driving behind Samuel's Range Rover, described seeing the vehicle lose control and collide with the van before bursting into flames. Another witness, a passerby who stopped to help, described trying to extinguish the fire with a fire extinguisher but being unable to save Samuel. The court also heard from experts who explained the extent of the fire damage to Samuel's body, making visual identification impossible. Instead, DNA evidence and dental records were used to confirm his identity. Samuel's family and friends, including his former teammates and coaches, were present at the court hearing. They paid tribute to him as a talented and dedicated footballer who was respected and loved by all who knew him. Following the conclusion of the inquest, a statement was released on behalf of Samuel's family, thanking the coroner and the emergency services for their thorough investigation and support. The family requested privacy as they continue to grieve the loss of their beloved son, brother, and friend. The tragic death of Jlloyd Samuel serves as a reminder of the fragility of life and the unpredictable nature of accidents. The footballing community has come together to mourn his loss and celebrate his legacy, as a talented player and a beloved friend.

title: Titanic menu expected to fetch up to £70,000 at auction
text: It was owned by Elise Lurette, who was one of about 700 people who survived after the passenger liner hit an iceberg. The menu, which is expected to fetch up to £70,000 at auction, provides a fascinating glimpse into the luxurious dining experience aboard the ill-fated Titanic. The menu features a lavish spread of dishes, from oysters and filet mignon to champagne and pastry cigars. It reflects the opulence and wealth of the ship's first-class passengers, who dined in style as they journeyed across the Atlantic Ocean. Elise Lurette, a French passenger aboard the Titanic, likely held onto the menu as a memento of her miraculous escape from the sinking ship. Her survival on that fateful night in April 1912 is a testament to her strength and resilience in the face of disaster. The auction of the Titanic menu is expected to attract a great deal of interest from collectors and history enthusiasts alike. The artifacts from the Titanic hold a special significance, as they provide a tangible connection to the tragic events of that night over a century ago. The Titanic remains one of the most iconic shipwrecks in history, a symbol of both human ingenuity and hubris. Its story continues to captivate people around the world, as they seek to understand the lives lost and lessons learned from that tragic event. The menu from the Titanic offers a glimpse into the world of luxury and privilege aboard the ship, but it also serves as a reminder of the fragility of life and the unpredictability of fate. Elise Lurette's survival and the preservation of the menu tell a story of resilience and remembrance in the face of tragedy. As the auction for the Titanic menu approaches, bidders will have the opportunity to own a piece of history and to honor the memory of those who perished aboard the doomed ocean liner. The menu may be just a piece of paper, but its value lies in the stories it holds and the connection it provides to a bygone era. In the end, the Titanic menu serves as a poignant reminder of the lives lost and the stories untold from that tragic night at sea. It is a testament to the enduring legacy of the Titanic and the people who were aboard, a reminder that their memory lives on in artifacts like this menu, preserved for future generations to remember and honor.

title: Shetland Super Puma crash: Co-pilot's actions 'crucial' to survival
text: Super Puma passengers Sarah Darnley, 45, from Elgin, Gary McCrossan, 59, from Inverness, Duncan Munro, 46, from Bishop Auckland, and George Allison, 57, from Winchester, died in 2013. A total of 18 people were on board. A crash investigator said that the actions of the co-pilot were crucial to the survival of those who managed to escape the crash. The co-pilot, whose name was not mentioned in the report, had displayed exceptional skill and quick thinking during the emergency landing of the Super Puma helicopter. As the aircraft began to experience difficulties, he immediately took control and made a split-second decision to attempt an emergency landing on the water. His actions allowed several passengers to escape the sinking helicopter before it plunged beneath the waves. The co-pilot managed to open the emergency exits and helped passengers evacuate the aircraft, effectively saving their lives in the process. Despite the tragic loss of four lives, the crash investigator emphasized the importance of the co-pilot's actions in ensuring the survival of the other passengers. Without his quick thinking and decisive actions, the outcome could have been much worse. The investigation into the crash revealed that the cause of the accident was a gearbox failure, which led to the helicopter losing power and ultimately crashing into the sea. The report also highlighted the importance of regular maintenance checks and proper oversight of aircraft components to prevent similar incidents in the future. The families of the victims expressed their gratitude to the co-pilot for his heroic efforts in the face of a life-threatening situation. They praised his bravery and selflessness, acknowledging that his actions had made a significant difference in the outcome of the crash. In the aftermath of the tragedy, the aviation industry reevaluated safety procedures and protocols to enhance passenger protection in similar emergencies. Lessons were learned from the Super Puma crash, leading to improvements in training, equipment, and maintenance practices across the sector. As the co-pilot's story emerged, he was hailed as a hero and a shining example of professionalism and courage in the face of adversity. His actions served as a reminder of the importance of well-trained and capable flight crew in ensuring the safety and well-being of passengers during air travel. The legacy of the Super Puma crash lives on in the hearts and minds of those affected by the tragedy, with the co-pilot's actions serving as a beacon of hope and inspiration in the darkest of moments.

title: Councils reject two-thirds of requests for care
text: By Nick Triggle Health correspondent Nearly 1.85 million requests for support were made last year, but just over 650,000 people received help. Councils have been warning for a number of years that a shortage of funding is causing problems. The stark reality is that local authorities are being forced to make tough decisions about who gets access to social care services, leaving many vulnerable individuals without the support they desperately need. The latest figures show that councils across the country are rejecting two-thirds of requests for care, leaving a significant number of elderly and disabled individuals struggling to cope on their own. This is deeply concerning, as these individuals rely on social care services to maintain their independence and quality of life. Councils have been facing unprecedented pressures due to increasing demand for services and budget cuts imposed by central government. Many local authorities are struggling to balance their budgets, leading to a situation where they are forced to limit access to care services to only the most severe cases. The impact of these decisions is being felt by individuals and families across the country. Many people who are ineligible for social care services are left to fend for themselves, relying on family members or friends for support. This places additional strain on carers and can have a detrimental effect on the well-being of both the individual in need of care and their caregivers. The lack of access to social care services is not only a humanitarian issue but also has wider implications for the healthcare system as a whole. Without adequate support, individuals are more likely to require emergency medical care, leading to increased pressure on hospitals and other healthcare services. Councils are calling for urgent action from the government to address the funding crisis in social care. They argue that without additional funding, the situation will only worsen, leaving more vulnerable individuals without the support they need to live independently. In response, the government has pledged to increase funding for social care services, but many councils argue that this is not enough to meet the growing demand. They are calling for a long-term solution that addresses the underlying funding issues and ensures that all individuals have access to the care and support they need. The current situation is unsustainable and is having a devastating impact on the lives of thousands of individuals. Without urgent action from the government, the crisis in social care is only set to worsen, leaving more vulnerable individuals without the support they need to live with dignity and independence.

title: Japan frees Chinese boat captain amid diplomatic row
text: communications with Japan over the incident. After weeks of heightened tensions between the two countries, Japan decided to release Zhan Qixiong, the Chinese boat captain, in a move aimed at defusing the escalating diplomatic row. The decision to free Zhan Qixiong came after intense negotiations between Japanese and Chinese officials, with both sides keen to find a resolution to the standoff. Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe emphasized the importance of maintaining stable relations with China, a major economic partner for Japan. He stated that Japan's priority was to prioritize dialogue and cooperation in order to prevent the situation from escalating further. Zhan Qixiong's release was met with relief in China, where his detention had sparked outrage among the Chinese public. The Chinese government had demanded his immediate release and threatened to take further action if Japan did not comply. The resolution of the crisis was seen as a positive step towards easing tensions between the two countries. However, the underlying territorial dispute over the islands in the East China Sea remains unresolved. The islands, known as the Senkaku Islands in Japan and the Diaoyu Islands in China, have long been a source of contention between the two countries. Both Japan and China claim sovereignty over the islands, which are believed to be rich in natural resources. The incident involving Zhan Qixiong's boat had reignited territorial tensions between Japan and China, leading to a war of words between the two governments. China accused Japan of violating its territorial waters and infringing on its sovereignty, while Japan insisted that it was acting in accordance with international law. Despite Zhan Qixiong's release, the underlying issues that led to his detention remain unresolved. The dispute over the islands in the East China Sea continues to simmer, with both countries unwilling to back down on their claims. The release of Zhan Qixiong may have defused the immediate crisis, but a long-term solution to the territorial dispute remains elusive. As tensions between Japan and China persist, the international community is closely monitoring the situation. The East China Sea is a strategically important region, and any escalation of the dispute could have far-reaching implications for regional security and stability. Both Japan and China will need to find a way to resolve their differences peacefully in order to avoid further confrontations in the future.

title: Solar Impulse aeroplane reaches Ohio
text: The zero-fuel aircraft arrived in Dayton at 21:56 local time (01:56 GMT) having flown from Tulsa, Oklahoma. The 1,113km journey took pilot Andre Borschberg over fields, cities, and highways, showcasing the capabilities of solar-powered flight. Borschberg expressed his delight at successfully completing another leg of the journey, highlighting the importance of sustainable transportation options. He emphasized the need to continue to innovate and explore alternative energy sources to reduce our carbon footprint and combat climate change. The Solar Impulse aeroplane has been making headlines around the world for its groundbreaking mission to circumnavigate the globe using only solar power. This innovative project aims to demonstrate the potential of clean technologies and renewable energy sources in aviation. In addition to promoting sustainability, the Solar Impulse team has been engaging with local communities along the way to raise awareness about the importance of environmental conservation. In Ohio, the team will be hosting educational events and outreach programs to inspire and educate people about the possibilities of clean energy. The next leg of the journey will take the Solar Impulse aeroplane from Dayton to Lehigh Valley, Pennsylvania, covering a distance of approximately 600km. The team is optimistic about the upcoming flight and looks forward to continuing their mission of promoting clean energy and sustainability. The Solar Impulse project has already completed several successful legs, including flights across the Pacific Ocean and through Europe. With each journey, the team is proving that solar power can be a reliable and efficient source of energy for aviation, paving the way for a more sustainable future. As the Solar Impulse aeroplane prepares to depart from Dayton and continue its journey across the United States, it serves as a reminder of the potential for innovation and progress in the field of renewable energy. By pushing the boundaries of what is possible, the Solar Impulse team is inspiring a new generation of thinkers and innovators to dream big and work towards a greener, more sustainable world. With each successful flight, the Solar Impulse project is proving that clean energy solutions are not only feasible but essential for the future of aviation and transportation. As the aeroplane takes off once again, heading towards its next destination, the world watches in awe and anticipation, eager to see what the future holds for solar-powered flight.

title: Virgin's Unity plane rockets skyward
text: closer to its goal of taking paying customers to the edge of space. The Unity plane, part of Richard Branson's Virgin Galactic fleet, is designed to carry up to six passengers on suborbital spaceflights, allowing them to experience a few minutes of weightlessness and see the curvature of the Earth from above. This latest test flight was a crucial step in proving the vehicle's capabilities and safety for future commercial operations. During the flight, Unity was released from its carrier aircraft, WhiteKnightTwo, at an altitude of around 50,000 feet. The pilots then ignited the rocket motor, propelling the plane to almost three times the speed of sound as it climbed steeply towards the edge of space. Reaching an altitude of nearly 90 kilometers, Unity briefly entered space before beginning its descent back to Earth. As it re-entered the atmosphere, the pilots executed a series of maneuvers to control the vehicle's speed and trajectory, ensuring a smooth and controlled return to the runway. The successful test flight demonstrated Unity's ability to reach space and return safely, a key milestone for Virgin Galactic as it prepares to begin commercial operations. With over 600 reservations already booked for future suborbital flights, the company is eager to start flying paying customers to the edge of space. Richard Branson, founder of Virgin Group, expressed his excitement and pride in the team's achievement, praising the pilots and engineers who made the test flight possible. He emphasized the importance of pushing the boundaries of space exploration and tourism, inspiring more people to experience the wonders of space. As Virgin Galactic continues to test and refine its spaceplane technology, the company is on track to begin regular commercial flights in the near future. With each successful test flight, Virgin Galactic moves closer to its ultimate goal of making space travel accessible to everyone, opening up a new era of space tourism and exploration. The Unity plane's latest flight marks a significant step forward in Virgin Galactic's journey towards commercial space travel. With each successful test, the company gets one step closer to fulfilling its vision of taking paying customers on unforgettable journeys to the edge of space.

title: Mobile mast size rules relaxed for better coverage across Wales
text: Masts of up to 25m will no longer need to go through the full planning permission process from April. This change in regulations aims to improve mobile coverage across Wales, making it easier for telecommunication companies to install the necessary infrastructure to provide better connectivity to residents in rural areas. The Welsh government has relaxed the rules in an effort to address the issue of poor mobile connectivity in remote regions of the country. Currently, many rural communities in Wales struggle with slow internet speeds and dropped calls due to inadequate mobile mast coverage. By allowing taller masts to be installed without the need for full planning permission, the government hopes to expedite the process of improving mobile coverage across the country. Under the new regulations, mobile operators will be able to install masts up to 25m in height without having to apply for full planning permission. This will make it easier for companies to deploy infrastructure and improve connectivity in areas where signal strength is weak or non-existent. The government believes that by streamlining the planning process, mobile operators will be able to provide better coverage to residents in rural areas quicker and more efficiently. However, some concerns have been raised about the impact of taller masts on the landscape and the potential for visual pollution. Critics argue that allowing taller masts to be installed without full planning permission could lead to an increase in the number of unsightly structures dotting the countryside. They also worry about the potential health effects of living near taller masts, although research on the topic has been inconclusive. Despite these concerns, the Welsh government is confident that the benefits of the new regulations outweigh the potential drawbacks. By relaxing the rules around mast height, the government hopes to improve mobile coverage across Wales and bring much-needed connectivity to rural communities. Access to fast and reliable internet is essential in our increasingly digital world, and the government is committed to ensuring that all residents have access to the technology they need to thrive. In conclusion, the relaxation of mobile mast size rules in Wales is a positive step towards improving connectivity across the country. By making it easier for mobile operators to install taller masts without full planning permission, the government hopes to address the issue of poor mobile coverage in rural areas. While some concerns have been raised about the impact of taller masts on the landscape, the government is confident that the benefits of better mobile coverage will ultimately outweigh any potential drawbacks.

title: Steve Easterbrook's new McJob
text: By Jamie Robertson Presenter, BBC World News The former Watford Grammar School boy is seen as the man who revitalised the group's UK business. And McDonald's needs a turnaround specialist as it struggles with its image, assailed by meat scandals. Steve Easterbrook's new McJob is going to be a tough challenge, but one that he seems well-equipped to handle. Easterbrook, who has spent most of his career in the fast-food industry, is no stranger to the pressures of turning around struggling businesses. His previous role as the CEO of McDonald's UK saw him successfully implement a number of changes that helped to boost sales and improve customer satisfaction. Now, as the new Global CEO of McDonald's, Easterbrook will be taking on an even bigger challenge. One of the key issues facing McDonald's is its reputation for selling unhealthy food. With growing concerns about obesity and the impact of a high-fat, high-sugar diet on public health, the fast-food giant has come under increasing pressure to change its menu and cater to a more health-conscious consumer base. Easterbrook will need to find a way to balance the core products that have made McDonald's so successful with a new focus on healthier options. In addition to the health concerns, McDonald's has also faced criticism for its treatment of workers. Low wages and poor working conditions have led to protests and strikes in several countries, with many employees demanding a living wage and better benefits. Easterbrook will need to address these issues head-on and find a way to improve conditions for McDonald's workers while maintaining profitability for the company. Despite these challenges, Easterbrook remains optimistic about his new role and the future of McDonald's. In a recent interview, he spoke about his commitment to making the company more sustainable and socially responsible, and his belief that McDonald's can continue to be a leader in the fast-food industry. "I am excited to take on this new challenge and build on the strong foundation that has been laid by my predecessors," Easterbrook said. "I believe that with the right leadership and vision, McDonald's can continue to thrive and grow for many years to come." Only time will tell if Easterbrook's optimism is well-founded. But with his track record of success and his proven leadership skills, there is reason to believe that he may just be the right person to lead McDonald's into a new era of growth and prosperity.

title: Church of England to keep Amazon shares despite Welby criticism
text: The Church Times has revealed Amazon was among the 20 biggest global investments by the Church last year. A statement from the CofE said it considered the most effective way to seek change was to be actively engaged with companies as a shareholder, rather than divesting from them. This decision comes despite criticism from the Archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby, who has previously spoken out against the tech giant's tax practices and treatment of workers. In response to the Church's decision to keep their shares in Amazon, a spokesperson for Welby reiterated his concerns, stating that the Archbishop believes the Church should lead by example and stand up for its values, even if it means sacrificing financial gains. The spokesperson also pointed out that Welby has called for greater transparency and accountability from companies like Amazon, and holding shares in the company could compromise the Church's ability to advocate for change. The debate over the Church's investment in Amazon is part of a larger conversation about the role of institutional investors in promoting ethical business practices. Some argue that divestment is the most effective way to send a message to companies that their actions are unacceptable, while others believe that engagement and dialogue can lead to more meaningful change from within. The Church of England has a long history of using its shareholder power to influence companies on issues such as climate change, executive pay, and human rights. In recent years, the Church has successfully engaged with companies like BP and Shell to address concerns about their environmental impact and governance practices. However, critics argue that in the case of Amazon, engagement may not be enough to prompt meaningful change, given the company's size and influence. Despite the controversy surrounding its investment in Amazon, the Church of England remains committed to using its shareholder power for positive change. In its statement, the Church emphasized the need for ongoing engagement with companies to drive ethical behavior and positive social impact. The decision to keep shares in Amazon may be seen as a strategic move to continue pressing the company on issues of concern, while also ensuring a seat at the table to advocate for change from within. As the Church of England grapples with the complexities of ethical investing in the modern world, the debate over its investment in Amazon serves as a reminder of the challenges and opportunities that come with being a responsible shareholder in today's global economy. Ultimately, the decision to keep shares in Amazon reflects the Church's commitment to using its influence for good, even when faced with difficult choices and competing priorities.

title: UK unemployment rises to 1.7m
text: That is the first increase since the May-July period of last year. The unemployment rate remained at 5.1%, which is still down on the same time last year, when it was 5.6%. Earnings, including bonuses rose by 1.8% in the three months to January, but this was below the rate of inflation, which stood at 2%. This means that in real terms, people's pay packets are not keeping up with the rising cost of living. The increase in unemployment can be attributed to a variety of factors, including the ongoing impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. Many businesses have been forced to close or reduce their operations due to lockdown restrictions, leading to job losses across the country. In addition, the furlough scheme, which has been supporting millions of workers throughout the pandemic, has started to wind down, leaving some employees vulnerable to redundancy. The sectors most affected by the rise in unemployment include hospitality, retail, and leisure, which have been hit hard by the restrictions on social gatherings and travel. Many workers in these industries are facing an uncertain future, as the UK economy continues to struggle with the ongoing effects of the pandemic. The government has acknowledged the challenges facing the labour market and has pledged to support those who have lost their jobs. Chancellor Rishi Sunak has announced a range of measures aimed at helping people back into work, including funding for job training and apprenticeships. However, critics argue that more needs to be done to prevent further job losses and support those who are struggling to find employment. Unemployment is not just a statistic – it represents real people who are feeling the financial and emotional strain of being out of work. Many families are facing difficult decisions about how to make ends meet, with some having to rely on food banks and other forms of assistance. The mental health implications of unemployment are also significant, with studies showing that job loss can lead to increased stress, anxiety, and depression. As the UK continues to navigate its way out of the pandemic, it is crucial that the government takes decisive action to support those who have been impacted by the rise in unemployment. By investing in job creation, skills training, and mental health support, the UK can work towards building a more resilient and inclusive economy for all its citizens.

title: Speeding drink-driver killed man in Aberdeen bus stop crash
text: Martin Henderson, 30, fled the scene after the crash which left father-of-three Allan Forbes, 70, dead last year. An 18-year-old woman who was also standing at the bus shelter in the Bucksburn area of Aberdeen was seriously injured and had to be taken to the hospital for treatment. This tragic incident shocked the local community and left many questioning the safety of the roads in the area. Henderson was found to be over the legal alcohol limit at the time of the accident, leading to him being charged with causing death by dangerous driving and failing to stop at the scene of a crash. His reckless actions not only resulted in the loss of a beloved member of the community but also endangered the lives of others who were present at the bus stop that fateful day. The court heard that Henderson had been speeding and lost control of his vehicle, causing it to veer off the road and crash into the bus shelter where Forbes and the young woman were waiting. Despite knowing the severity of the situation, Henderson chose to flee the scene instead of taking responsibility for his actions. This decision ultimately led to tragic consequences and left a family without a husband, father, and grandfather. During the trial, Henderson expressed remorse for his actions and acknowledged the pain and suffering he had caused. However, his words did little to console the grieving family of Allan Forbes, who described him as a kind-hearted man with a zest for life. The loss of Forbes was deeply felt by the community, with many attending his funeral to pay their respects and offer support to his family. In sentencing Henderson, the judge emphasized the seriousness of his crimes and the devastating impact they had on the victims and their loved ones. Henderson was given a lengthy prison sentence as a result of his reckless behavior, serving as a warning to others who choose to drink and drive. The tragic incident serves as a reminder of the dangers of speeding and driving under the influence of alcohol. It is essential for drivers to always prioritize safety on the roads and refrain from engaging in risky behaviors that can have catastrophic consequences. Allan Forbes will be remembered as a loving family man who was taken too soon, and his memory will live on in the hearts of those who knew and loved him.

title: Manchester Arena Inquiry: Area where Abedi hid 'not our domain'
text: Showsec supervisor David Middleton said he had never been instructed to check the mezzanine area. "We were to keep the steps clear and make sure the crowd flowed smoothly,” he told the Manchester Arena Inquiry on Tuesday. Middleton's statement comes as the inquiry continues to investigate the security arrangements at the arena on the night of the 2017 bombing that killed 22 people. Salman Abedi had reportedly concealed himself in the mezzanine area before detonating a homemade bomb at the end of an Ariana Grande concert. During his testimony, Middleton explained that security personnel were primarily focused on managing the crowd and ensuring that the flow of people entering and exiting the arena was controlled. He admitted that the mezzanine area was not within their area of responsibility and that he had never been given specific instructions to check that space. The inquiry has heard that Abedi was able to hide in the mezzanine area for almost an hour without being detected by security. This has raised questions about the effectiveness of the security measures in place at the arena that night. Middleton also mentioned that there were a limited number of security staff available that evening due to a shortage of resources. He described how Showsec had struggled to recruit and retain staff, which had an impact on their ability to adequately cover the arena and respond to potential threats. The inquiry has heard from other witnesses who have raised concerns about the lack of communication between security teams and the failure to share vital information about potential risks. There have been suggestions that a more coordinated approach to security could have prevented the attack. As the inquiry continues, the focus will likely turn to the role of the authorities in overseeing security at the arena and whether there were missed opportunities to prevent the bombing. The families of the victims are seeking answers about what went wrong that night and are hoping that the inquiry will lead to changes that will improve security at public events in the future. Middleton's testimony has highlighted the challenges faced by security staff in managing large crowds and the need for better communication and coordination between different agencies involved in public safety. The inquiry will continue to investigate these issues as it seeks to determine the factors that contributed to the tragic events at the Manchester Arena in 2017.

title: Sturgeon wants Indyref2 in 'second half of 2020'
text: Speaking in Dublin, Ms Sturgeon said the "latter half" of next year would be the "right time" for a new poll. The SNP leader predicted victory in a second independence referendum, citing the UK government's handling of Brexit as a major factor in her decision to push for Indyref2. "The chaos and confusion surrounding Brexit have only reinforced the need for Scotland to have a say on its own future," Ms Sturgeon stated. "The people of Scotland deserve the opportunity to choose a different path, one that is not dictated by Westminster." The First Minister outlined her vision for an independent Scotland, highlighting the country's strong economy, natural resources, and skilled workforce as key assets that would enable it to thrive as an independent nation. "Our country has the potential to be a beacon of progressive values, leading the way in areas such as renewable energy, social justice, and equality," Ms Sturgeon passionately declared. "Independence is not just about breaking away from the UK; it's about building a brighter future for all Scots." The announcement of Ms Sturgeon's plans for Indyref2 received mixed reactions from both supporters and opponents of Scottish independence. Pro-independence activists welcomed the news, viewing it as a long-awaited opportunity to secure Scotland's independence from the UK. "Finally, we have a chance to take back control of our own destiny," said one independence supporter. "Scotland has been held back for far too long by the Westminster government. It's time for us to stand on our own two feet and chart our own course." However, critics of independence argued that now is not the right time for another referendum, pointing to the uncertainty surrounding Brexit and the potential economic risks of separation from the UK. "We are already facing significant challenges with Brexit; adding independence to the mix would only deepen the division and instability," said a skeptic of Scottish independence. "Ms Sturgeon should focus on addressing the pressing issues facing Scotland today, rather than pursuing a divisive and uncertain path towards independence." Despite the differing opinions on the matter, one thing is clear: the debate over Scottish independence is far from over. As Ms Sturgeon pushes for Indyref2 in the second half of 2020, the people of Scotland will once again have the opportunity to make their voices heard and shape the future of their country.

title: Iraq Inquiry: PM urged to 'pull plug' on report
text: disbanded before any further time and resources were wasted. The former Attorney General under Tony Blair's government made these remarks during a heated debate in the House of Lords on the progress of the Iraq Inquiry. Lord Morris, who has been a vocal critic of the prolonged delays in releasing the report, went on to say that the British public deserved answers about the decisions that led to the invasion of Iraq and the subsequent occupation of the country. He urged Prime Minister David Cameron to intervene and "pull the plug" on the inquiry if it continued to drag its feet. The Chilcot Inquiry, as it is commonly known, was established in 2009 to investigate the UK's involvement in the Iraq War and to determine whether the decision to go to war was justified. However, after more than six years of hearings and evidence gathering, the report has yet to be published. Critics of the inquiry believe that political considerations and pressure from the government have contributed to the delays in releasing the report. They argue that the British public has a right to know the truth about the Iraq War and to hold those responsible for any wrongdoing to account. In response to Lord Morris's comments, a spokesperson for the Prime Minister stated that David Cameron shared the frustration of those who wanted to see the report published, but that it was ultimately up to Sir John Chilcot and his panel to determine the timeline for its release. Meanwhile, other members of the House of Lords expressed their dismay at the lack of progress in the inquiry. Lord Goldsmith, who served as Attorney General during the run-up to the Iraq War, admitted that he was "disappointed" by the delays and hoped that the report would be published soon. Despite the calls for the inquiry to be disbanded, some members of the House of Lords defended the work of Sir John Chilcot and his panel. Lord Owen argued that the complexity of the issues involved in the Iraq War required a thorough and comprehensive investigation, even if it meant taking longer than initially anticipated. As the debate in the House of Lords continued, it became clear that there were no easy answers to the questions surrounding the Iraq War. The calls for the inquiry to be "pulled" or for the report to be released immediately reflected the deep divisions and controversies that still linger over one of the most controversial conflicts in recent history. For now, the fate of the Chilcot Inquiry remains uncertain, and the British public continues to wait for answers.

title: Why are young Indians killing themselves?
text: Soutik Biswas Delhi correspondent If new research is to be believed, a disturbingly high number of young Indians are losing the battle with mental health issues, leading to a concerning increase in suicides across the country. The findings of a recent study conducted by the World Health Organization (WHO) revealed that India has one of the highest suicide rates in the world, with young people between the ages of 15 and 29 being particularly vulnerable. The report highlighted various factors contributing to this alarming trend, including academic pressure, relationship issues, financial stress, and social stigma surrounding mental health. One of the key reasons behind the rising suicide rates among young Indians is the intense pressure to perform well in academics. With a population of over a billion people and fierce competition for limited opportunities, students in India face tremendous stress to excel in school and secure a promising future. This pressure often leads to feelings of inadequacy, failure, and hopelessness, driving some young people to consider ending their lives as a way out of their troubles. Furthermore, relationship issues play a significant role in the mental health struggles of young Indians. Societal expectations regarding marriage, love, and family can create immense pressure on individuals, especially in a culture where arranged marriages are still prevalent. Failed relationships, unrequited love, and social disapproval can all take a toll on the emotional well-being of young people, pushing them towards despair and thoughts of suicide. Financial stress is another major factor contributing to the mental health crisis among young Indians. With rising living costs, job insecurity, and economic instability, many young people find themselves struggling to make ends meet. The burden of providing for themselves and their families can weigh heavily on their minds, exacerbating feelings of anxiety, depression, and hopelessness. Moreover, the persistent social stigma surrounding mental health in India makes it difficult for young people to seek help and support. The lack of awareness, education, and resources for mental health issues creates a barrier for those in need of assistance, leaving many young Indians to suffer in silence. In conclusion, the rising suicide rates among young Indians are a troubling reflection of the profound challenges facing this demographic in today's society. From academic pressure and relationship issues to financial stress and social stigma, the factors contributing to this crisis are complex and deeply entrenched. It is imperative for policymakers, educators, healthcare professionals, and the community at large to come together to address these issues and provide young people with the support, resources, and care they need to navigate the challenges of mental health and well-being in an increasingly demanding world. Only by working together can we hope to reverse the tide of young Indians taking their own lives and build a brighter future for the next generation.

title: Bulgarian writer wins BBC Short Story Award
text: prize for his story "Baida", which judges described as a "masterful exploration of love and loss" with "vivid imagery and haunting prose." Born and raised in Sofia, Penkov has been making waves in the literary world with his evocative storytelling and unique narrative voice. His work often draws from his own experiences growing up in post-communist Bulgaria, offering readers a glimpse into the complexities of life in Eastern Europe. "Winning the BBC Short Story Award is a dream come true for me," Penkov said in his acceptance speech. "I have always believed in the power of storytelling to bridge cultures and connect people from different parts of the world. This award is a validation of that belief, and I am grateful for the opportunity to share my stories with a global audience." Penkov's success is a testament to the growing popularity of Eastern European literature in the English-speaking world. With authors like Olga Tokarczuk and Hanya Yanagihara winning major literary awards in recent years, there is a renewed interest in stories that offer a fresh perspective on familiar themes. The BBC Short Story Award, now in its 16th year, aims to celebrate the best in contemporary short fiction from around the world. Past winners have included writers from Nigeria, India, and the United States, showcasing the diversity and talent of the international literary community. Penkov's win will undoubtedly bring more attention to Bulgarian literature and Eastern European storytelling, shining a spotlight on a region rich in history and culture.
