The protesters called for an end to austerity measures and a renewed focus on job creation and social welfare programs, arguing that these are the keys to restoring Italy's economic prosperity. As the crowd marched through the streets of Rome, chanting slogans and waving banners, it was clear that the people's frustration with the government's policies was reaching a boiling point. The rally served as a stark reminder to Letta and his coalition partners that they ignore the demands of the people at their own peril. In the coming weeks, Letta will face increasing pressure to reevaluate his government's economic agenda and respond to the concerns of the protesters. Whether he will be able to salvage his coalition and regain the trust of the public remains to be seen, but one thing is certain: the people of Italy are no longer willing to accept austerity measures as the only solution to their country's economic woes.

title: Tay Cities Deal £1.84bn plan to create 15,000 jobs
text: governments, in addition to funding from the private sector and local authorities. The plan is ambitious, aiming to create over 15,000 jobs and generate £760m in economic growth for the region. One of the key projects outlined in the submission is the development of a decommissioning hub for the oil and gas industry. With the North Sea oil fields reaching the end of their productive life, there is an increasing demand for dismantling and disposing of these facilities in an environmentally responsible manner. By investing in this sector, the Tay Cities Deal aims to position itself as a leader in decommissioning services, attracting companies from around the world and creating high-skilled jobs for the local workforce. In addition to the decommissioning hub, the submission document includes a range of infrastructure projects designed to improve connectivity and accessibility in the region. This includes upgrades to road and rail networks, as well as investments in digital infrastructure to support the growth of technology and innovation sectors. Another focus of the Tay Cities Deal is on supporting the regeneration of town centers and waterfront areas in Dundee, Perth, and surrounding towns. By investing in cultural and tourism initiatives, as well as creating new business spaces and housing developments, the plan aims to revitalize these areas and attract both residents and visitors to the region. Education and skills development are also key components of the Tay Cities Deal, with proposals for new training facilities and partnerships with local colleges and universities to ensure that the workforce is equipped to take on the jobs created by the plan. By investing in education, the region hopes to address skills shortages and provide opportunities for lifelong learning and career advancement. Overall, the Tay Cities Deal represents a significant investment in the future of the region, with a focus on sustainable economic growth and job creation. By leveraging public and private sector funding, as well as the expertise of local authorities and businesses, the plan aims to position the Tay Cities as a vibrant and competitive hub for industry, innovation, and culture in Scotland. As the submission moves forward for approval from the Scottish and UK governments, stakeholders in the region are optimistic about the potential for positive change and development that the Tay Cities Deal could bring. With a clear vision and detailed plan in place, the region is poised to take advantage of this opportunity to shape its future for the better.

title: Betsi health board chief criticises 'misleading' Tawel Fan claims
text: It made major criticisms but found no evidence of institutional abuse at the now-closed Tawel Fan ward for dementia patients at Glan Clwyd Hospital. The report, led by Donna Ockenden, highlighted a number of failings in the care provided at the ward, including poor leadership, inadequate staffing levels, and a lack of training for staff. However, Ockenden stressed that there was no evidence to suggest that abuse was systemic within the unit. Despite this, the chief executive of the Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board, Gary Doherty, has criticized what he described as "misleading" claims about the nature of the abuse at Tawel Fan. Doherty stated that while the board fully accepts the failings identified in the report, it is important to clarify that there was no evidence of widespread abuse or mistreatment of patients. In a statement released to the press, Doherty said, "While the Ockenden report makes clear that there were significant failings in the care provided at Tawel Fan, it is important to emphasize that there was no evidence of institutional abuse. It is misleading to suggest otherwise, as this undermines the hard work and dedication of the vast majority of staff who provide excellent care to patients every day." Doherty also highlighted the steps that the health board has taken to address the issues identified in the report, including the implementation of a new leadership team at Glan Clwyd Hospital and increased training for staff. He stressed that the board is fully committed to ensuring that the failings identified in the report are not repeated in the future. The Ockenden report was commissioned in 2015 following concerns raised by families of patients at Tawel Fan about the quality of care provided at the ward. The report took five years to complete and involved interviews with over 100 families, as well as an examination of thousands of documents relating to the care provided at the ward. While the report did not find evidence of systematic abuse, it did reveal a number of serious failings in the care provided to patients at Tawel Fan. These included patients being left in soiled clothing, inadequate pain relief, and poor communication between staff and patients. The findings of the report have led to calls for greater accountability within the health service, with many arguing that the failings at Tawel Fan should serve as a wake-up call for the entire healthcare system. The Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board has apologized for the failings identified in the report and has pledged to implement all of the recommendations made by Ockenden to ensure that such failings are not repeated in the future.

title: TEDGlobal: Burns portrait comes alive at TED
text: By Jane Wakefield Technology reporter, TEDGlobal, Edinburgh The demonstration was part of a session at the TEDGlobal (Technology, Entertainment and Design) conference that highlighted the fusion of art and technology. The audience was left in awe as they witnessed the iconic face of Scottish poet Robert Burns come alive in stunning 3D projection. The project, led by artist Sarah Kenderdine, used cutting-edge technology to create a lifelike representation of Burns, complete with subtle facial expressions and movements. Kenderdine explained that the goal was to bring history to life in a way that is engaging and immersive for the audience. The interactive nature of the presentation allowed attendees to explore different aspects of Burns' life and work. They could zoom in on details of his face, hear his poetry recited in his own voice, and even interact with the virtual portrait through gestures and voice commands. The project was a collaboration between artists, historians, and technologists, who worked together to ensure that the virtual portrait was as accurate and authentic as possible. By combining historical research with advanced digital techniques, they were able to create a truly captivating experience that bridged the gap between past and present. As Kenderdine explained, "Technology has the power to transform the way we interact with art and history. By using digital tools, we can bring the past to life in ways that were never before possible." The audience at TEDGlobal was not only impressed by the technical prowess of the project but also moved by the emotional impact of seeing Burns' portrait come alive. Many expressed their appreciation for the innovative approach to storytelling and the way it sparked their curiosity about history and literature. One attendee, a literature enthusiast from Glasgow, described the experience as "absolutely breathtaking." She added, "It's incredible to see how technology can enhance our understanding of the past and make it more accessible to a wider audience." The session concluded with a lively Q&A session, during which audience members had the opportunity to ask questions and interact with the creators of the project. The discussion touched on topics ranging from the challenges of historical accuracy in digital representations to the potential applications of this technology in museums and educational settings. Overall, the demonstration of Burns' portrait at TEDGlobal was a testament to the power of art and technology to inspire, educate, and entertain. It left a lasting impression on all who attended, reminding them of the endless possibilities that lie at the intersection of creativity and innovation.

title: France's Macron calls for 'historic reconstruction' of Europe
text: Speaking in Berlin on the first full day of his presidency, he was joined by German Chancellor Angela Merkel. She said the pair had a shared vision for the future of Europe and were committed to working together to bring about positive change. Macron's call for a "historic reconstruction" of Europe comes at a crucial time for the European Union. With the rise of nationalist and populist movements across the continent, there is a growing sense of division and instability. Macron recognizes the need for the EU to evolve and adapt to these challenges in order to maintain its relevance and effectiveness. One of the key issues Macron highlighted in his speech was the need for greater cooperation on security and defense. He called for a joint European defense force and a common asylum policy to address the ongoing refugee crisis. Macron's proposal for a "European sovereignty" would see member states pooling their resources and working together to tackle common threats and challenges. In addition to security and defense, Macron also emphasized the importance of economic reform and social cohesion within the EU. He called for a more integrated and balanced economic union, with greater investment in infrastructure, innovation, and sustainable growth. Macron stressed the need to address economic disparities between member states and promote social justice and equal opportunity for all Europeans. Macron's vision for Europe is one of unity, solidarity, and progress. He sees the EU as a force for good in the world, promoting peace, stability, and prosperity. Macron's ambitious agenda for the EU includes reforms to the eurozone, closer cooperation on climate change and environmental protection, and a stronger role for Europe on the global stage. In response to Macron's speech, Chancellor Merkel expressed her support for his proposals and pledged to work closely with France to bring about positive change in Europe. Merkel emphasized the importance of Franco-German cooperation in shaping the future of the EU and overcoming the current challenges facing the continent. The meeting between Macron and Merkel in Berlin marks the beginning of a new era in European politics. With a renewed focus on unity, solidarity, and progress, Macron's presidency promises to bring about significant changes in the EU and reinvigorate the European project. As Macron embarks on his efforts to reform and rebuild Europe, he faces numerous challenges and obstacles. However, with the support of Chancellor Merkel and a strong commitment to his vision for the future of the EU, Macron is determined to lead Europe towards a brighter and more prosperous future. The success of Macron's presidency will ultimately depend on his ability to rally support from other European leaders and gain the trust and confidence of the European people.

title: Potholes cost councils £1,600 a day in compensation
text: highest payout, with £123,000 awarded in compensation for pothole damage. This staggering amount highlights the ongoing issue of poorly maintained roads causing havoc for motorists across the UK. Potholes are a menace on the roads, causing damage to vehicles and posing a safety risk to drivers and pedestrians alike. With the average cost of repairing a pothole estimated to be around £50, it's clear that councils need to do more to address this problem before it gets even worse. Despite efforts to fill in potholes and repair damaged roads, it seems that councils are struggling to keep up with the demands of maintaining a safe and smooth road network. The financial burden of compensating drivers for damage caused by potholes is only adding to the strain on already stretched budgets. Councils are constantly facing tough decisions when it comes to allocating funds, and the issue of road maintenance is often pushed to the bottom of the list. However, the costs of neglecting this vital infrastructure are now becoming all too apparent, as drivers are forced to foot the bill for repairs that could easily have been prevented. In some cases, potholes are left unfixed for long periods of time, leading to further deterioration of the road surface and increasing the risk of accidents. This lack of timely maintenance not only costs councils more money in the long run but also puts lives at risk on a daily basis. It's clear that a more proactive approach is needed to tackle the problem of potholes and ensure that our roads are safe for all who use them. This means investing in regular maintenance and repairs to prevent the need for costly compensation payouts in the future. Ultimately, the cost of ignoring the issue of potholes far outweighs the initial investment required to fix them. By taking action now, councils can save money in the long term and create a safer environment for everyone on the roads. As drivers continue to battle with potholes and the damage they cause, it's crucial that councils step up their efforts to address this ongoing problem. With millions of pounds being paid out every year in compensation, it's clear that the current approach is simply not sustainable. In conclusion, the issue of potholes costing councils £1,600 a day in compensation is a stark reminder of the need for better road maintenance across the UK. By investing in our infrastructure now, we can avoid the high costs of neglecting our roads in the future and ensure a safer journey for all.

title: China 'to survey disputed East China Sea islands'
text: State news agency Xinhua said the survey was part of China's "programme to safeguard its maritime rights and interests". The islands are called Diaoyu in China and Senkaku in Japan. The row over the islands dates back many years, with both countries claiming sovereignty over the territory. The dispute has led to tensions between China and Japan, two of the largest economies in the world. China's decision to conduct a survey of the disputed islands comes at a time when tensions in the region are high. In recent years, China has ramped up its military presence in the East China Sea, prompting concerns from its neighbors and the international community. The United States, in particular, has been closely monitoring the situation and has called for a peaceful resolution to the dispute. The survey of the islands is likely to further strain relations between China and Japan. The two countries have a long history of territorial disputes, and the issue of the Diaoyu/Senkaku islands is one of the most contentious. Both countries view the islands as a symbol of national pride and have been unwilling to back down in the face of opposition. The survey comes just days after a Chinese government spokesman reiterated China's claim to the islands, stating that they are an "inherent part of Chinese territory". Japan, on the other hand, has consistently maintained that the islands belong to them and has bolstered its military presence in the region in response to China's actions. The dispute over the Diaoyu/Senkaku islands is not just a bilateral issue between China and Japan. It also has implications for the broader geopolitical landscape in East Asia. The United States, as a key ally of Japan, has a vested interest in ensuring stability in the region and has pledged to defend Japan in the event of any military conflict over the islands. As tensions continue to escalate in the East China Sea, the international community is closely watching the situation. The survey of the disputed islands by China is likely to be seen as a provocative move by Japan and could further exacerbate the already strained relations between the two countries. The coming weeks and months will be crucial in determining the outcome of this long-standing territorial dispute and the impact it will have on the broader region.

title: First peek at Harry Potter and the Cursed Child play
text: By Amelia Butterly, Newsbeat reporter. Published on Pottermore, JK Rowling's Harry Potter website, the images show a young boy in a nest with wings. The play, split over two parts, is designed to pick up where the final Harry Potter book left off, following Harry, Ron, Hermione, and their children as they navigate the wizarding world. Fans of the series have eagerly awaited a glimpse of the production, which has been shrouded in secrecy since its announcement. The release of these images has sparked excitement and speculation among Potterheads everywhere. The young boy in the nest is none other than Albus Potter, Harry's middle child, who struggles to live up to the legacy of his famous father. The symbolic imagery of the wings hints at Albus's journey to find his own identity and carve out his own place in the magical world. The play promises to explore themes of family, friendship, and the enduring power of love, all of which were central to the original Harry Potter series. Audiences can expect to be taken on a thrilling and emotional ride as they witness the next chapter in the lives of their favorite characters. In addition to the main cast of characters, the play introduces a host of new faces, including Albus's best friend, Scorpius Malfoy, the son of Harry's former nemesis, Draco Malfoy. The dynamic between Albus and Scorpius is sure to be a highlight of the production, as the two boys navigate the challenges of growing up in the shadow of their famous families. The visuals released on Pottermore offer a tantalizing glimpse of the magical world created by JK Rowling, with intricate set designs, stunning costumes, and special effects that bring the wizarding world to life on stage. Fans can expect to be transported back to the beloved Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, as well as new locations that will expand the scope of the Harry Potter universe. As anticipation builds for the premiere of Harry Potter and the Cursed Child, fans around the world are eagerly counting down the days until they can experience the magic for themselves. With these first images offering a taste of what is to come, it is clear that the play will not disappoint in delivering a spellbinding adventure that will delight both longtime fans and newcomers to the series alike.

title: 'Scrap ban' on term-time holidays
text: By Hannah RichardsonBBC News education reporter Since September last year, local authorities have been obliged to fine parents who take children out of school for unauthorised term-time holidays. This controversial policy, known as the 'scrap ban', was introduced in an effort to crack down on students missing valuable learning time and disrupting the flow of lessons. The Department for Education argues that regular attendance at school is crucial for children to reach their full potential and achieve academic success. According to research, even a few missed days of school can have a significant impact on a child's progress and attainment levels. By enforcing fines for unauthorised absences, the government hopes to send a clear message to parents about the importance of consistent school attendance. However, the 'scrap ban' has sparked heated debates among parents, teachers, and education experts. Many argue that the policy unfairly penalises parents who may have valid reasons for taking their children out of school during term-time. Some families face unavoidable circumstances such as illness, family emergencies, or financial constraints that make it difficult to adhere to strict school attendance rules. Moreover, critics of the 'scrap ban' argue that it fails to consider the benefits of taking children out of school for educational or cultural experiences. Travel can be a valuable learning opportunity for students to explore different cultures, languages, and historical sites. Experiential learning outside the classroom can enhance a child's understanding of the world and provide unique insights that cannot be gained from textbooks alone. In response to these concerns, the Department for Education has stated that parents can request permission for term-time absences in exceptional circumstances, such as family weddings or religious observances. However, the discretion of approving these requests lies with school headteachers, who must consider each case individually. Despite the ongoing debate surrounding the 'scrap ban', the government remains steadfast in its commitment to improving school attendance and reducing educational disruptions. Education Secretary Gavin Williamson has expressed confidence that the policy will encourage parents to prioritise their children's education and uphold the expectation of regular school attendance. As the 'scrap ban' continues to generate controversy and mixed reactions, it is clear that finding a balance between promoting school attendance and accommodating family circumstances remains a complex challenge. The ongoing dialogue between policymakers, educators, and parents is crucial in ensuring that children receive a quality education while recognising the diverse needs and experiences of families across the country.

title: Wife 'stunned' by wedding ring find
text: Paul Higson had been scared to tell his wife Jan he had lost the ring and it took him two days to pluck up the courage to confess. But when he finally did, Jan was surprisingly calm and understanding. However, little did they know that this lost ring would come back to them in the most unexpected way. It all started when Jan was cleaning out their garden shed and stumbled upon an old, dirty and worn-out ring hidden in a dusty corner. She was curious and intrigued by the discovery, so she decided to clean it up and take a closer look. As she wiped away the dirt, she couldn't believe her eyes. It was their missing wedding ring! Stunned and speechless, Jan rushed inside to show Paul the miraculous find. The couple was overwhelmed with emotions as they held the ring in their hands, reminiscing about their wedding day and the love they shared. It was a moment they would never forget. As they inspected the ring, they noticed that it had been slightly damaged and the gold was tarnished. But to them, it didn't matter. The ring held sentimental value far beyond its physical appearance. It was a symbol of their commitment, love, and the memories they had created together. Paul and Jan felt grateful and blessed to have found the ring again, and they knew it was a sign that their love was meant to last a lifetime. The missing ring had brought them closer together and reminded them of the importance of cherishing each moment they shared. With tears of joy in their eyes, Paul and Jan decided to renew their vows and exchange the ring once again. It was a beautiful and heartfelt ceremony, filled with laughter, love, and the promise of a forever together. The couple proudly wore their wedding rings, now with a new sense of appreciation and gratitude. They knew that no matter what challenges they faced in the future, their love would always be strong and resilient. As they looked at the ring on Jan's finger, they both smiled, knowing that it was more than just a piece of jewelry. It was a symbol of their enduring love and the bond they shared. And they were grateful for the unexpected twist of fate that brought their lost ring back to them. In the end, Paul and Jan realized that sometimes things get lost along the way, but they always have a way of finding their way back home. Their wedding ring was a reminder of that, and they vowed to never take their love for granted again.

title: Commons could close early due to coronavirus
text: Jacob Rees-Mogg said the option to close early was being considered but added that emergency legislation needed to be approved first. MPs will see other changes to the way the House of Commons operates in the coming weeks in response to the coronavirus outbreak. The proposed closure of the Commons is part of the government's effort to curb the spread of the virus and protect the health and safety of members of parliament, staff, and visitors. Rees-Mogg emphasized that the decision to close early would only be taken if necessary and as a precautionary measure. In addition to the possibility of early closure, other changes being considered include limiting the number of visitors allowed in the Commons, restricting access to certain areas of the parliamentary estate, and implementing social distancing measures within the chamber. These changes are aimed at reducing the risk of transmission of the virus and ensuring that the business of parliament can continue in a safe and responsible manner. Rees-Mogg also announced that MPs who are considered to be at high risk of severe illness from the virus, such as those with underlying health conditions or over the age of 70, will be able to participate in parliamentary proceedings remotely. This will allow them to continue to represent their constituents and contribute to debates and decision-making without having to physically attend the Commons. The government is working closely with parliamentary authorities, public health officials, and experts to ensure that the necessary precautions are in place to protect the health and well-being of everyone in the parliamentary estate. Rees-Mogg urged MPs, staff, and visitors to follow the guidance and advice provided by public health authorities and to take all necessary precautions to prevent the spread of the virus. As the situation continues to evolve, further measures may be implemented to address the challenges posed by the coronavirus outbreak. The government is committed to ensuring that parliament can continue to function effectively and serve the interests of the public, while also prioritizing the health and safety of all those who work in and visit the parliamentary estate. In these uncertain times, it is important for everyone to come together and take collective action to combat the spread of the virus and protect the most vulnerable members of society. The proposed changes to the way the House of Commons operates are a reflection of this commitment to safeguarding public health and ensuring that parliamentary business can continue in a responsible and sustainable manner.

title: VW US sales rise despite scandal
text: previous year, despite the ongoing emissions scandal. Volkswagen has been embroiled in controversy since it was revealed last year that they had installed software in millions of diesel vehicles worldwide to cheat emissions tests. This led to a sharp decline in sales and a tarnished reputation for the German automaker. However, recent sales figures from Volkswagen of America suggest that the company may be turning a corner. Despite the scandal, VW managed to sell over 30,000 cars in the US in October, showing a slight increase compared to the same period last year. The rise in sales can be attributed to several factors. Firstly, Volkswagen has launched an aggressive marketing campaign to regain consumer trust. The company has been emphasizing their commitment to environmental sustainability and transparency, while also offering attractive incentives to customers. Additionally, VW has introduced several new models that have been well-received by consumers. The Tiguan and Atlas SUVs have been particularly popular, appealing to American consumers' growing preference for larger vehicles. Moreover, the overall growth in the US automotive market has also benefited Volkswagen. Low gasoline prices and an improving economy have boosted consumer confidence and willingness to purchase new vehicles, even from a company with a tainted reputation. Despite the positive sales figures, Volkswagen still faces challenges ahead. The emissions scandal has cost the company billions of dollars in fines and settlements, not to mention the damage to its brand image. Rebuilding trust with consumers will be a long and arduous process, requiring consistent efforts from VW to demonstrate accountability and ethical practices. Furthermore, competition in the automotive industry remains fierce, with other carmakers investing heavily in electric and hybrid technology. Volkswagen will need to innovate and adapt quickly to stay competitive in the rapidly evolving market. Overall, the recent rise in US sales for Volkswagen is a promising sign that the company may be on the path to recovery. However, it will require sustained efforts and a commitment to ethical practices to fully regain consumer trust and secure its place in the American automotive market. Only time will tell if Volkswagen can successfully overcome the challenges posed by the emissions scandal and emerge stronger than ever.

title: Women still do more household chores than men, ONS finds
text: The Office for National Statistics said that, when it came to unpaid chores at home, women were doing almost 40% more than men on average. Men averaged 16 hours a week helping out. The disparity in household chores between genders has long been a topic of debate, with many arguing that the burden falls disproportionately on women. Despite advancements in gender equality in the workplace and other areas of society, the ONS findings highlight that traditional gender roles still persist within the confines of the home. The data reveals that women are more likely to take on a larger share of household chores, ranging from cooking and cleaning to childcare and grocery shopping. This division of labor is not only unjust but also perpetuates harmful stereotypes about women's roles in society. Experts believe that the unequal distribution of household chores can have far-reaching consequences, affecting women's mental and physical health, career opportunities, and overall well-being. The ONS findings underscore the need for a more equitable distribution of household responsibilities to ensure that women are not unfairly burdened with the majority of domestic work. In recent years, there have been efforts to challenge these traditional gender norms and promote more equality within the home. Campaigns such as #ShareTheLoad have aimed to raise awareness about the unequal distribution of household chores and encourage both men and women to take on a more equal share of the work. While progress has been made, there is still much work to be done to achieve true gender equality in the home. It is important for both men and women to recognize and challenge the deeply ingrained societal expectations that dictate how household chores should be divided. By working together to create a more balanced and egalitarian approach to domestic responsibilities, we can create a more harmonious and equal society for all. Ultimately, the ONS findings serve as a reminder that gender inequality is not just a problem in the workplace or in public life but also within the confines of the home. It is essential that we continue to challenge these entrenched gender norms and strive towards a more equitable and just society for all.

title: Coronavirus: Ex-soldier self-isolating on 'uninhabited' Hildasay
text: Chris Lewis has walked 12,000 miles after setting off from near his home in Swansea in August 2017. He has now been given special permission to live in the one house on Hildasay, Shetland, a remote uninhabited island off the coast of Scotland, due to the coronavirus pandemic. The 67-year-old ex-soldier had been traveling around the world on foot, but when the outbreak of the virus hit, he found himself stranded in Shetland. With limited options for accommodation, he was granted permission to stay on Hildasay, where he now finds himself in self-isolation. Living alone on the island, surrounded by nothing but nature, Lewis has embraced the solitude and tranquility that comes with being isolated. He spends his days exploring the rugged terrain, fishing for his meals, and taking in the stunning views of the surrounding sea. Despite being in self-isolation, Lewis has not lost his sense of adventure. He continues to document his journey, sharing his experiences with the world through his blog and social media channels. His story has captivated audiences around the globe, offering a glimpse into the life of a man who has chosen to live off the grid in the midst of a global crisis. As the pandemic rages on, Lewis remains hopeful that he will eventually be able to continue his journey. But for now, he is content to call Hildasay home and to embrace the challenges that come with living on an uninhabited island. In the midst of uncertainty and fear, Lewis serves as a reminder of the resilience of the human spirit. His determination to continue his journey despite the obstacles in his path is a testament to the strength and endurance of the human soul. As the world grapples with the challenges posed by the coronavirus pandemic, Lewis's story offers a sense of hope and inspiration. It is a reminder that even in the face of adversity, there is always a way forward, and that with perseverance and determination, anything is possible. While the world waits for the pandemic to pass, Chris Lewis continues to walk his path, one step at a time, on the road less traveled. And in doing so, he reminds us all of the power of the human spirit to overcome even the most daunting of challenges.

title: Putin's Stasi spy ID pass found in Germany
text: Russian and East German secret services. The discovery of Putin's Stasi spy ID pass in Germany has raised questions about his past activities and connections during his time in Dresden. Putin, who was stationed in Dresden from 1985 to 1990, has often spoken about his time as a KGB officer in East Germany. He has described his role as primarily focused on intelligence gathering and counterintelligence operations. However, the revelation of his Stasi pass has brought new scrutiny to his activities during that period. The Stasi, the secret police of East Germany, was known for its extensive surveillance and repression of dissidents. The close co-operation between the KGB and Stasi was well-documented, and Putin's possession of a Stasi spy ID pass suggests that he was actively involved in intelligence operations in East Germany. Putin's spokesperson has downplayed the significance of the discovery, stating that it was not uncommon for KGB officers to have relationships with other intelligence agencies. However, some experts believe that the revelation of Putin's Stasi pass could have implications for his current role as the president of Russia. The timing of the discovery is particularly notable, as tensions between Russia and Western countries have been on the rise in recent years. Relations between Russia and Germany, in particular, have been strained over issues such as the conflict in Ukraine and allegations of Russian interference in Western elections. The revelation of Putin's Stasi pass could further strain relations between Russia and Germany, as it raises questions about his past connections and activities. Some German politicians have called for further investigation into Putin's time in Dresden, and there are calls for transparency about his activities during that period. Despite the controversy surrounding the discovery, Putin has not shied away from his past as a KGB officer. In a recent interview, he stated that he was proud of his service in the KGB and that it had shaped his worldview. He emphasized the importance of intelligence work in protecting national security and stated that he had always acted in the interests of his country. As more information about Putin's past comes to light, it is clear that his time in Dresden continues to be a topic of interest and speculation. The discovery of his Stasi pass has only added to the intrigue surrounding his early career as a KGB officer, and it remains to be seen what further revelations may come to light in the future.

title: Trump tariffs: President says EU makes business 'impossible'
text: Defending his tariff plans as he hosted the Swedish PM at the White House, Mr Trump said other countries had "taken advantage of" the US for decades. Shortly afterwards it was announced that the European Union would be among the targets of his latest wave of trade measures. The president stated that the EU has made it "impossible" for American businesses to compete on a level playing field. The proposed tariffs on steel and aluminum imports have caused a stir among EU officials, who have vowed to retaliate if the measures are implemented. European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker called the plans "blatant protectionism" and warned that the EU would not hesitate to impose countermeasures on American products. The EU is not the only target of Mr. Trump's ire. He has also taken aim at China, accusing the country of engaging in unfair trade practices that harm American workers. The president has threatened to impose tariffs on a wide range of Chinese imports in an effort to level the playing field. Critics of the president's tariff plans have warned that they could have a negative impact on the US economy. Many American businesses rely on imported steel and aluminum to manufacture their products, and higher tariffs could lead to increased production costs and job losses. In response to these concerns, Mr. Trump has insisted that the tariffs are necessary to protect American industries from unfair competition. He has argued that other countries have long taken advantage of the US by flooding the market with cheap goods, putting American companies at a disadvantage. The president's tough stance on trade has been a key part of his economic agenda since taking office. He has repeatedly promised to prioritize American workers and bring manufacturing jobs back to the US. While his supporters have praised him for taking a hard line on trade, critics have accused him of sparking a trade war that could harm the global economy. As tensions continue to escalate over the proposed tariffs, the international community is watching closely to see how the situation unfolds. Many are concerned about the potential impact of a trade war between the US and its trading partners, and are calling for a diplomatic solution to the current standoff. Only time will tell what the future holds for US trade policy under the Trump administration. As the president continues to push for tougher trade measures, the global economy hangs in the balance.

title: Sir Terry Matthews: Wales lacks IT commerce skills
text: we need are individuals with the specific skills and expertise in information technology to drive our economy forward." Sir Terry Matthews, a prominent figure in the tech industry and one of Wales' most successful entrepreneurs, has been vocal about the need for Wales to develop a stronger IT workforce. In his upcoming address at the conference in Newport, he plans to highlight the importance of harnessing technology to streamline processes, improve efficiency, and ultimately increase profits for businesses in Wales. "We have a wealth of innovative thinkers in Wales, but what we lack are individuals with the technical know-how to turn those ideas into reality," Sir Terry explained. "In order for our country to remain competitive in the global market, we must invest in developing a workforce that is skilled in information technology." With a career that spans several decades in the tech industry, Sir Terry has seen firsthand the impact that advancements in IT can have on business growth. From founding successful companies like Mitel and Newbridge Networks to investing in promising startups through his venture capital firm Wesley Clover, he is a firm believer in the power of technology to drive economic success. However, Sir Terry also recognizes the challenge that Wales faces in attracting and retaining top IT talent. "We need to create an environment that is conducive to fostering a strong IT workforce," he noted. "This includes investing in education and training programs, promoting collaboration between businesses and universities, and offering competitive salaries and benefits to tech professionals." In addition to addressing the skills gap in IT, Sir Terry is also passionate about supporting diversity and inclusion in the tech industry. "We must ensure that opportunities in IT are accessible to individuals from all backgrounds, regardless of gender, race, or socioeconomic status," he emphasized. As Sir Terry prepares to take the stage at the conference in Newport, he hopes to inspire business leaders, policymakers, and educators to join forces in strengthening Wales' IT workforce. "By investing in our people and providing them with the tools they need to succeed, we can build a thriving tech ecosystem that benefits not only businesses but our entire economy," he concluded. With his wealth of experience and unwavering dedication to advancing the tech sector in Wales, Sir Terry Matthews serves as a guiding light for the country as it navigates the challenges and opportunities of the digital age.

title: Wales council mergers: Cost could be £200m, says WLGA
text: reorganisation could lead to potential savings of around £146 million over a 10-year period. Despite this estimate, the Welsh Local Government Association (WLGA) has expressed concerns over the potential costs involved in implementing these mergers. In a recent statement, WLGA chief executive Steve Thomas highlighted the projected cost of the council mergers, suggesting that it could reach up to £200 million. This significant financial burden has raised questions about the feasibility and practicality of the proposed reorganisation. Thomas emphasized the importance of ensuring that any mergers are carried out in a way that minimizes costs and maximizes efficiency. He stressed that the focus should be on delivering improved services to residents while also making the most of public resources. The Williams Commission's recommendation to reduce the number of local authorities in Wales has been met with mixed reactions. Supporters argue that streamlining council structures could lead to better coordination and more effective decision-making. However, opponents raise concerns about the potential impact on local communities and the delivery of vital services. One of the key arguments in favor of council mergers is the potential for cost savings through economies of scale. By consolidating resources and reducing duplication, it is believed that local authorities could operate more efficiently and effectively. This could result in better services for residents and a more sustainable financial future for councils. Despite the projected financial benefits of the proposed mergers, the WLGA remains cautious about the potential risks and challenges that lie ahead. Thomas emphasized the need for careful planning and consideration to ensure a smooth transition and minimal disruption to services. As discussions around the future of local government in Wales continue, it is clear that there are complex issues at play. Balancing financial considerations with the need to deliver high-quality services to residents will require careful thought and strategic decision-making. Ultimately, the success of any council mergers will depend on the ability of local authorities to work together collaboratively and effectively. Finding the right balance between cost savings and service delivery will be crucial in determining the long-term impact of these proposed changes on communities across Wales.

title: Rory Cowan: 'Unhappy' Mrs Brown's Boys actor quits
text: Cowan said he had been "unhappy", and left his co-stars after a Mrs Brown show at London's O2 Arena on Sunday. He has worked with the comedy's creator Brendan O'Carroll for 26 years. "I hadn't been happy working for the Mrs Brown's Boys TV company for the last 18 months," Cowan told the Irish Sun. The Irish actor, who played Agnes Brown's son Rory in the hit comedy show, explained that he was not enjoying his time on set and had been struggling with the long hours and time away from home. Cowan also mentioned that he had been feeling unappreciated by the showrunners. "I feel that 26 years is enough so I decided it was time to go," he added. Cowan expressed his gratitude towards O'Carroll for giving him the opportunity to work on the show, but stated that it was time for him to move on. Following Cowan's departure, O'Carroll released a statement expressing his sadness over the situation. "To all of us it feels like a death in the family," he said. O'Carroll praised Cowan for his dedication and talent, stating that he would be greatly missed on set. Mrs Brown's Boys has been a huge success since it first aired in 2011, with its mix of slapstick humor and heartwarming family moments winning over audiences worldwide. The show has been praised for its relatable characters and clever writing, with Cowan's portrayal of Rory being a fan favorite. Fans of the show have taken to social media to express their support for Cowan and share their disappointment over his departure. Many have praised his comedic timing and chemistry with the rest of the cast, highlighting his contributions to the show's success. As for Cowan, he has not yet announced his future plans but mentioned that he would be taking some time to relax and reflect on his next steps. The actor also expressed his gratitude towards Mrs Brown's Boys fans for their support over the years. While Cowan's departure is certainly a blow to the show, fans are hopeful that Mrs Brown's Boys will continue to entertain audiences with its unique brand of comedy. As for Cowan, his decision to leave the show marks the end of an era, but also the beginning of a new chapter in his career.

title: John Boehner survives House rebellion in US Congress
text: focus of heated debate during the House vote. The pipeline, which would transport oil from Canada to the Gulf of Mexico, has been a contentious issue among Republicans and Democrats alike. Ahead of the vote, Mr Boehner made it clear that the Keystone XL pipeline would be a key priority for the Republican-controlled House. He argued that the pipeline would create jobs and boost the economy, while opponents raised concerns about its environmental impact. Despite the internal opposition within his own party, Mr Boehner was able to rally enough support to secure his position as Speaker of the House. In a statement following the vote, he expressed gratitude for the faith his colleagues had shown in him and vowed to continue working towards the party's goals. The rebellion against Mr Boehner was seen as a sign of the growing divide within the Republican party between its moderate and conservative factions. Some members of the more conservative wing have criticized Mr Boehner for not being aggressive enough in pushing for conservative policies, while others have praised him for his leadership in a hostile political environment. As the new Congress gets underway, Mr Boehner faces the challenge of uniting the Republican party behind a common agenda. With a slim majority in the House and a Democratic president in the White House, passing legislation will require careful negotiation and compromise. One of the first items on the agenda is the approval of the Keystone XL pipeline, which is likely to face strong opposition from Democrats. President Obama has threatened to veto any legislation approving the pipeline, citing concerns about its environmental impact. In addition to the Keystone XL pipeline, the Republican agenda includes efforts to repeal or defund parts of the Affordable Care Act, also known as Obamacare. Republicans have long been critical of the healthcare law, arguing that it is burdensome and costly to implement. Despite the challenges ahead, Mr Boehner remains optimistic about the prospects for the Republican party in the new Congress. He has pledged to work with his colleagues on both sides of the aisle to find common ground and advance the party's agenda. As the dust settles on the House rebellion, Mr Boehner and his supporters are looking ahead to the next battles on the horizon. With a divided Congress and a contentious political climate, the Speaker of the House faces a tough road ahead, but he remains determined to lead his party towards a successful future.

title: Mayor hopes Treasury will hop on board travel plans
text: key part of his ambitious plans to revolutionize the city's transport network. Sadiq Khan, the Mayor of London, is hoping that the UK Treasury will hop on board with his vision and provide the necessary funding to make it a reality. The 'New Bus for London' is a hybrid electric double-decker bus that has been designed to be more environmentally friendly and efficient than its predecessors. It is equipped with state-of-the-art technology, including regenerative braking and low-emission engines, making it a symbol of London's commitment to sustainability. During his visit to Northern Ireland, Mayor Khan highlighted the economic benefits of investing in public transport infrastructure. He emphasized the importance of creating high-skilled jobs in the manufacturing sector and promoting innovation in the transport industry. The new chassis production line, which is a joint venture between a London-based company and a Northern Irish manufacturer, is expected to create hundreds of jobs and boost local economies on both sides of the Irish Sea. However, Mayor Khan faces a significant challenge in securing the necessary funding for his transport plans. With the UK government's austerity measures and cuts to local authority budgets, he will need to convince the Treasury to prioritize investment in public transport to make his vision a reality. In a statement to BBC News, a spokesperson for the Treasury acknowledged the importance of improving transport infrastructure in London but indicated that any funding decisions would need to be made in the context of wider budget constraints. The spokesperson emphasized the need to consider value for money and cost-effectiveness in any investment proposals. Despite the challenges, Mayor Khan remains optimistic about the future of London's transport network. He has pledged to work closely with the government and other stakeholders to secure the necessary funding and support for his plans. He believes that investing in public transport is not only essential for addressing congestion and pollution in the capital but also for driving economic growth and creating a more inclusive and sustainable city for all residents. As Mayor Khan continues to champion his vision for a greener, more efficient transport system in London, all eyes will be on the Treasury to see if they will hop on board with his plans and provide the funding needed to make them a reality. The stakes are high, but the potential benefits for the city and its residents are even higher. Only time will tell if Mayor Khan's ambitious vision for London's transport future will come to fruition.

title: ME, or chronic fatigue syndrome, 'not caused by the XMRV virus', say researchers
text: By Helen Briggs Health reporter, BBC News US scientists linked the condition, also known as ME, to a mouse-like virus in 2009 after finding it in blood samples. Now, new research has cast doubt on this connection. A study published in the journal Science Translational Medicine reports that the XMRV virus is not a cause of ME, also known as chronic fatigue syndrome. The controversy began in 2009 when a team led by Dr Judy Mikovits, then at the Whittemore Peterson Institute in Nevada, published a paper linking XMRV to chronic fatigue syndrome. The paper suggested that the virus could be transmitted through blood transfusions and that it might be linked to prostate cancer. However, subsequent studies failed to replicate the findings, and the original paper was retracted in 2011. Dr Mikovits was later fired from her job and became embroiled in legal disputes with her former employer. The new study, led by Dr John Coffin from Tufts University in Massachusetts, found no evidence of XMRV in blood samples from 293 patients with ME. The researchers used a highly sensitive method to detect the virus, known as PCR, which amplifies the genetic material of the virus. "We found absolutely no evidence of XMRV in any of these patients," Dr Coffin told BBC News. "This study provides very strong evidence that XMRV is not the cause of ME." The findings are likely to be welcomed by patients with ME who have long been frustrated by the lack of effective treatments for their condition. ME is a disabling illness characterized by extreme fatigue, pain, and cognitive problems. Sarah, a 30-year-old woman from London who has been diagnosed with ME, said she was relieved to hear that the XMRV virus is not the cause of the condition. "This research provides some hope that we may one day find the true cause of ME and develop better treatments," she said. Dr Coffin said that the search for the cause of ME should continue, as it is likely to be a complex disease with multiple contributing factors. "ME is a very real illness that can have devastating effects on people's lives," he said. "We need to keep looking for answers so that we can help patients who are suffering." The research was funded by the National Institutes of Health and the US Department of Defense. The findings are likely to have implications for future research into the causes of ME and the development of new treatments for the condition.

title: Boris Johnson: Intelligence questions raise trust issue again
text: Laura Kuenssberg Political editor @bbclaurakon Twitter The questions that many of his colleagues aren't quite sure about. And of course, the question that the front runner to become prime minister in a few weeks answers heartily, yes of course. But the doubts persist, lingering like a dark cloud over the leadership of Boris Johnson. The latest revelation that Johnson failed to attend crucial meetings of the Cobra emergency committee while foreign secretary has sparked fresh concerns about his ability to lead effectively. Cobra meetings are held to coordinate the government's response to national emergencies, such as terrorist attacks or natural disasters. Johnson's absence from these vital discussions has raised serious doubts about his commitment to national security and his grasp of crucial intelligence information. This is not the first time that questions have been raised about Johnson's intelligence and trustworthiness. During his tenure as foreign secretary, he was accused of mishandling sensitive diplomatic matters and making inappropriate comments that jeopardized Britain's relationships with its allies. His tendency to make off-the-cuff remarks and his lack of attention to detail have caused alarm among many in the political establishment. While Johnson may project an image of joviality and confidence, there are growing concerns that he lacks the seriousness and gravitas required to lead the country in these uncertain times. His track record of gaffes and blunders has led many to question whether he is truly fit to be prime minister. Furthermore, Johnson's refusal to answer questions about his personal life and past actions has only fuelled suspicions about his integrity and honesty. His evasiveness on key issues, such as his relationship with businesswoman Jennifer Arcuri and the true nature of his Brexit plans, has eroded public trust in his leadership. As the Conservative Party prepares to elect its new leader and the country braces for the possibility of a no-deal Brexit, the specter of Boris Johnson looms large. Can he be trusted to navigate Britain through these tumultuous times with wisdom and skill? Or will his penchant for controversy and chaos only lead to further instability and division? The intelligence questions surrounding Boris Johnson raise serious doubts about his ability to lead with integrity and competence. As the next prime minister of the United Kingdom, he will face a myriad of challenges that require a steady hand and a clear mind. Whether he can rise to the occasion remains to be seen. The eyes of the nation are watching, waiting to see if Johnson can prove his skeptics wrong and earn the trust of the British people.

title: Man's surgery wait death 'avoidable', says ombudsman
text: board confirmed that the delay in Gareth's surgery was "avoidable" and acknowledged the failings in the management of his care. Gareth was a loving husband and father of two young children. He had been living with ACHD for several years and was awaiting a surgical procedure that could potentially improve his quality of life. However, due to a series of administrative errors and communication breakdowns within the healthcare system, Gareth's operation was repeatedly postponed. The ombudsman's report highlighted that Gareth's case was not an isolated incident, but rather a symptom of a larger issue within the NHS. Long waiting times for surgeries, understaffed hospitals, and poor coordination between healthcare providers have all contributed to the unnecessary deaths of patients like Gareth. Gareth's widow, Emily, has been vocal in her criticism of the healthcare system and has called for greater accountability and transparency in the handling of patients with complex medical conditions. She believes that if Gareth had received the timely care and attention he deserved, he would still be alive today. The ombudsman has made a series of recommendations to prevent similar tragedies from occurring in the future. These include improved training for healthcare staff, better communication between different departments, and a more streamlined process for managing surgical waitlists. The health board has issued a public apology to Gareth's family and has pledged to implement the ombudsman's recommendations. They have also promised to conduct a thorough review of their internal processes to ensure that such mistakes are not repeated. Gareth's death has sparked a national conversation about the importance of timely access to healthcare services and the need for a more patient-centric approach to medical care. His tragic story serves as a cautionary tale for healthcare providers across the country, reminding them of the profound impact that their decisions can have on the lives of their patients. As the healthcare system grapples with the aftermath of Gareth's death, his family continues to mourn his loss and seek justice for the avoidable tragedy that befell him. They hope that by sharing his story, they can prevent similar incidents from happening in the future and ensure that no family has to endure the pain and suffering that they have experienced.

title: Le Patourel brothers could be set for Guernsey blue plaque honour
text: Oxford, and a respected historian who specialized in medieval France. His younger brother, Philip, was a talented artist known for his watercolor paintings of the Guernsey landscape. The Le Patourel brothers were born and raised in Guernsey, where they developed a deep love and appreciation for the island's history and culture. Their contributions to the fields of history and art have left a lasting impact on the island and beyond, making them deserving candidates for a blue plaque honour. John Herbert Le Patourel's groundbreaking research on medieval France helped to shape our understanding of this period in history. His work has been instrumental in illuminating the political, social, and cultural dynamics of medieval society, and his publications are still widely regarded as seminal texts in the field. As a professor at the University of Oxford, he inspired countless students with his passion for history and his innovative approach to research. Philip Le Patourel, on the other hand, captured the beauty of the Guernsey landscape with his evocative watercolor paintings. His artistry brought to life the natural splendor of the island, showcasing its unique charm and character. His paintings have been exhibited in galleries around the world, garnering critical acclaim for their exquisite detail and vibrant colors. The proposed blue plaque would commemorate the legacy of the Le Patourel brothers and celebrate their significant contributions to the fields of history and art. It would serve as a testament to their lasting impact on Guernsey's cultural heritage and inspire future generations to continue their pursuit of knowledge and creativity. Local residents have expressed their support for the blue plaque proposal, citing the brothers' importance in Guernsey's history and the need to recognize their achievements. If approved, the plaque would be a fitting tribute to John Herbert and Philip Le Patourel, honoring their dedication to their respective fields and their profound connection to Guernsey. The blue plaque would be a symbol of pride for the island and a reminder of the rich heritage that the Le Patourel brothers helped to preserve and promote. It would stand as a testament to their enduring legacy and inspire others to follow in their footsteps, pursuing excellence in the fields of history and art. As the proposal moves forward, local authorities are hopeful that the blue plaque will be installed at the brothers' former home in the Fosse Andre, in St Peter Port. It would be a fitting location for the plaque, situated in the heart of Guernsey where the Le Patourel brothers' passion for history and art first took root.

title: Covid: Device aids 'virtual' treatment of Leicester patients
text: University Hospitals of Leicester Trust said a small blood oxygen monitor meant it had treated 130 people at home. Patients take their own readings and are checked daily over the phone by a specially-trained nursing team. Andy Hughes, a senior respiratory consultant at the trust, explained that the device allows them to closely monitor patients' oxygen levels remotely, providing crucial insights into their respiratory health without the need for frequent hospital visits. The Covid-19 pandemic has presented numerous challenges for healthcare systems worldwide, with hospitals often overwhelmed by the sheer volume of patients needing care. In response, many medical facilities have turned to innovative solutions to ensure that patients continue to receive the treatment they need while minimizing the risk of exposure to the virus. The use of remote monitoring devices like the blood oxygen monitor in Leicester is a prime example of how technology can be leveraged to provide quality care to patients in the comfort of their own homes. This virtual approach to healthcare has proven to be effective in reducing the burden on hospitals and allowing patients to recover in familiar surroundings. By empowering patients to take an active role in monitoring their health, healthcare providers can also gain valuable insights into their condition, enabling them to make informed decisions about their care. The use of remote monitoring devices not only helps to alleviate the strain on hospital resources but also allows for more personalized and patient-centered care. The success of the remote monitoring program at University Hospitals of Leicester Trust highlights the potential of digital health solutions in transforming the way healthcare is delivered. As the world continues to grapple with the challenges posed by the Covid-19 pandemic, innovative approaches to healthcare delivery will become increasingly important in ensuring that patients receive the care they need in a safe and efficient manner. The use of devices like the blood oxygen monitor in Leicester is a step in the right direction towards harnessing the power of technology to improve patient outcomes and enhance the overall healthcare experience. In conclusion, the virtual treatment of Leicester patients using remote monitoring devices represents a significant advancement in healthcare delivery, particularly in the context of the Covid-19 pandemic. By leveraging technology to empower patients and provide personalized care, hospitals can ensure that patients receive the treatment they need while minimizing the risk of exposure to the virus. The success of the remote monitoring program at University Hospitals of Leicester Trust serves as a testament to the potential of digital health solutions in revolutionizing the way healthcare is delivered, paving the way for a more patient-centered and efficient healthcare system.

title: Monarch airline awaits package holiday licence decision
text: future of the beleaguered airline. Monarch, Britain's fifth largest airline, has been operating for over 50 years and employs around 2,750 staff. The company has been struggling financially in recent months, with reports suggesting that it is in need of a cash injection to survive. The decision to extend Monarch's licence by just 24 hours has left passengers and staff feeling anxious about the future of the airline. The CAA's decision to delay announcing the fate of Monarch has led to speculation about what the future holds for this iconic British airline. Rumours have been swirling about potential buyers and investors who may be interested in saving Monarch from collapse. However, with no official announcement from the CAA, the uncertainty continues to hang over the airline like a dark cloud. Passengers who have booked package holidays with Monarch are also facing uncertainty about whether their trips will go ahead as planned. Without a valid ATOL licence, Monarch would not be able to legally sell package holidays, leaving thousands of holidaymakers in limbo. The CAA's delay in making a decision on Monarch's licence has only added to the confusion and frustration felt by these passengers. With the fate of Monarch hanging in the balance, the company's employees are also feeling the strain. Many staff members have been with the airline for years and are now faced with the possibility of losing their jobs if Monarch ceases operations. The lack of clarity from the CAA has left employees unsure about their future job security, adding to the stress and anxiety of an already difficult situation. Industry experts are watching the situation closely, with some speculating that Monarch may not survive the current financial turmoil. The airline industry is notoriously volatile, with many airlines facing financial difficulties in recent years. If Monarch were to go under, it would be the biggest airline collapse in the UK since the demise of XL Airways in 2008. As the clock ticks on and the uncertainty continues, all eyes are on the CAA to make a decision on Monarch's licence. The fate of this iconic British airline hangs in the balance, with passengers, employees, and industry experts all eagerly awaiting news of what the future holds for Monarch. Only time will tell whether Monarch will be able to weather the storm and continue flying the skies for years to come.

title: 'Tuition grants affecting Welsh universities'
text: approach to ensure that those who can afford to pay, do so. Under the current system, the Welsh government provides a tuition fee grant to cover the cost of tuition for Welsh students studying at universities in Wales. This policy was initially introduced to attract more students to higher education and relieve financial burden on families. However, with the rising costs of higher education, Prof Colin Riordan believes it is time for a reassessment. In a recent interview with the BBC, Prof Riordan expressed his concerns about the sustainability of the tuition fee grant policy. He argued that the current system is not fair to all students, as it does not take into account their financial circumstances. By moving towards a means-tested approach, he believes that the funding can be allocated more efficiently to those who truly need it. The proposal for a means-tested approach has sparked debate among policymakers and stakeholders in the education sector. While some agree with Prof Riordan's stance, others argue that such a change could deter students from lower-income backgrounds from pursuing higher education. They fear that the introduction of means testing could create barriers for these students, making it harder for them to access education. However, Prof Riordan is adamant that a means-tested approach is necessary to ensure the long-term viability of Welsh universities. He emphasized the importance of investing in higher education to maintain the quality and reputation of Welsh universities. By shifting the focus towards targeted funding for those in need, he believes that the education sector can better support students and improve overall outcomes. In response to the concerns raised, the Welsh government has announced plans to conduct a thorough review of the tuition fee grant policy. Education Minister Jeremy Miles stated that the government is committed to making higher education more accessible and affordable for all students in Wales. The review will seek input from various stakeholders, including universities, student organizations, and policymakers, to ensure that any changes are made in the best interest of students. As discussions continue on the future of tuition grants affecting Welsh universities, the importance of finding a sustainable funding model remains at the forefront. Prof Colin Riordan's call for a means-tested approach has sparked a crucial debate on how best to support students and ensure that higher education remains accessible to all. The outcome of the review will have far-reaching implications for the education sector in Wales, shaping the future of tuition grants and the accessibility of higher education for generations to come. As stakeholders work towards a consensus, the need to balance affordability with quality education will be paramount in shaping the policies that will impact the next wave of students in Wales.

title: NHS pressure: Hospital corridors 'the new emergency wards'
text: By Nick TriggleHealth correspondent The warning comes as figures for the NHS in England showed January was one of the most difficult months on record. Record numbers of seriously-ill patients faced delays in being seen in hospital emergency departments, leading to overcrowding and pressure on the healthcare system. This pressure has forced hospitals to resort to extreme measures, with reports emerging of patients being treated in hospital corridors due to the lack of available beds. Some hospitals have even been forced to designate corridors as makeshift emergency wards, with patients lined up on trolleys waiting to be seen by overwhelmed medical staff. The situation is dire, with healthcare workers facing unprecedented levels of stress and exhaustion as they struggle to provide care to a growing number of patients. The toll on both patients and staff is evident, with reports of delays in treatment leading to increased suffering and poor outcomes for those in need of urgent care. This crisis in the NHS is not a new phenomenon, but rather a symptom of long-standing issues within the healthcare system. Years of underfunding, staff shortages, and lack of adequate resources have contributed to the current state of affairs, with hospitals struggling to cope with the increasing demands placed upon them. The pressure on the NHS is further exacerbated by the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, which has stretched healthcare services to their limits. Hospitals are facing a dual challenge of treating a surge in COVID-19 cases while also trying to maintain essential services for patients with other illnesses and injuries. The government has pledged additional funding to help alleviate the strain on the NHS, with promises of increased investment in healthcare services and efforts to recruit more staff. However, critics argue that these measures are not enough to address the systemic issues facing the NHS and that more comprehensive reforms are needed to ensure the sustainability of the healthcare system in the long term. In the meantime, hospitals continue to struggle to cope with the pressures of winter, with patients increasingly being treated in hospital corridors and makeshift emergency wards. The sight of sick and vulnerable people waiting for care in overcrowded and under-resourced facilities is a stark reminder of the challenges facing the NHS and the urgent need for action to address them. Without significant changes and investment, the situation is likely to worsen, with potentially devastating consequences for patients and healthcare workers alike.

title: Celebrities join calls to axe sixth-form 'learning tax'
text: By Judith Burns Education reporter, BBC News Unlike schools and academies, sixth-form colleges in England are unable to claim back their VAT costs. The government says they are liable for the tax because they are "independent" institutions, despite the fact that they provide essential education to thousands of young people across the country. This so-called "learning tax" has been a point of contention for years, with many arguing that it puts a financial strain on sixth-form colleges and limits their ability to provide quality education to students. Now, a group of celebrities has joined calls to axe the tax in order to ensure that all young people have access to the education they deserve. Actor and activist Emma Watson, known for her role as Hermione Granger in the Harry Potter series, has been vocal in her support for abolishing the tax. In a recent interview, she stated, "Education is a basic human right, and no student should be denied access to quality learning because of a tax that unfairly targets sixth-form colleges. It's time for the government to address this issue and level the playing field for all students." Joining Watson in the fight against the "learning tax" is musician and philanthropist Beyoncé. In a statement released on social media, Beyoncé wrote, "Every young person deserves the chance to succeed, regardless of their background or financial situation. By abolishing the VAT on sixth-form colleges, we can ensure that all students have the resources they need to reach their full potential." The support from these high-profile figures has brought renewed attention to the issue of the "learning tax" and put pressure on the government to take action. Many are hopeful that with such influential voices backing the cause, real change can be achieved for sixth-form colleges and the students they serve. While the government has yet to announce any plans to abolish the VAT on sixth-form colleges, the growing momentum behind the campaign is a promising sign for those advocating for fair and equal access to education. As the debate continues, it is clear that the support of celebrities and public figures will play a crucial role in pushing for much-needed reform in the education system. In the meantime, sixth-form colleges continue to operate under financial strain, struggling to provide the same level of support and resources as other educational institutions. The call to axe the "learning tax" grows louder by the day, with students, teachers, and now celebrities all united in their demand for change. Only time will tell if their voices are heard and if the government will finally address this long-standing issue.

title: Edinburgh's Christmas: Market did not have 2018 planning consent
text: Underbelly are still awaiting planning permission to operate in 2019/20, and still need a crucial building warrant. The council said the market would not go ahead as planned on Saturday if the warrant was refused. It comes after safety fears were raised regarding the structure of the market's festive attractions. The Edinburgh Christmas Market has been a staple of the city's holiday season for years, attracting tourists and locals alike with its festive atmosphere and array of vendors selling unique gifts and treats. However, concerns have been raised about the safety of the market's structures, prompting the council to withhold the necessary permissions for the event to go ahead. The market, which was set to open this weekend, features a variety of attractions including a Ferris wheel, ice rink, and stalls selling food and crafts. However, without the required building warrant, it is unclear whether these attractions will be able to operate safely. The council has stated that they are working with Underbelly to address the safety concerns and ensure that the market can go ahead as planned. However, if the necessary permissions are not obtained in time, the event may have to be cancelled. In a statement, a spokesperson for the council said: "The safety of the public is our top priority, and we cannot allow the Christmas Market to go ahead if there are doubts about the safety of the structures. We are working closely with Underbelly to resolve these issues, but if the necessary permissions are not obtained by the scheduled opening date, we may have no choice but to cancel the event." Underbelly, the events company responsible for running the market, has expressed confidence that they will be able to address the concerns raised by the council and obtain the necessary permissions to operate. In a statement, they said: "We take the safety of our customers and staff very seriously, and we are working with the council to ensure that all necessary safety measures are in place. We are confident that we will be able to obtain the required permissions in time for the market to open as planned." Despite the uncertainty surrounding the market's opening, many are hopeful that a solution will be found in time for the event to go ahead. The Edinburgh Christmas Market is a beloved tradition for many in the city, and its cancellation would undoubtedly be disappointing for both locals and visitors looking forward to getting into the festive spirit.

title: Diana documentary: What the critics said
text: highest ratings in years, drawing in millions of viewers eager to catch a glimpse into the private life of the beloved Princess Diana. Despite the mixed reactions, the documentary has sparked important conversations about mental health, the pressures of fame, and the complexities of life within the royal family. Many viewers have expressed empathy for Diana and admiration for her strength in facing adversity with grace and resilience. Some have even drawn parallels between Diana's experiences and those of other public figures, highlighting the universal challenges that come with living in the spotlight. As the debates rage on, one thing is clear: Princess Diana's legacy continues to endure, captivating audiences decades after her tragic death. Her words, captured on tape, serve as a poignant reminder of her humanity and the struggles she faced behind the glamorous facade of royalty. Whether the documentary is praised or criticized, one thing remains certain – Diana's story will always be one that fascinates and inspires us all.
